content:
Posted: November 23, 2014
Simple yet strategic game, 7.5/10.However, after hours of gameplay, it appears to be quite hard to find a opponent (occationally same opponents), and you can sort of call it a "pay to win" game. Don't get me wrong, its is possible to play and win without paying at all, but investing money in this game can potencially gain you a huge adventage. However, its not too hard to get more cards (just not as good), most of the commons and uncommons of the Core 2013 booster pack can be obtained, just by playing through the campaign. And When some achievments (non-steam) is unlocked, players somtimes / often will get a couple of cards (~10). And In game currency can also buy player some cards. For 15 cards packs (which garenteeds 3 uncommon and a rare) cost players around 5250 IP(In-game Points) *NOTE each win gains player around 150 IP, each lost will only award the player for 75 IP (to get a fifteen cards deck requires around 35 wins) or 300 LP (~3 USD). Or players can also start with a "pre-made" deck which  defined each factions. (Players are strongly recommended to finish the campaign before purchasing any one of them, due to the fairly high pricing at 12, 950 IP (87 wins) or 750 LP (~4.80 USD). I recommend beginers to spent ~20 USD first and buy ONE deck, and 7 packs  of 15-card booster, that should start player off in the game. (NOTE* please check this site http://infinity-wars.wikia.com/wiki/Infinity_Wars_Wiki  to determine which 15-card booster you are purchasing.) DO NOT buy Core 2013, player will gain most of those cards within campaign. For cards you want, however did not have the luck to fetch them from the booster, no worries, players can go on the Trade Channel (the second option of chat box channels in the lower left conor of the window) and the common language is looking for (LF), want to trade (WTT) [Trade out]. (NOTE* players are required to be at level five or above in order to invite a trade, however, players can message the other trader to invite instead) Good luck for fetching cards! Enjoy the game! If this is helpful please dont forget to rate up this review so others can see it. Thanks you!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 29, 2016
												It's so close to getting a recommendation, and I actually really like this game but there are just some things that really rub me the wrong way.I've left the game for a few months and came back because I got a promo code. I didn't leave because of any specific problem, I just didn't feel like playing it for a while.So I started a rift run, got super nice cards, lost one match fairly and lost 2 by awful misfortune. Well damn, but that happens. I still love doing rift runs because the game mechanic is just nice.So I use the promo booster, grind some IP and buy the rift deck so I can improve my drafted deck.And not long after, on another rift run, I get 2 luckstomps again. Ugh. Well, I almost never handle RNG gracefully and I once had streak of misfortune in games that if reserved would make me win the lotto jackpot. Twice in a row.I hate luckstomps, and I hate them both ways, whether I lose or win. Especially in a game like IW I prefer a difficult and intricate match that results in a loss than a simple one-sided slaughter that results in a victory for me.There nowadays seem to be more lock-and-key combos of decks where 2 totally valid decks end up with one player suffering a guaranteed loss. I'd wager it's a result of adding more cards, and I'll be honest, I have no idea how to fix it, I won't even try.But wait, this is still not the reason I give this game a thumbs down. While I feel the RNG and luck part is a bit too harsh now in IW I could deal with it, or if I couldn't I would just silently move on.What's bothering me is lacking polish. When I left the game there were the occasional issues with card graphics glitching out (which are still there to some extent) but that's just cosmetic. After I returned there were multiple bugs that affected gameplay.2 notable examples:1. Enemy has a Hell's Gambler and it activates TWICE during the first turn and works twice, which gives a really unfair advantage, the card is only supposed to activate once2. During my second rift run (2 misfortune losses in) I had a REALLY nice game, only a bit luck from my enemy for the first turns but it was a really difficult and fun game and I had a bit more luck later in the game, hell if I would've lost normally it would've been totally fine. But no. I lost to a serious glitch. My enemy plays a nice exile combo and replicates flying dragons like crazy and I struggle to defend. Then I get a Lance of Jinhai and use it on an Evolving Parasite, so it gets reach and can take over the first attacking dragon and defeat the second, after that a morale victory would've been in reach and those were his last 2 dragons as well.Alas upon resolving the turn the game quickly switches my parasite with another character in the assault zone. And no, there was no card in play and no played ability that warranted this switch. And no, I did not place the cards wrong and just thought I did everything right. I have the game on video and rewatched it multiple times, checked every card that was in play. The switch was uncalled for and it killed me, it totally ruined the game. And prematurely ended my rift run.I'm not a sore loser if it comes to fair matches. But I'm a very sore loser if it comes to losing because of glitches. Even more so in a game mode like rift where every loss hurts and every victory counts. And this is not the first game that I kinda love but ultimately dropped ONLY because of lacking polish.It's becoming an awful trend in modern game development. I'm looking at you Tera, with random warp barrier cancelling and atrocious optimization that leads to single digit FPS on high-end systems. I'm also looking at you X Rebirth, with frequent game breaking bugs that even went as far as corrupting saved games permanently.Well X Rebirth is fixed nowadays but I won't forget the pain of having pre-ordered it just to get smacked in the face by a storm of glitches.Really poeple. New cards and expansions are great, but a certain level of polish should come before new content.Fix game breaking bugs before adding new content.I for one will drop this game for a while. I really like it so I might come back some other time and give it another chance, especially when the new campaign is fully implemented because the story has potential. I like the gameplay, the story, the visuals it's just that lacking polish and glitches get the better of me. Again. I'll be sending the video to the devs so they'll be able to take a look.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 15, 2014
												I’ve played a couple of digital card games extensively (Shadow Era, Hearthstone) as well as dabbled with a few others (Solforge, PoxNora, Kingdoms CCG).  Out of all of these digital card games, I would say that I have only truly loved Shadow Era’s gameplay mechanics, so when I read about Infinity Wars on Steam, I was hesitant, as history demonstrated that I was inclined to dislike a TCG more often than not. Furthermore, after I downloaded Infinity Wars and jumped into the tutorial, I felt even more hesitant, because I found its simultaneous-turn system and multi-zone battlefield confusing to learn.I cannot stress enough how glad I am to have fumbled through the tutorial and AI campaign missions. As a result, I discovered a true strategic gem – a gem in beta with much more polish than many other digital card games which have been fully released. Sure, Infinity Wars has gorgeous animated cards, a delightful music score, and engrossing atmosphere/lore with 8 distinctly different factions [8, not including the Star Trek factions]. That’s super. But what sells me are the game mechanics. Unlike most other digital card games, the battlefield of Infinity Wars is divided into multiple zones (command zone, support zone, assault zone and defense zone). You can move your characters between most of these zones, and certain destructive spells only work on your opponent’s characters when they are in certain zones at a certain moment in time.  In addition, turns are taken simultaneously, which results in plenty of wicked mind-games going on between you and your opponent in PVP. It sounds a bit complicated, but trust me -- it’s awesome. In other digital card games, I sometimes felt frustrated at not being able to draw a major card in time (major = integral part of my deck strategy), or felt the frustrations of pay2win and lack of balance. Infinity Wars addresses the first concern with the command zone mechanic (3 “commander” characters, or characters which are integral to a deck’s strategy, are available at the start of the game, and you can play them on the actual battlefield or use their abilities as soon as you have the resource [mana] for them). Furthermore, my frustrations of getting a “bad draw” are mostly quelled by the trading post system, in which a player can obtain extra cards, or swap out cards, by paying resources. I don’t feel that Infinity Wars follows a pay2win business model at all – you can actually build a competitive deck fairly quickly. You receive a large selection of cards by completing the academy (training) and campaign missions, and earn cards by playing each day and completing achievements. Very rarely have I seen a card played by an opponent in PVP that screamed “IWIN” (you know what I mean). In other words, I think the game is pretty well-balanced for a beta. There are favorable and not-so-favorable matchups depending on which faction(s) you utilize, of course.I think that strategic-minded gamers will also love deck-building in Infinity Wars, as you can combine cards from different factions to create a truly unique deck that’s perfectly suited to one’s individual play-style. Furthermore, I love that there are many different ways to win, aside from the standard “destroy the opponent’s base”. Certain factions lean towards playing a certain way to win, and mixing complementary cards belonging to different factions in order to reach such a win condition is incredibly fun. As soon as I discovered there was a super-defensive faction that was based on Ancient Chinese lore and obtaining board-control in long, drawn-out games, I was like, “OH HELL YES, THEY TOTALLY MADE THAT FACTION WITH MY INTERESTS AND PLAYSTYLE IN MIND!” (I’m referring to Descendants of the Dragons). I splashed my Descendants deck with some complementary healing and buff cards from a different faction (Warpath), and soon enough, rainbows were shooting out of my nostrils (that’s a good thing). I do want to make a comparison to another digital card game before I conclude. However, I don't want to ramble about Hearthstone too much.  I want this review to mostly focus on the intrinsic qualities of Infinity Wars, but I have to stress how multi-dimensional and in-depth Infinity Wars is compared to Hearthstone. The complex bluffing games essential to Infinity Wars, multi-zone battlefields, as well as the creative freedom of its deck-building system, just makes Hearthstone seem so one-dimensional in comparison. In other words, Infinity Wars truly feels like a battlefield, with 3 commanders accessible from the get-go which complement one’s unique play-style and desired win condition. As long as it is financially feasible, I hope that Lightmare, the developers of Infinity Wars, will continue to develop their game with the more "strategically-minded" niche gamer in mind, as opposed to making “catering for the casual masses” their number one priority. Of course, Infinity Wars has its flaws. I encounter numerous display bugs each day, and I think the user interface needs much refinement (why can’t I sort my cards so I can easily differentiate between my soul-bound and tradable cards?). That said, I strongly feel as though Lightmare are on the right track. From what I’ve seen, they’re a cool company that truly listens to community feedback (you’ll see them actively participating in discussions with the community, even outside of the official forums and Steam). If this gigantic rant makes one reader (who is interested in strategy and/or digital card games) think "Hey, Infinity Wars appears rather complicated at first, but I would like to approach it with an open-mind and check out the game mechanics!" -- I would be very happy.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 10, 2014
												pros: free-to-play, good tutorial (I recommend doing before you go to the campaign), hyped soundtrack, creatively animated card illustrations, animated UI & interface, windowed fullscreen option available, a lot of cards (all animated) with a ton of single player campaign missions & challenges (which rewards you with moar cards!1!!), you can construct as many custom decks (for free) as your heart desires with at least 9 different factions to choose from (but limited to 3 different factions per deck for it to be legal in multiplayer), gameplay allows two win conditions (reduce opponent health or morale to zero), gameplay allow ways to bluff & position. Also on the bottom right of the UI is an auction button (allows card draw & resource schemes) & at the bottom left is the undo button.cons: the game requires you to create a login profile (why not just auto link with the steam account?), player vs player multiplayer modes has to be unlocked by completing single player challenges & leveling up your profile first (you need to be at least lvl 10 to play ranked constructed, although it's understandable due to experienced ranked opponents), few missing sound ques, the AI sometimes doesn't make the smartest decisions (& some campaign levels are trial&error), storyline is forgettable, when you close the chatbox during a multiplayer match there is no way of getting it back (& no way of reestablishing contact with previous opponents), ive experienced a few deck loading bugsOverall, after playing for almost 2 decades of Magic: The Gathering & many other card games, Infinity Wars is by far the most compelling of all card games ive played. This is a must play for MTG, Hearthstone, Yu-gi-oh, etc. players - who long for a better card game that offers depth, easy to learn, customizable, streamlined online multiplayer ; but leaves out the pay-to-win BS, terrible UI & menu interfaces, & frustrating/inconvenient multiplayer experience.Infinity Wars has my highest recommendation and a must play! One of the most fun CCG experience out there.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 21, 2014
												After wasting crap load of time and money on MTG, I decided to return to TCG once Digital TCG started rising again (i.e. Hearthstone).  Hearthstone didn't do it for me because it was one of the most casual♥♥♥♥♥♥I've ever tried in my life.  So I looked for a better alternative.  Then I found Infinity Wars.  I'll cover IW in two main aspects: F2P and Gameplay/Strategy potentials.Is it F2P?I think the game is pretty fair.  Firstly, yes you can actually TRADE cards in this game.  You can buy Lightmare Points to buy booster packs but you can also earn IW Points to buy booster packs.  You earn IW points from playing games online, including private games with your friends.  How many games does it take to buy a booster pack?  I think it is around 30-40 games (Just a rough estimate, haven't done the math myself), assuming 50% win rate.  But there's more.When you start the game, you will have to play some campaigns.  They will teach you about each factions and you will earn starter deck of each faction when you complete first 3 or 4 missions of each factions.  Also, any games you play, you get experience points for your account and you will get a free booster pack every time you level up.  Every level requires more experience than the last but in the beginning you will level up often and you will be showered with booster packs.  But there's more.There is a thing called daily rewards and weekly quests.  Every week, you will be given 3 quests.  It can be just gaining certain amount of experience or playing some amount of PvP.  You get one random card for each quest you complete.  You will get 1 random card for logging in daily and you will get another random card for playing 3 PvP games.  So assuming you are diligent, you get 2 cards per day, another 2*7+3 = 17 cards per week.  And these are truly RANDOM cards.  I've gotten couple of legendaries just from logging in every day.   It's pretty rare but it's really nice when you get them.I also need to note that free cards you get from daily, weekly or levels are SOULBOUND, meaning you can't trade them.  Only the cards you get with Lightmare or IW points are tradeable.  I think it's fair considering how many cards they pump into you and you don't want to screw the trade economy.So in summary,1. 2 cards every day (untradeable)2. 3 cards every week (untradeable)3. 1 booster pack (15 cards) every level (untradeable)4. In-game points you earn to buy booster packs (tradeable)Gameplay/StrategyIW is definitely unique.  I'll cover them in sections.  1. Simultaneous turnsMost card games are turn-based but this game has SIMULTANEOUS turns, meaning you and your opponent plan at the same time and things happen all at once.  This means you have to plan according and predict your opponent's moves instead of waiting for them to make a move and react.  If you played MTG, then you know about saving that kill spell in case your opponent buffs a creature into a raging hulk or saving that counter-spell in case he casts some devastating spell.  Not in this game.  You have to predict them coming.  On the other way around, you can dodge certain spells by moving your characters in and out of the battlefield.  This adds an element of mind-game.  Instead of casting spells and hope that your opponent doesn't have an answer for it, you can move around it, dodging, baiting and calling shots.  It really depends on the deck but some games can be very intense.  You don't just play your strategy and hope your opponent doesn't have an answer to it.  If you know they could potentially counter you, you can find a way around by baiting.  This is only possible in Digital TCG so it's taking full advantage of the digitalized TCG!  This fact alone is worth checking this game out.2. Deck buildingAlright, magic has 5 colored factions but IW has 8?  (There's 2 more factions for Star Trek series but I won't cover that here)  And you can only have up to 3 factions for each deck?  What's up with that?  Well, IW is different in a sense that your deck will be based on 3 cards and they are called Commanders.  Every deck has 3 commanders and their faction alliance determines how you build the deck and each faction has their unique strategy and combining them.  You can build a pure faction deck and play to its fullest strength or you can make a deck of hybrid factions, playing with jack-of-all-trade playstyle.  You aren't just limited to 3 factions because there is a card that allows you to play any factions.  ANY character card can be a commander.  The 3 commanders are placed in the commander zone at every game and you can play them whenever you want, provided that you have enough resources.  Most of the time, you can play the character's ability from the commander zone so you can even build a deck around that entire aspect.If you played MTG, you know well about resource management.  In IW, you gain 1 resource every turn so you rarely have to worry about being mana-screwed.  The commanders are like lands in a sense that they determine the color of your deck.  There are characters and spells to boost your resource to get ahead early so there are some resource management in the game.  Your deck should be consistent with your intended gameplay every time since you won't get mana-skrewed very well, provided that you balanced the resource curve.  Consistency is the key because I really hated getting mana screwed in MTG.  Honestly I think that is one of the major design flaws of MTG.  MTG is more flexible with deck building in a sense that you can have any color and any cards in your deck provided that you have the lands to support it.  But ultimately you have to buy those 20 dollar rare lands to even make your dreams possible.  I miss the potentials in MTG but not that much.  Coming from MTG which has beautifully balanced 5 color scheme (each color allies with 2 while opposing one), I felt kinda iffy about the whole factions thing, especially since the devs seem to intend to add or subtract them in the future (super not sure about this but there were 7 factions in the beginning but now there's 8. 10 if you include the non-canon ones) but I learned to love the lore and each faction is quite fun to try.In summary:1. Simulatneous turns for mind-games2. Commanders and 8 unique factions for intersting deck building strategies3. Basic resource management so you won't get mana screwed most of the time

												This game is actually quite a treat. I personally love TCG and when Hearthstone came out, I was excited. I immediately picked it up, and put money on it. Not even into my first 24 hours of playing, I got bored. It lacked true depth. Infinity Wars is different, and expanding. The different styles is really what takes me. Do you pull a deffensive stance and let the moral of your opponents fall? Do you summon hordes of troops, rally, and charge into battle? Do you, summon your opponents graveyard and destroy them?All I can say is, it's free, it's expansive, and it's fun. The game has been out for a bit, but litterally just hit Steam. Give it a chance.8/10

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								I. Am. Hooked.Yes, it's neat that the cards are animated I guess, but not a big deal. The mechanics of the game, however, are a big deal; and are an incredibly unique take on TCG. (Yes, TCG - you can trade!)The biggest things that caught my eye:'Command cards' - three unit cards that you pre-select when making the deck that start off in the corner, revealed. You can tailor specific opening strategies around this, and there are tons of possibilities here. And you don't get screwed over by bad draws, because they're always there at the start.'Trade post' - Speaking of bad draws, the 'trade post' function not only allows you the usual 'mulligan' at the start of the game, but also gives you the ability to spend otherwise unused resources on drawing new cards or even swapping out cards you don't need to draw new cards (for less resources). This is an AWESOME mechanic for bypassing those games where you're basically twiddling your thumbs as you draw useless land cards in magic.It's actually F2P. You get a lot of usable cards from playing through the campaign, and you accrue a decent amount of generic in-game currency to purchase booster/blister packs easily. After a single day of playing I was able to afford a couple of blister packs and I was quite happy with that. One could probably afford a booster pack maybe once a week? Depends on how much you play of course.You can trade. (Well, aside from the starter cards you unlock in campaign mode at least.) I had given up hope that a card game would EVER let you trade, after all the CCGs I've played.There's much more I'm forgetting, and there wouldn't be enough space anyway.TL;DR: It's free, it's actually got a good F2P model from what I can tell, and it's worth your time. Get it.

Posted: February 28, 2016
												"Freemium" comes to computer...  After 9 hrs of play I give up.  What a waste of my life.  Single player was awesome for the first few hours in the beginning, and I reached lvl 7; awesome!  Got some cool cards and some fake money (IP).  That's when the fun ended.  Since I was done with the single player portion of the game (very limited) I thought I'd try my hand at a "rift run."  You pay your hard earned fake money (damn near all of it for one shot when you're done with the single player portion) and play against other players in a mode where you're given 4 card choices at a time and have to pick one each time to create a 43 card deck.  Cool (or so I thought) there's a chance to win the deck and some other cards!  I got my♥♥♥♥♥handed to me in five games, three losses, two draws, and all of my funny money was gone!  The other awesome part is that if you want to "buy" card packs, you have to actually buy them, with real money.  What a♥♥♥♥♥♥game.  Don't waste your time.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												First impression of beta; This TCG is made of some serious f**king win.   1. Unique and robust combat system combined with a very fluid interface.   The cards are beautifully animated when you inspect them and it is greatly appreciated. 2. Solid sound effects for a DTCG, which is sadly rare. It could be better and I'm sure it will, these devs look like they pump out a lot of content and patches.3.Techo-fantasy setting.. It's cyber-punk on crack; Robots, demon-infused robots, robot's molesting demons, undead trying to eat the humans who are watching demons getting molested ... it's all here and its fresh and interesting genre for TCGs that is highly reminiscent of Warhammer 40K (which is definitely not a downside) 4. ANDROID SUPPORT. And iOS if you fancy burning money I guess.  But the options are all there and this is a huge drawcard.  I know a lot of people like myself prefer to play on tablets or phone, or at least have the option to. 5. It's F2P so f**king download and try it already, you won't regret it.

content:
Posted: March 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								So I've spent some time with Infinity Wars and I'd like to give some initial impressions of the game.  First off let me tell you this game is deeep.  It's so deep that after eight hours of play my head is still swimming in all the tricks and strategy of the game and I'm fairly sure I still don't understand all of it and I know for certain that in multiplayer there's sharks down there that do.  If you want a challenging card game with loads of strategic possibilities this is the game you've been looking for.With all that depth comes a fairly steep learning curve that's thankfully helped along by some training missions.  The training missions are pre-established, stacked deck games that will teach you the basics of the game.  I found the training missions to be very helpful in understanding the game play although at the same time somewhat frustrating as the computer metagames things that, in my opinion, no real player could anticipate.  In some instances of the training mission the computer downright cheats to teach you your lesson, doing things that are absolutely outside the rules.  In the final "test" of the training mission the computer starts up with cards that could never be on the field of play until many turns into the game in a real game.  It's frustration to the max as it's nearly impossible to defeat the last test without playing some of the real game to get more and better cards to build a better deck.  It nearly made me rage quit the game forever.Other forms of solo play are a campaign mission for all the games factions, which will keep you playing in solo for a while, and several bots to challenge.  Then of course there's the PvP play where you go head to head against another real player.  Personally I have not yet done PvP and I'm fairly sure there are some other game modes in there that I haven't seen yet.So what is the actual game play like??  Well if you can imagine, it's as though Magic the Gathering, Yugiou, and Texas Hold 'em got together in a funky three way and had a child.  There's the normal getting packs of random cards to collect with which you build a custom deck of your own with. Creature summoning, fighting it out with creature health and life scores, keep your own heath up, and summon spells and enchantments.  Fairly standard concepts if you've ever played other card games.The first unique thing about this game though is that turns are taken simultaneously.  That's right, while your planning out what you’re going to do next so is your opponent.  Once you both hit "end turn" what you both did happens in a particular order.  This allows for some interesting game play and a bit of bluffing from time to time.  You'll find yourself trying to second guess and plan ahead for what your opponent "might" do.  This plays on the way there are 3 zones for your summoned creatures to be in, support, attack, and defense and that some cards target one of those areas specifically.  If there's a creature in the zone you targeted during your turn your good to go, but if your opponent has moved that creature to another zone your spell card basically fizzles.  The other interesting thing about this game is the morale bar.  The morale bar starts at 100 points, same as your player health.  Each time one of your creatures dies you lose a set amount of morale based on what that particular creature's morale loss is.  And then there are cards which will boost or reduce yours or your opponent’s morale.  Should your morale reach zero you will also lose the game.  It's sort of like having a second health bar that gets reduced by other means and gives more depth to how you set up your deck and how you go about winning the game. It all makes for some interesting and different game play than any other card game you'll find.  The next question; is this a pay to win game?  So far as I've seen at the moment I'd say no.  Yes there are random packs and decks you can buy with either real money, or credits you earn while you play the game.  If you choose to keep it free it will take you longer to get a larger selection of cards from which to build your deck from and thereby your deck may initially be weaker than say someone who'd played the same amount of time yet spent real money on cards....  But keep in mind that even in a real world card game like Magic the Gathering or Yugiou I could go down to my local game store and plop down tons of money to buy boxes of cards right now, or buy more slowly as I have the extra money.  In that respect it's not much different than real life.  Also remember that these packs are random, so even if I gain them though play credits there's always the possibility that I may pull out better cards, or cards that are more important to me, over time than a person who plopped down a ton of real money to buy them.  Finally there's also a lot of player skill to factor in.  Even if you have an incredible selection of awesome cards there's the question of can recognize and build a viable deck with them and even if you can do that can you use that deck to win?  I've seen many a player in real world card games that had a great deck, but they had no clue how to use it properly.So at the end of the day is this game good??  I'd say yes, it's a lot of fun and something I intend to continue playing.  Is it better than say, Hearthstone, the other popular online card game right now??  I would say that the answer to that depends on what you want in a card game.  Comparing the two is a bit like comparing checkers to chess.  Hearthstone is also a great game, but is much more simplistic and straightforward.  If you want an easy to understand, high speed card game go with Hearthstone.  If you want a deeper, more challenging game go with Infinity Wars.  Personally I think I enjoy the depth of Infinity Wars more.

number of helpful: 8 of 14 people (57%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 12, 2016
												Flawed GreatnessPlay this game! It´s free and it´s worth a try. However the lack of missing features that i´d consider the basics make me not recommend it in the curent stage.So why do i still suggest that you play this game?Simple enough: The gameplay. It´s a unique card game mechanic that survives without resource problems, RNG or disadvantages for either the first or the second player.These three fact alone make it stand out already. Players play at the same time so there is no unbalancing in the order that most TCGs and CCGs face, resources accumulate automatically which gets rid of some really depressing games (this feature is luckily becoming the new standart in this genre) and other than the RNG factor that comes with the genre, there are no cards that vary in their effectiveness.There are a ton of different classes which all feel extremely unique unlike anything i´ve seen so far in card games. But as i said, the best thing about this game are the mechanics. 3 different zones give a ton of strategy and there are more win conditions than just beating your opponent down.If i could end this review here, Infinity Wars would easily be my favourite digital card game.But sadly i can´t. Because despite of making everything important right, it fails at some basic things that if you take them for granted, which i most certainly do, will push you away.Keep in mind that this is still in early access and that the following things only apply to the state of the game that i played.First off, there is nearly no solo play. The campain is fun but over really quickly which means that if you want to play against the AI, you´re stuck playing against the same decks over and over. They keep playing the same cards and after a few rounds you just lose interest in playing against the same things again. The worst thing is, that they don´t even cover all races in the game.Secondly: There are races that are unexcessable without real money. Want to play the dead with their ever growing zombies? Well you can only get those via the premade decks which in return you can only get with real money. This can be extremely frustrating if it happens to a free user and will immediatly make him stop playing the game.There´s also a lack of polish. Sure you can´t expect that from a non major developer but if opening a pack takes 3 years and with all the animations that just look super crappy, the game gets a kind of cheesy feel to it.There are a lot of other little things i didn´t like, like battlegrounds that make annoying sounds when you hit the end turn button or the fiddling to select / get to the card you want to look at.After all i can only say again: you should give this game a try. If you can overlook the negative sites you will find a rich experience that will satisfy all desires you could have in a card game.Sadly i couldn´t...

content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								I'm really liking Infinity Wars.  Normally, I would avoid games that have aspects of 'drain-your-wallet-to-get-the-cool-stuff' but I'm happy to report that after only 5 hours of playing, I have a few epic cards, and I'm really enjoying myself. Gameplay, for the veteran MTG player, will feel very familar.  I like the layout, which is animated all pretty-like.  The cards themselves have great artwork, and it's not that hard at all to get a hang of the rules.  There's a few glitches or maybe issues that I'm not quite understanding -- when I play a location, the playfield seems to change to .. just a field.  The fortress disappears, etc.  Maybe that's cause I'm playing a nature/green/whatever factioned card?  Anyway .. Deck construction is cool, but the instructional video shows a completely different layout (a more useful one) than what I got.  It's a bit of a pain to have to scroll through cards instead of being able to sort them by cost, abilities, faction, etc.  I'll have to look more into that, I'm probably just missing something.Overall gameplay is quick and fun.  The AI for the campaigns is challenging, but I'm really looking forward to some PvP duels. Highly recommend this free game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
												I've played many TCG games, ranging from Magic the Gathering, to Yu-Gi-Oh, to Hearthstone and so forth. In my honest opinion, Infinity Wars is pretty unique considering how hard it is to make a TCG game that seems fun and not as dull or repetitive as other games.INNOVATIONS: Simultaneous turns                         Unique effects that range from invincibility to ground units, to attacking if destroyed another character, etc.                         Unique character abilities that range from a LARGE variety of things                         A 4 Zone field which are Attack, Defense, Support and Command.                         ALL cards are animated                         Artifacts and Locations that allow a deck built around them                         9 different factions, and more added as time goes on                         The command section which allows expensive cards abilities to be used without putting them on the fieldAs you may see, it doesn't seem much. That's because it's too hard to write down without boring you with an extremely long list of excessive text which you or may not even read. But moving on, what you're actually looking forPROS:A very good Free To Play model and is by no means a Pay to Win game         An infinite number of builds can be created due to the large variety of cards         A well balanced game compared to other TCG for not letting different factions have too much power over the other         This is not a brain dead game. An example of one would be, but not limited to Rush Down Hunter from Hearthstone         The staff is actually very responsive to the community and constantly listens to any suggestionsCONS:The layout of the game may confuse new players          The game looks pretty complex to new players          Hard to start getting into without playing at least 1 complete story line for Campaign for cards          Bots are in this game (the bad ones that exploits game mechanics), but the admins will be removing them          Have to wait 6 minutes for a person AFK in a game before kicking them and giving you a win          Have to wait 3 minutes if a person DCs before able to claim a winCONCLUSION: Overall, I would say this is a well made TCG which gives a more military like spin to TCG as well as giving off a strategic mindset with all the new abilities, artifacts, locations, and effects, the only problems would be new players trying to get in to the game, and the AFK/DC system. The rest of the problems were made by part of the community that create bots to exploit the game to get rare cards.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
												Being a general fan of TCGs, I've played quite a few of them. Currently, I don't think there's a better TCG on the market than Infinity Wars. I'll just make a few comparisons with the ones I've been playing in the last few months.Hearthstone is a finely polished TCG and as far as graphics goes, it's my top TCG. However, you have a fairly limited amount of cards and getting new ones is a chore. I can't honestly say it's pay-to-win, but it definitely pushes you into buying stuff because of the slow pace with which you get new cards. A real campaign does not exist, but you can buy a couple of missions for a steep price and finish it in a day (if you're slow). What pushed me over the edge and away from this game was the lack of rewards - when I beat challenges on nightmare difficulty and was simply returned to the main menu. It was at that moment that I said "awwwww, forget it".Hex is advertised as a revolutionary take on the TCG genre and it promises a lot. Promises is the key word here since there is almost no PvE content. Also, Hex still feels like just another MTG clone but with a god complex. In time, it might show itself as THE TCG game, but gamers (and everyone else, for that matter) don't particularly like waiting long for promises to come true.Finally, we come to Infinity Wars and to the reasons why I consider it the best TCG currently on the market. Let's do this one with pros, cons and neutrals.PROS+ playing board elements differ from the standard MTG&clones layout+ simultaneous turns make it less likely for you to wait for a slow opponent+ every card is animated+ a lot of achievements+ cards, of course. You get cards for logging in, playing 3 games in a day, finishing campaign missions, winning PvP matches, levelling up and god knows what else. The least I got was 2 cards a day. DId I mention that you get a whole deck of cards (40) for finishing the first 5 missions of a campaign?+ every non-cosmetic item (and some cosmetic ones as well) can be bought with the currency you earn from playing games+ you have additional options to utilize if you don't want to spend your energy on cards (shuffle and draw a card, draw a card, increase max resources)+ PvP mode where decks are combined does a good job of eliminating P2WCONS- automatic zooming when you click on a card- not being able to zoom in on a card when making a deck- if you or the enemy have a lot of creatures in a single zone it's almost impossible to target the creature you want to target- you have to visit the forums to learn enough info to make a valid deck (e.g. I overlooked card purity and every deck I made was illegal before I read the rules)NEUTRALS- card art (some are good, some would look better static)- a lot of factions- no cards have their own voiceAll in all, it's the one TCG that gives me a sense of accomplishment every time I play it (and even on a bad day). Except for some things that were overlooked (like the lack of zoom in your card library), it's everything I've wanted from a TCG. Plus, it's free.GENERAL SCORE 9,0/10.0

The battlefield concept is interesting and adds a lot of depth to the strategy and tactics of these games.But I feel like the game doesn't give you enough alternatives to earn in-game cash to buy cards. I'm also not happy with the game's matching ability. As a starting player without even a PVP badge on my first PVP games, it kept matching me with someone that had gold badges on everything and kicked my butt thoroughly every single game. After my third match in a row with this guy I gave up playing for a while, and soured my first experience with PVP in the game.Secondly, even though I've completed all the available single-player content, i don't feel like I have enough cards to field a viable deck in PVP unless I'm in pauper mode. So if you don't mind playing in pauper mode (and can find opponents in this mode), or if you want to spend the cash on one of the pre-made decks, you may be frustrated during your initial play against real players with full decks.

								I've played MtG, pokemon, and DBZ card games among some others I have foggier memory of. I've tried as number of card games on the computer. I really wanted to like hearthstone but hated it. Every card features beautiful art work that I actually admire, much like alot of the art in MtG. I mostly play free to play, and while this game can be happily enjoyed not spending a dime, I feel no remorse loosening my scrooge like hold on my wallet and shelling our for a few packs of preorders whenever a new set comes out.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
												I play a lot of CCG's in rl i used to play magic, spellfire, UFS(scout), world of warcraft, L5r, and many online electronic ccg's. I can say for sure infinity wars brings something unique to the table not knowing for either side who will be attacking or defending untill after you've made your moves and plays ads an incredible strategic depth to it. abilities more or less not resolving on an "instant chain" really i think leads to a more healthy game environment(like l5r) than the judge heavy play of magic or similar games. i will say that the strategies that are truly viable in each symbol of infinity wars are unfortunately fairly limited for now .... but it really hasnt had that many booster sets yet give it time and i think each set will add new victory conditions and play styles. As to the free to play  / pay to win. I can firmly say as a free player i have never felt like i couldnt compete even right after i finished the tutorial for all factions you get a lot of cards to work with and it doesnt take long to build at least 1 competitive deck, I like where they are going with thier model you can get more cards faster for money, you can but aestetic upgrades for money, they could probably use some in game currency booster options for real money. but on the whole you can indeed play this game 100% for free and have just as much chance to get rares and build a great deck you just wont get packs as fast as someone dropping real coin on it.  The aestetic upgrades are things like backgrounds for your decks while you play, and deck backings. i could maybe see them marketing custom special animations or special animated art for the cards as well ... almost like a "skin" if you will.Lastly deck building is honestly a pleasure as you pick your commanders it automatically filters the cards out to match the "purity" of your deck so you dont have to sift through a mountain of cards and/or accidentily put an illegal card in it. theres a format checker so you can check to see if your deck is legal in a given format. as well as a built in cost breakdown for your deck so you can watch your curve, a abilities/creatures/artifacts/locations split that not only tells you how many of each you have in deck but splits them up in the deck building screen so if you need to make an alteration things are fast and easy to find.Theres all my pros now to the cons.the game is young ... you will run across some things that young ccg's have such as cards that dont work 100% as printed(sleeper hakeem) and cards that are too strong in given meta like the location for dod that cant be targetted and wins them the game in short order, there are precious few cards to counter it since its a location that cant be targetted so its "too dependable" a strategy there is not a full meta yet so combo decks tend to be king especially if they revolve around non creatures to win.  there is definitely rush mechanics(combo) with flame dawn, but control isnt quite there yet as a meta strategy and is almost exclusive to the dod for viability. reanimator works, but the games real problem is that aggro doesn't work, the threat that one could play an aggro deck keeps the more rediculious combo decks out of cycle in most ccg's, sure killing things on the board works but ONLY in the context of going for a quick combo damage victory and scrapping the few early cards in your way(verore/flamedawn). aggro can't target enough things by default to be a viable deck strategy theres no "combobreaker" style play yet that works in competitive, its just too hard to get to support row and command center and in the exiles case your hand. They also have situations where most of the colors dont specifically play well with others and 1 or 2 play really well. beasts only really target friendly"beast" cards, but the robot faction seems to be able to pump anything under the sun, verore and exiles seem the same way it seems silly why anyone would choose the second in either pairing over the other because they then have to bridge the hurdle of ..... "my cards dont help each other in 99% of cases how do i make this a cohesive deck strategy" while the first pair are so cohesive with anything they could just throw about anything in there on sybol or in neutral symbol and make it work somehow. I wish they would hire me as a card / rules designer i think i could do a lot for them mechanically.all things summed i would give it a 8/10 very stable game if you're tired of how rediculious the rules are in magic and you dont like stack based games prefer a more strategic feel like l5r as opposed to a solotaire combo vs possible combobreaker style of play like magic. you will like this game. if what you want is to spam 10 cards in a row that your opponent can't do anything about because he didn't specifically sidedeck against you and then proclaim you win. this is probably not the game for you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												This game makes me so conflicted. It is easily the best TCG in active play. Unfortunately it crashes pretty much without fail every 25 minutes or so. I thought it going to its full release update would help. It did not.Dont get me wrong. I love it; totally fun and easy to learn. But this crashing business is driving me insane. Just let me play the damn game!EDIT: It's been two years, they totally fixed the crashing stuff basically immediately after I made the original review as I recall and even more than two years later, its still the best card game out there bar none. If you actually enjoy card games the only person missing out if you don't play it is you. I hope to all the eldritch beings this game doesn't go under, because NO ONE i've seen is doing even REMOTELY close to as good as infinity wars is in the trading card game industry in terms of gameplay, card balance, and overall fun factor. Hearthstone is akin to smashing your testes with a ball-peen hammer, and infinity wars is like a nice glass of your preferred alcohol by comparison. MTG doesn't come remotely close to being as competetively fair. And so far this is the only card game that isn't threatening to strangle me to death for not PAYING for cards. And this makes the whole post sound kind of elitist but seriously, I've played every card game under the sun, and no one does it like lightmare does for infinity wars. The game is well supported, the art is on par with MTGs cards, cept these are animated. The only real complaint I have with the game anymore is that I don't have enough friends who are intelligent enough to grasp the concept of the gameplay to be able to play with me regularly because the game is very... thourough. There are many aspects to gameplay and will basically require you to be a card game veteran or you will be getting decimated all the time because your ability to customize your deck and strategy is basically not limited by the cards considering how many of them there are. So if you are struggling to find brain cells to rub together and you just put whatever you feel looks cool in your deck you wont have a leg to stand on. Which you could argue is a learning point for real deckbuilding but... Theres a difference between knowing how to play, and knowing how to win, and some people aren't very good at the latter.

								Solid card game with a lot of variance to create unique decks.  Of course like any card game some cards are much better than others, but devs look to be active in keeping the game as balanced as it can be. If they are able to add a solid auction/trading house would not hesitate to give it a 9/10.  There is a bit of a pay to win, but enough solo that seems to be expanding so you can still get to a solid level to compete against others, just a tad bit slower.  Have played a few card games and this one seems the most balanced so far I have played.Invite Code 1269F and feel free to add me ingame.

content:
Posted: June 4, 2014
												As a player of Magic the Gathering, I always felt that MTG lacked depth because of it's singular approach of reducing your oppositions life pool to zero. I disregard decking as a legitimate method of winning because it is simply not as practical. Infinity Wars resolves this issue by adding the morale pool in addition to a life pool. This addition of a morale pool creates more opportunities for creative deck building. A defensive deck is as legitimate as an offensive build. The simultaneous turns also improves the flow of the game and creates some interesting possibilities. The Gameplay is solid and the Free to Play structure is done well and allows a player to enjoy without paying, although buying items in the store is tempting for the same reason I have amassed giant MTG collections. The art direction is visually pleasing and the animated cards communicate the idea of the art well, both humorous and serious  ideas come across well.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								Solid card game with a lot of variance to create unique decks.  Of course like any card game some cards are much better than others, but devs look to be active in keeping the game as balanced as it can be.  Able to earn a decent amount of cards if played regularly and have bought card packs from the 1st expansion and was able to build a fairly solid deck.  The biggest fault in the game is not auction/trading house, but just a trading channel.  This to me is the biggest reason I would rate this about a 6.5/10.  If they are able to add a solid auction/trading house would not hesitate to give it a 9/10.  There is a bit of a pay to win, but enough solo that seems to be expanding so you can still get to a solid level to compete against others, just a tad bit slower.  Have played a few card games and this one seems the most balanced so far I have played.Invite Code 1269F and feel free to add me ingame.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is exactly what you are looking for.So you like TCGs, PvP card games, awesome conceptual art + animation, and the thrill of victory?  Why on Earth isn't this game already in your Library?  It's free to play, the patch as of March 12, 2014 makes obtaining a solid card collection VERY easy, the campaign and quest objectives are continuously challenging when you just want to test your deck, and it is so easy to find yourself glued to your mouse on your fifth draft wondering when the addiction started.Praise aside, this game is still in beta.  There happens to be plenty of transparency regarding what is currently not working well, what fixes are on-deck vs. long term, the game devs road map for progression, and highly active and public support from staffers.  Tech support is usually within 24 hours (the high volume around major patch days are obviously slower) and QA / Marketing members are active in streaming, vid casting, and the in game global chat.

content:

Early Access Review
								After seeing some videos online and the recent reviews, I decided to give Infinity Wars a whirl myself. I can say it's definitely a fun game. The gameplay itself i unique while not alienating players who've tried other popular card games . They also add a lot of personality and life to cards by giving each of them an animation. The game is still in beta, so there are kinks they need to iron out, sometimes when adding a new card to your deck it might be marked illegal the next time you log in and you may need to take it out and put it in again, and sometimes it may take a while to find a match; but these are minor complaints that I'm sure they'll iron out in the future. Also, the game isn't Pay 2 win; their are know major cash shop items that give you a major advantage. Sure, you can buy card packs with real money, but your better off just buying them with the in game currency, it doesn't take that long  (plus you get a free card pack when you level up and sometimes as a daily win award.) If you like card games, this is definitely one you should give a try.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 4, 2014
												As a player of Magic the Gathering, I always felt that MTG lacked depth because of it's singular approach of reducing your oppositions life pool to zero. I disregard decking as a legitimate method of winning because it is simply not as practical. Infinity Wars resolves this issue by adding the morale pool in addition to a life pool. This addition of a morale pool creates more opportunities for creative deck building. A defensive deck is as legitimate as an offensive build. The simultaneous turns also improves the flow of the game and creates some interesting possibilities. The Gameplay is solid and the Free to Play structure is done well and allows a player to enjoy without paying, although buying items in the store is tempting for the same reason I have amassed giant MTG collections. The art direction is visually pleasing and the animated cards communicate the idea of the art well, both humorous and serious  ideas come across well.

content:
Posted: March 11
												Wait... I wasn't write any evaluations about this game? REALLY? I must repair that!I played this game before it come to steam, overseers section wasn't here yet! I spend twice more time than the steam counter actually show ;) .okey, so here's three reasons I put Infinity Wars on the podium of all TCG:------------------------------------1- The most Free To Play beyond all TCG!If you know a bit about Trading Card Games, you know it's one of the most expensive game style you can get. The well-knowed Magic The Gathering by example cost 3.5€ a booster of 15 cards (1 rare, 3 uncommons, 11 commons), and a competitive deck can cost 150€, then become outdated after 1 year.Analogical cards are also expensive: Hearthstone, Hex, Duel of Champions, Scroll, all of them request between 20 and 50€, with the same problem of rotation.Infinity Wars is totally free! Not because of the exigence of the collection or the deckbuilding performance, but because of the accessibility of the packs. You can complete the entire collection in one year. In comparison, a FTP player in HEX is only happy to get all double-shards at this moment (Unless he played 10 hours/days ^^ ).And if you wish play a good builded deck, you can try a free weekly one enought fine to beat "Metagame" (if there are one...).Players generally spend money for alternate art cards or battlefields, and that work: Paradoxally, I spend more money on this game than the other TCG (15€ on IW, 5€ on DoC, 3€ on Heatstone). A good confidence and respect for Lightmare Studio.----------------------------------------------------2- Simultaneous turn!That's the best point of this game: you play your turn IN THE SAME TIME of your opponent. You have 3 minutes to manage your turn, 5 if you request more times (limited to 3 requests). You opponent do the same, then everything is resolved at the same time (Be careful of the initiative rule! All beginners make the mistake).So you can manage, organize, planify, expect: you must be confident in your reflection AND your intuition! in fact, the intuition is here an important factor and you can win even in a bad situation due to a careless and overconfident opponent or due to a excessive prudence and unconfident of this one. Bluff is also a big tactic (exept for brainless sligh deck, but... meh, they are easy to counter).That also why all beginners are dissuaded by this game, felling "too complex", but... really, after passed the first impression, you will love it!----------------------------------------------------3- original mechanism, great combinason of deckbuildingAs I said, there are not really "metagame" in Infinity Wars. of course, there are some Legendary spoiling cards, but they are easy to get (thank to the draft) and are not sign of victory (Don't cry on "The Calamity", it's just a MTG "Wraith of god" or a HEX "Extinction", very expensive to cast and predictible (When you see your opponent get 11 ressources, you can expect it)).The deck building is based on "Purity rule", to resume:* There are actually 8 factions on this game.* You can put 3 commanders. each commander represent one faction purity.* You can put more commander of the same faction for more purity, from 1 (3 factions) to 3 (pure faction).Each faction have their mechanisme, combine faction and purity is interesting to build combo idea or particular mechanism. You have 8 faction of 3 purity, so 119 combinations possible! (8 faction mean 8 " pure faction (3 purities)", 7x8 "2 factions (2 purity on one faction + 1 purity on a second faction)" and 55 "3 factions" (1 purity on each faction).In comparison, in Magic or Hex, you have 5 colours, that mean you can play until 31 combinations of colours (5 one-colours, 10 bi-colours, 10 tri-colours, 5 quadra-colours, 1 pentacolour).The unique problem of this game is... may player are intimidated by this special rule and don't try at least to evolve or experiment a bit... so come! We need more people! :D

content:
Posted: January 5
Upvoted... for nowI do have to admit, Infinity Wars is a very unique and entertaining game. The simultaneous turn-based system is definitely one-of-a-kind, introducing a whole new level of both strategy and luck, the two most important factor in competitive card game genre. The factions are well developed, each with their distinctive strengths and weaknesses. I have enjoyed this game for about two years, and I still come back whenever I can.Unfortunately, things were not as good as it used to be. Descendants of the Dragons faction is constantly blamed for being too overpowered, an opinion I also share. The Avatars are way too strong. Some factions are downright weaker than the others - in this kind of game, it is very important to keep things "different," instead of either "superior" or "inferior." The Star Trek collaboration was somewhat brilliant, but Klingon faction is perhaps a bit too strong. The new campaign system is bland to say the least. The list goes on.Still, I believe that Infinity Wars can be improved, as it was first introduced. I'm counting on it. Hence the upvote... for now.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 29, 2014
												This game has finally done what every other online tcg should have been doing from the beginning; every single card is animated. I actually enjoy just looking through and appreciating the awesome art work and watching the cool little animations. I also really love how every deck feels completely broken when it goes off; It's a total power trip!One of my favorite and most unique features is when you play a location card and your side of the board transforms to match it; it looks awesome! The different factions each represent different deck strategies that you're probably familiar with. The flame Dawn Army is your Big Red Aggro deck, playing a lot of fast creatures to win the game before your opponent can stabilize. Genesis Industries is a robot synergy deck that lets you play cheap guys who eat each other to get bigger. The Warpath uses really cheap big guys to smash through your opponent's creatures and in to the win zone. The Cult of Verore is a control deck that makes it's own creatures stronger by killing yours. The Descendants of the Dragon is a turbo fog control deck that uses all kinds of defenses to frustrate your opponent until you literally win the game by draining his morale or playing a giant unstoppable dragon. The sleepers of Avarrach is one of the best, coolest and most viable zombie decks of any tcg I've seen. Using recursion and graveyard effects to help you amass an overwhelming horde of the undead. The Exiles are demons who reward you when you discard cards from your hand or sacrifice creatures. All in all, you should DEFINITELY check out this game; if only to see the cards.

												I´m not a big strategist and not even an expert at this game or anything, but, dude, this game is so much fun. You see, by playing MTG online you don´t have too many possibilities for collecting cards and building decks, and Heartstone dont have the cool mechanics from Magic, so... Infinity Wars! The library of cards is huge and  you can mix ALL the factions in so many possibilities with the three commanders system, it´s like, you can come up with a new strategy to test everytime you get a new card! The game has a lot of bugs, even during matches (that will make you lose the game sometimes), but it doesn´t ruin the experience for me. If you´re too competitive and isn´t willing to spend money on it, i don´t recommend this game. It takes a long time and a lot of patience to build a good deck without paying, so if winning and having the ways to get all the cards you want is a big deal for you, it´s not really that much fun. But you see, if you login every day the games gives at least one booster every week, so if you love to collect cards like me, loves the thrill of getting a card you wanted on a booster you worked so hard to get and gets REALLY EXCITED when the deck you´ve been working on for the last week with a weird combination of factions turns out to have a good strategy, start playing right now, cause this game is awesome. (if you don´t mind the bugs)

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												1-) Best Alternative TCG to Hearthstone 2--) Easy to pick up impossible to master3---) Great Meta throughout all Rankings 4----) Not pay to win; but incentives purchases  1) Infinity wars is imo one of the greatest cult classics among the lesser well known tcgs. (Hearthstone being the most popular as to exclude it) And other tcgs come close to it imo such as Hex : Shards of fate, Solforge, M&M, MTG; Although out of these i found that Infinity wars did not seem too convoluted in its system design; it was easy to pick up but hard to master. This was due to the almost gambling like turn system; where each players turns ended only when they accepted it. And when this happened, both players turns happened simultaneously. So in this perspect you can place some of your more valuable cards in safer zone. Pre-emptive moves among other intresting targeted spells would play together in this mash of motions.2) The reason that it was easy to pickup and impossible to master was the fact that you were given the basic deck of cards from each faction upon completing its faction campaign. (more of an extended tutorial if you will) Which served as your barebones skeleton of to which build upon; and if you so fancied the starter deck expands upon this. Although it feels more like an intermediate deck of which stacks on your barebares campaign deck. It was also very plentiful with the amount of card packs it gave early on. (as level up gave card packs) Thus by the time you hit around lvl 10 you should have had plenty of cards of which you felt were very strong to compete with. And as the TCG mantra goes; more cards; more possiblities.3) The meta of the game very deep and rich to say the least. This is because certain deck types almost always counter another deck type. And thus you had to either make you decks strengths more apparent, or your weaknesses less apparent. A good deck can get you carried higher in the ranks but as peoples understanding these inherent ideas grow; decks became harder and harder to counter. And thus there was always this arms race of sorts to pump up the RNG gods (random number game = equivlent to lady luck)4)As stated earlier the reason this was not pay to win was becuase you were given the barebones of which to work with. And given pleniful amount of packs which slowed down as your cards grew from level ups (higher level = slower level up). Meaning that your earned currency to buy cards become more valuable and thus the payed currency. But this was fine as you will have amassed more cards when this spike occurs. Although the missing powerhouse in your decks made you crave more cards as a result.9/10

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game has a really nice balance and a lot of depth to the strategy. I used to play Magic a few years back (it got too expensive to keep up) and while this has some similarities, I think I might actualyl prefer the style of Infinty Wars. I've seem some complaints that this is "pay to win", but have not found that to be the case. After going through just 2 of the single-player campaigns (there's one for each faction) and about half of the academy tutorials, I've accumulated enough booster packs to build some fairly formidable decks. Deck building definitely gets addictive and there's great nuances to balancing your card selections, especially when you start mixing more than one faction into a single deck. I'm not usually too big on multiplayer games, but really enjoy the PvP in this. Matchmaking is quick and the games have a great pace. Overall a great game, my only gripe so far is that the in-game currency is slow to accumulate versus the real Lightmare currency that costs actual dollars. I've logged about 10 hours of game time and amy barely even halfway towards being able to buy a booster pack with in-game currency. However, I've mostly been playing Academy and Campaign single-player matches, and it looks like the standard PvP gives you about double the currency of the single-player matches, so that's a plus. Anyway, its free to play, so try it already!

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 29, 2014
												This game has finally done what every other online tcg should have been doing from the beginning; every single card is animated. I actually enjoy just looking through and appreciating the awesome art work and watching the cool little animations. I also really love how every deck feels completely broken when it goes off; It's a total power trip!One of my favorite and most unique features is when you play a location card and your side of the board transforms to match it; it looks awesome! The different factions each represent different deck strategies that you're probably familiar with. The flame Dawn Army is your Big Red Aggro deck, playing a lot of fast creatures to win the game before your opponent can stabilize. Genesis Industries is a robot synergy deck that lets you play cheap guys who eat each other to get bigger. The Warpath uses really cheap big guys to smash through your opponent's creatures and in to the win zone. The Cult of Verore is a control deck that makes it's own creatures stronger by killing yours. The Descendants of the Dragon is a turbo fog control deck that uses all kinds of defenses to frustrate your opponent until you literally win the game by draining his morale or playing a giant unstoppable dragon. The sleepers of Avarrach is one of the best, coolest and most viable zombie decks of any tcg I've seen. Using recursion and graveyard effects to help you amass an overwhelming horde of the undead. The Exiles are demons who reward you when you discard cards from your hand or sacrifice creatures. All in all, you should DEFINITELY check out this game; if only to see the cards.

Early Access Review
								Infinity Wars is a great game if you are into CCGs. There are some nice twists to the original formula known from the likes of Magic: The Gathering. The cards are beautiful and animated which is a first as far as I know. ALL cards that can be used for ranked play can be gathered without paying real money. Even some easy to get early cards allow for some strong competitive decks. The devs are active and there have already been 2 new sets released. New sets are scheduled every 3 months and so far all of them can be bought with ingame money. There is a nice single player campaign and cool academy missions which help you with the rules and building a card stock.All in all I had a very fun experience playing this game the last week.Btw, here is my universal invite code, which you can type in while registering: 2B2C8  This will give both of us some extra ingame currency.

content:
Posted: June 5, 2015
												I did like it at first, but the single player was greatly toned down recently. Albeit the fact that the new single player is a bit more user-friendly, it's not so hard hitting--you are babied into playing Infinity Wars. Also it is much smaller than before. Multiplayer is good for the most part. You get cards when leveling up and you can also buy them.  However, don't expect to get anything besides cards for free. Card backs, game textures, and avatars all require you to spend real money for them, which is a big con compared to games like Hearthstone. A few pluses to mention. All cards are animated and the game has great music!Keeping this review slim. TL,DR: No cosmetics are free, no singleplayer. Animated cards are cool, but better off playing Hearthstone unless you really, REALLY like multiplayer card games.

												Outstanding variation in terms of deck building. There is NO limit to how many different decks you can build and save, so you can customize and try out new ideas as much as your heart desires.The simultaneous turns takes a little getting used to, but allow for some really unique plays.Free to play aspect is solid. 1 card for logging in daily, 1 card for 3 games played daily, weekly quests, free packs on leveling up, and in game currency for playing matches. number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 28, 2015
												I work as a professional audio engineer, and the voice over work in this game is abysmal. There are plosives, lots of mouth and tongue clicks (aka mouth noise), and every voice sounds like it was recorded on totally different equipment. Most likely they just hired low cost voice over people from the internet, and each one is using a different standard of equipment. Acting is also sub par. I would have rather had no voices that distracting, low quality voices. Additionally, there are various typos throughout the system. The most obvious one I saw was the word 'availiable' (yes, with two 'i's) in the opening tutorial. Nice.On to game play, I'm a long time TCG player of various games, and this one is just a cheap knock off of Hearthstone, which is already a fairly boring game for those who are used to more complex and exciting games like MTG. Game play itself is marred by a very confusing turn system (which is unexplained and un-intuitive to new comers). I found myself stuck on the tutorial level where it says 'attack with all' and there is simply no button that says 'attack' or 'proceed' or 'go'. The fact that I have to carefully scan the screen for several minutes, check the options menu, and finally just give up shows a complete failure in this aspect.It's pretty clear the developers here only cared for making shiny graphics and animations, and cared nothing for the audio, the user interface, or even proper spelling.

number of helpful: 7 of 13 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												I can't believe I had to find this thing out from the Steam reccomendations page. This game should be talked about far more widely. If you enjoy magic or any similar card games, please try this out, it needs far more love. It is free to play, but not pay to win, as a glance at the store can tell you. The in game currency is handed out pretty regularly, the only pay exclusive items are for appearance (card backs, backgrounds). The campaign itself is wonderfully well made, with the the early stages teaching you how to play the deck the campaign is based around, and later stages relying on you coming up with interesting card combinations to win an otherwise one sided fight. The art is great, the game balance (as far as I can tell so far) is damn well done, and the updates seem regular. Please give it a try!UPDATE: As an update: 2 months in of playing it practically everyday, and it still hasn't gotten old. Finished the entire campaign, which teaches you rather well how to play each faction and various deck strategies they use. The AI opponents are rather dumb once you play against them enough, but PVP is very fun, and not the least bit stressfull. Even if you lose, you still get way more experience and cash than the AI would give you, and its very quick and easy to play the 3 games you need to get the second free card a day. With weekly quests to give you more free cards, and the 2 daily ones having a chance of being anything from a common to an epic (got 2 already this way), it never feels like you're stagnating. You can always build new decks and try new strategies, it doesn't hurt you to lose (in unranked anyway), and if you don't feel like that, there are always the rotating decks to try out, with varying difficulties of use. So to reiterate, if you like card games, play it!

content:
Posted: February 13, 2015
												I've played very little, but I really liked it. It has its own niche of a playstyle, quite similar to Yu-gi-Oh (a game which I absolutely adore).This game has a lot of potential and I love the way the game itself plays out. Granted I have my disagreements with some of the gameplay elements, but you can't love it all. It certainly doesn't break my Hearth like Cardstone does though. It doesn't try to kick me when I lose by also giving me nothing from card packs. That's of course after Cardstone opened a fresh wound with RNG and poured salt in it. Enough of Hearthstone though.With a heavy heart I must say that I sadly can't recommend it to almost anyone I know. The artstyle is good, I love the design, but the battlefield, the animations and the soundeffects are sub-par AT BEST. They're simply horrible. Calling them stock would be doing them too much justice. There are top notch free sound effects available out there and this game doesn't seem to be using any. Either that or my game is just broken. It really erodes away the sheer gameplay potential of the game as its feel is so dull I can't force myself to launch it.Once the animations and more importantly sound effects are fixed, the game will be MUCH less annoying. Right now it just has a complete lack of visual and audial charm.I know it's hard designing quality animations and fitting proper sound effects, different ones for each card, also making the game much bigger in the process, but if it's done in the future, I'll change my view to a Recommend.
