content:
Posted: April 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								i love this game!  I have been playing CCGs since Magic the gathering 4th edition came out.  Most recently I played a big name digital card by Blizzard, which i was very disappointed with.  Infinity Wars is the whole package.  Fun gameplay, fantastic card animations, and a HUGE library of cards.Now some specifics:1) there is a fantastic campaign mode that quickly gets you starter sets for every faction in the game, enabling you to quickly begin trying all the factions out to see what kind of decks you might like.2) I felt like I was always unlocking new cards.  after only playing for 4 days I have over 600 cards.3) There is never any need to spend real money on this game.  you can unlock every card just by playing the game.4) You get a random card just for logging in every day.  that card can be any card and rarity.  from common to legendary.5) Theres a reward for playing 3 games in a day, and weekly quests as well.6) You get rewarded for playing against your friends.  More xp, more in game currency, and more cards.7) This is the first digital CCG I have played that actually feels good to play on the computer.  In fact the game itself would not work as a tabletop game. Thats because...8)  Each player plays cards at the same time!  Let me explain.  each turn you have about 2 minutes to spend your resources to summon you characters, use special abilities, attack your foe and defend yourself.  Once you have done everything you want for the turn you simply push the "end turn" button. While you have been doing everything listed above so has your opponent, so when you both push "end turn" the uniqueness of simultanious play really shines.  every happens in a specific order for both characters at the same time, allowing for bluffing, tricking, trapping and utterly destorying your foe in fun new ways not possible in traditional card games.Now for some of not so good things about infinity wars:1) this is most definatly still a beta version of the game.  it crashes, it gltches, cards will be covered by other text, some cards abilities act a little wonky.  the game still has some bugs for sure, but even with its technical issues it is still worth playing.2) the card library needs some work.  when you go in to find a card there are some helpful search options to find what your looking for, but there needs to be more.  there needs to be an option to look up cards by special ability and by resource cost.  you can llok up cards by faction, by type of card, and by which set of cards its from; but with the amount of cards in the game there needs to be a better way to narrow it down.3) This game needs more players!  I dont know how many people are currently playing, but there have been a few times when Ive tried to play some PVP matches and it took 3-5 minutes to find someone to play against.4) It seems to take lots of in game currency to buy anything.  it costs 5200 points to buy a boster of cards that comes with 15 cards.  you get at most 75 points after playing a bot, or 150 for beating a pvp match.  if its your friend you both get 150 win or lose.  you need to play 70 bots minimum to get a booster or 35 pvp matches.  In my opinion you should be able to get a booster in half that many games.so there you have it.  dispite some flaws that will hopefully be worked out as the game nears official release this is still the digital CCG to play.  Fast, fun, and unique in a way no other card game has every been.  Hope to see you on Infinity Wars!

content:
Posted: April 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								A good alternative to Hearthstone and MTG that features stunning card animations and very unique gameplay.Infinity Wars is an easy to learn but complex card game that focuses on winning in either two ways, destroy the enemy fortress (which has health) or kill enough of their minions and deplete enemy morale to zero, forcing their retreat. You choose 3 commanders, of whatever faction you wish, but depending on which cards you want to use, you will need a minimum amount of that factions commanders. An example would be having a specific faction card, lets say (Genesis) that requires you to have 2 of its factions commanders. For this card to be in your deck, you need 2 of those 3 required commanders to be of that faction, in this case Genesis. This allows for unique deck creation as you can have 1 commander from 3 different factions, allowing you to use faction cards with a required commander cost of 1, making it a unique and versatile deck. Or if your like me, use three commanders from the same faction and gain access to its extremely powerful cards.Very noob friendly with a long and informative tutorial that is completely optional to do, but I would highly recommend completing the first two sections to make sure you understand the game. The third is for more advanced play, and can take upwards of an hour to complete, due to learning how to use special game mechanics.To make sure you aren't getting destroyed, multiplayer VS people is disabled until you reach level 4, which will take roughly 1:30 - 2:00 hours to finish.There is a long campaign that is interesting and very fun, which allows you to play every faction in the game to better learn its playstyle and get comfortable with the cards they command. Or if you feel like killing computers for that much wanted experience, just play the AI over and over until you reach the required level.No Pay 2 Win, you can pay for decks and booster packs with real money or use the in game currency to buy cards. (like most online TGC) If you do choose to sink money into IW, the prices are very reasonable and you get a good amount of cards added to your collection.Low player base, as its probably not very popular with the current kings of cards being MTG and more recently, Hearthstone.If you were to ask me to explain Infinity Wars in a sentence, it would be (Its like the middle grounds of Hearthstone and Magic: The Gathering: animated cards, complex at times, simple to learn and very fun to play)Personal Rating: 4/5

Early Access Review
								Alot similiar to Hearthstone as they have a 30 card Sealed/Draft Format where you select 1 of 3 cards for your deck. You gain 1 resource a turn so no screwed games due to lack of resources. Pretty Balanced for as new as the game is as every single card has a use in a deck from what I have seen. The ability to have 3 commanders can be a little overpowered as some of them should be banned and not be commanders IMO. But I think its an upgraded version of hearthstone with a much larger selection of cards but instead of having class restrictions you have race restrictions which you can still create hybrid decks. Solid size enviorment I havent had any trouble finding a game in constructed or limited/draft I havent had to wait longer than 10 seconds for a game. Overall great game if you enjoy these type of card games and I strongly reccomend to anybody who enjoys hearthstone as its a step up. Game needs more advertisement though I think it has potential to be the best of its kind. Also message me if you enjoy this review and I can give you a reference code to play and it would help me out a ton :)

content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												Deepest CCG I've played in a long time. Fun for [filthy] casuals, but what kept me playing is the complexity of strategy that you can formulate to help you win games.I started the game, finished the tutorials, the campaign, and then took a weekly free deck (aka LoL) into Ranked (aka Not LoL) and had a pretty good winrate. Well how does the game play like? It's basically turn-based laning, thinking 'what will my opponent do next turn' and 'what can i do to best counter what he will do' ...and you may soon find that the little details like slightly different positioning is the difference between victory and defeat.The only reason why the score isn't in the high 90s is that the game was "too hard" for the 15% of people who don't recommend the game. Like any good PVP game, you will be punished for your misplays, filthy casuals! Seriously though, unless you're in the bottom 15% of the curve in Steam, you'll probably enjoy the game.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								In a nutshell:  Infinity Wars is a great game, and I'd highly recommend it to anyone wanting a deep strategy card experience.**At first I was playing Infinity Wars and Hearthstone, and I was vacillating between the two.  Then I gave Infinity Wars a dedicated afternoon, and that's all she wrote.  Now it's Infinity Wars and nothing else.When you first start playing you don't realize how many subtle mechanics there are that really allow a deep level of strategy and custom deck building.  Once you do; however, you quickly come to appreciate how intricate and sophisticated this game can be (and I mean that in a very good way!).  There are also a TON of cards and card combinations, so anyone who enjoys building a unique, custom deck is going to be in hog heaven.When you do give this game a try don't be put off by the generic feeling tutorial and beginner campaign decks.  These are simple on purpose I believe to ease beginners into the game.  Once you have the basics under your belt try searching the web for some custom deck ideas.  You'll quickly see the amazing amount of different ways you can put together a devious combination of cards to wreck havoc on your opponent.And did I mention the daily log in rewards, quests, tournaments, ranked play, leveling rewards, etc. etc.?  This game has a lot going for it to keep you engaged, and it's an indie title too boot.  You can't lose on that!So, in summary:  This is a fantastic game, and if you should definitely give it a shot.  I'll bet you'll be hooked in no time.  :)And feel free to hit me up for a game anytime.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
												Infinity Wars is one of the greatest digital TCGs... scratch that.Infinity Wars is one of the greatest TCGs I have ever played, and I have played my fair share.This game is not for those who are only seeking a casual experience (seriously, go play Hearthstone or one of those web-based games), Infinity Wars has a great level of depth to the gameplay that can only be found in simultaneous turns. Imagine fusing competitive pokemon with its simultaneous turns (leading to prediction wars, 50/50s, and a very intense experience) with MTG (factions with very different tools that work together to create hundreds of possible strategies).Ok, so currently its not the most balanced game ever. The exiles faction is bothering many players with its RNG elements. HOWEVER this is not as serious a problem as many take it to be. This is not like Magic where any deck that isn't OP will never win. You can get by with a limited card pool without dropping $100 plus. This game is completely free to play. I haven't dropped a cent on this yet, although I do plan on doing so at some point to help out the developers.Speaking of limited card pools, those without a lot of Rare/Legendary/Epic cards can play "paupers" where only common and uncommon are allowed, or merged, where the two players divide their decks amongst each other. These have really long queues, however.There are a lot more features coming soon too, and IW2015 will be expanding on the already existing game. Team battles and other stuff are in the works, or so I hear.TL;DR Jus' get it. It gud an' free tu.

												At the time of this review i have logged 41 hours on this game. Infifnity Wars is an amazing tcg with new inivative mechanics combined with astounding animated are for each card. the turns are taken simaltainiously with both players having the same amount of rescources at the stard of the match, this game features a double win condidtion style of players which alters which faction and type of deck you play. content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												After 90 hours of playing, I come to the conclusion that this game is a really well thought-out one. By design, balance and pay2win aspects.Design: Organised HUD, easy overview, memorable music and nice animations for each cardBalance: Due to the Meta, rush based decks are a little stronger than stalling decks but balance retains stable overall.Pay2Win: Basically, none. The things that can be bought by LP (Lightmare points) only are cosmetics. Card packs and starter decks are both bought by real and ingame currency.I really haven't seen a cardgame like this and is has much much potential. I expect it to grow and become more popular in time.Now there are some negative aspects too. First off, you'll have a hard time as a beginner. The game has a lot of mechanics to learn, and that could take a while. And once you're done with all campaigns and bot battles you want to gather some cards and for that you gotta farm.Also matchmaking does a wierd job sometimes for beginners.Still, once you're past the newbie-status you can fully enjoy this game to your heart's content

								Awesome Game probably the best Digital TCG I have played, compared to Hearthstone it is much more competitve in nature. Lightmare is being very open and clear about their plans for the game without giving to much away which I like as well.Overall : 8.5/10 would definatly give it a try!

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												OVERALL: One of the most engaging and best card games out there. If you're looking for something fresh that is not a yet another reskin of MTG with minor gameplay changes, give this game a shot. It's only 1GB and it's free, you're not losing anything if you don't like it.Even though the playerbase is pretty small right now, the other players are really newbie friendly and the game itself lets every player access 5 ''competetive'' decks for free each week, meaning that most of the time even if you are matched with a veteran (and you will, trust me) you still stand a chance. The mechanics are very hard to compare to most online TCGs out there, but they probably come closest to Duels of Champions, with more flexible lanes, the ability to mix factions and, most importantly, simultaneous turns. This means that you not only need to plan your own turn, but also predict what the enemy will do! Once youre both done, all the actions will be played in order, meaning that it's possible to literally dodge out of spells way. There is also a ton of cards available, which is extremely impressive given the fact that they're all nicely animated.Graphically this game is the best looking one out there, even Hearthstone doesn't come close with it's production values. Each card is animated and while on some it's just a minor detail, some are truly impressive. There is quite a lot of grind to get cards without paying, but it's possible, especially if you play the draft mode. The developers are working on a solution to it, so you may want to hold on for a bit if that really puts you off.Downsides? Well, the playerbase is quite small right now, meaning that you'll run into strong players a lot. Personally I like that as it's a proper challenge and I'm still doing just fine, even though I only started this week. Does take a lot of practice and reading though as well as some imagination when you need to guess what they'll do next.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
												Now, I'm not one for writing these reviews in all honesty, but I feel the need to write something for a game that I've been pretty faithful to lately, I was playing the Beta and I was practically addicted to it during that time, I would refuse to turn off my laptop in order to play a game or two. I personally love this game, I love all the different factions and their own unique playstyles, And how almost every deck has counter-play right now, they are fairly balanced at this point in time. If you're looking for a genuine free to play game, this is one that you'll enjoy. While I can say that it gets a little tedious at times trying to get the packs you need for new cards, but that's where I like the 'Master & Apprentice' system, it's basically a system where you can play with someone you've met, or invited to the game to be either your Master or Apprentice, and for each 15 minutes of play in game with that person, you both get a 'blister pack', you also gain all the rewards of playing an actual PvP game, but you get to play it with a friend! Oh how glorius this it! XD (Sorry for my poor English at points, It's not my 'native' tongue.)

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								Let it be known I am already a fan of ccg. That being said, Infinity wars has a lot to offer any strategy minded individual. As a ccg it has some interesting features, bearing familiar elements for those adept with ccg already. There are 7 main factions, a unallied faction whose cards can be included in any deck, and of course, the amazing Star Trek expansion. Deck building is virtually unrestricted - a legal deck must have three 'Commander' cards, which determine the types of cards you can include in your deck, and at least 40 cards.  Each card has an affinity cost, and as long as you have enough generals of the appropriate type in your command slot, you can put that card in your deck. A maximum of three copies of any card can be included, but you can break that rule by also putting those cards in your command zone (protip). There are also unlimited cards, which as their nomiker indicates, can be included in any number.   Now where IW excels is that, while rare or epic cards can seriously affect the battlefield, some of the most effective decks I've run or come across use common, or even unlimited cards. I've had marked success in both ranked mode and tournament play, which are single pvp battles. These are further restricted by set types, including five different types of deck restrictions. Within these, if you are concerned about pay-to-win decks, there is even a merged deck mode, which shuffles both players card sources together, theoretically limiting the effectiveness of people with scads of cash. However, the game is balanced enough (imo) to not require such drastic measures. The draft mode as well is extremely fun, and also (if you do well) seems to be the best mode of earning the in game currency. Drafting players select three commanders from 3 4 card choices, and then draft a deck from cards that will come up in the same 4 card options. This means 0 wait time, as you are not dependant on other players to make desicions, you just draft, and then can queue up for matches at your own convenience. 3 losses and you are out, but the better you do, the more you earn. Once you accumulate 3 losses the game offers you the choice to purchase your deck, with cost reductions based on how well you did, and taking your entry fee into account. Anything purchasable in the game can be bought with the silver coins you earn from playing the game normally (infinity points) or by purchasing Lightmare points (terrible name) with actual cash. While grinding infinity points, apart from draft, is sloooooooooow, (more o's are really needed, but just imagine them) that is hopefully due to the fact that the game is still in Beta. No good getting people all jacked out too soon as of yet is the reasoning I figure. That being said, after beating the campaign mode, the tutorial/challange mode, and participating in 2 drafts, I have close to 600 cards. That's a lot of options. This game packs in a ton of great features for being free. I downloaded it about a week ago, have a full time job, and have still logged 50+ hours. I have not regretted the ZERO dollar investiment, and it's pebbles to download. I run it in windowed mode with an average pc, and can still do whatever else I like while I destroy people in pvp. If you like strategy games, get this. If you like ccg, you are actually missing out if you don't start playing this. Immediately. This is already way too long (most have you have stopped reading) but if you still are, one final note. I have spent all my in game cash on booster packs of Star Trek, b/c hell yeah Star Trek. So far I've managed to peel Commander Riker, Data twice, and mother-trucking Q himself. Now I ask, and tell me true - Why WOULDN'T you want to play a  card game where you can play WIll Riker and beat people down with him? Why?

content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is a great TCG. If you are a fan of "Magic the Gathering", you will love this. I would go so far as to say it is much better. The stratagy involved is far supierior. The fact that this game was designed as a digital TCG allows it to use mechanics that would never work with a a real world TCG the biggest being the turn system (which I freaking love). I won't go into all the details/rules of the game that make it great as I am sure you can read it n their website or watch a youtube video.You can easily play this game without spending a dime and have tons of fun without being stomped all the time. If you did feel like supporting the game and its developers the prices are far from outrageous. Compared to "MtG" and "Yu-gi-oh" the booster packs are no more expensive and the premade decks seem far cheaper. They update often and are always working on new cards and game modes to keep things fresh and interesting.  I played "MtG" for years and was blown away by how great this game is instantly and it took me like a fever. It's hands down the best TCG I've ever played digital or realworld. 10/10

content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												Deepest CCG I've played in a long time. Fun for [filthy] casuals, but what kept me playing is the complexity of strategy that you can formulate to help you win games.I started the game, finished the tutorials, the campaign, and then took a weekly free deck (aka LoL) into Ranked (aka Not LoL) and had a pretty good winrate. Well how does the game play like? It's basically turn-based laning, thinking 'what will my opponent do next turn' and 'what can i do to best counter what he will do' ...and you may soon find that the little details like slightly different positioning is the difference between victory and defeat.The only reason why the score isn't in the high 90s is that the game was "too hard" for the 15% of people who don't recommend the game. Like any good PVP game, you will be punished for your misplays, filthy casuals! Seriously though, unless you're in the bottom 15% of the curve in Steam, you'll probably enjoy the game.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								In a nutshell:  Infinity Wars is a great game, and I'd highly recommend it to anyone wanting a deep strategy card experience.**At first I was playing Infinity Wars and Hearthstone, and I was vacillating between the two.  Then I gave Infinity Wars a dedicated afternoon, and that's all she wrote.  Now it's Infinity Wars and nothing else.When you first start playing you don't realize how many subtle mechanics there are that really allow a deep level of strategy and custom deck building.  Once you do; however, you quickly come to appreciate how intricate and sophisticated this game can be (and I mean that in a very good way!).  There are also a TON of cards and card combinations, so anyone who enjoys building a unique, custom deck is going to be in hog heaven.When you do give this game a try don't be put off by the generic feeling tutorial and beginner campaign decks.  These are simple on purpose I believe to ease beginners into the game.  Once you have the basics under your belt try searching the web for some custom deck ideas.  You'll quickly see the amazing amount of different ways you can put together a devious combination of cards to wreck havoc on your opponent.And did I mention the daily log in rewards, quests, tournaments, ranked play, leveling rewards, etc. etc.?  This game has a lot going for it to keep you engaged, and it's an indie title too boot.  You can't lose on that!So, in summary:  This is a fantastic game, and if you should definitely give it a shot.  I'll bet you'll be hooked in no time.  :)And feel free to hit me up for a game anytime.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
												Infinity Wars is one of the greatest digital TCGs... scratch that.Infinity Wars is one of the greatest TCGs I have ever played, and I have played my fair share.This game is not for those who are only seeking a casual experience (seriously, go play Hearthstone or one of those web-based games), Infinity Wars has a great level of depth to the gameplay that can only be found in simultaneous turns. Imagine fusing competitive pokemon with its simultaneous turns (leading to prediction wars, 50/50s, and a very intense experience) with MTG (factions with very different tools that work together to create hundreds of possible strategies).Ok, so currently its not the most balanced game ever. The exiles faction is bothering many players with its RNG elements. HOWEVER this is not as serious a problem as many take it to be. This is not like Magic where any deck that isn't OP will never win. You can get by with a limited card pool without dropping $100 plus. This game is completely free to play. I haven't dropped a cent on this yet, although I do plan on doing so at some point to help out the developers.Speaking of limited card pools, those without a lot of Rare/Legendary/Epic cards can play "paupers" where only common and uncommon are allowed, or merged, where the two players divide their decks amongst each other. These have really long queues, however.There are a lot more features coming soon too, and IW2015 will be expanding on the already existing game. Team battles and other stuff are in the works, or so I hear.TL;DR Jus' get it. It gud an' free tu.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2015
												So I have a little bit of a hard time deciding whether or not to recommend this game. On the one hand it has excellent game mechanics and in terms of strategic depth it's probably the best card game I've seen (including magic the gathering - also if you liked magic you will almost certainly love this game!).That said the game doesn't have the largest player base anymore (only a few hundred people at a time now a days) and there are some noteworthy issues with it.Rating of IW:Mechanics: 9.5/10 (and I don't think I'd give anything a 10)Strategic Depth: 9.5/10Balance: 6 (it's not horrible and the margin by which it tends to favor certain builds isn't actually that big. But the meta has felt pretty similar for a long time).Welcoming to new players: Game 1/10; Community 7-8/10. This game takes a lot of time to really get into. It's a great game but expect to put many hours into it to get a feel for the mechanics, tricks, meta, etc. (To give a rough idea I'd say you need to spend about 20hours on this game just to get a decent feel of it).Developer Responsiveness: 6/10Bugs: 5/10 (They aren't horrible, you can still play the game and most often don't run into them, but do expect to lose matches occasionally (around 1 in 50?) due to bugs that aren't going away anytime soon).F2P: 9.5/10So with regards to the mechanics/strategy. This game uses simultaneous turns and resources automatically increase up to 10. The resources thing is nice (particularly if you are coming from magic, no getting land sc***ed or mana glut) but it's really the simultaneous turns that make this game stand out. Both players que there turns at the same time, on a given turn one player has priority and priority switches player each turn. The order of play is as follows: upkeep and comes into play effects, premeptive abilities, regular abilities, attacking and the other player defending (each of those resolves for the player with priority and then the other player and each player gets to que the order in which their cards happen within those phases) - although it's a lot more streamline when playing it than what I just described sounds.  Since both players turns are qued at the same time and resolve without either player being able to react to them this introduces a lot of bluffing into the game. For example "Which zone is this character going to be in? One were they can attack or defend or back in support where they are safer from my opponents removal cards?" A lot of the game has to do with correctly and consistently anticipating your opponents actions and winning a game has as much to do with deck construction as it does with accurately predicting your opponent (depending on the match the second one of these can be more important.. especially in draft formats).Cards: Cards are quite diverse and comprable to magic the gather in terms of the range of their mechanics. (Noting that magic has something like 20 years on this game, so more like magic back in the mercadian masques block).Welcoming to new players: The community is pretty friendly and will generally be pretty nice to players (well, maybe not if a player is complaining to them about something that they aren't really the person it should be taken up with, but in general). That said the campaign and challenges (a.k.a. tutorial/single player) is pretty short and it takes a very long time to build up ones card pool. So starting out you will probably lose a lot. Try rift runs because at least then the card pool is statistically the same for you and your opponent, but you won't have the experience with the game that they do and still don't expect to win that much for awhile. Harsh I know, and lots of players (both new and old) have given feedback on how to improve that aspect but,Developer Responsiveness: This is a game by a small indie company. They have a community manager and player support person (a different person for each of those). Both of those people are pretty on top of it and I do feel like the developers work pretty hard on the game behind the scenes. Also generally they do actually look at player feedback and address it... eventually. I've made several different suggestions (on rewording particular cards, new card ideas and various other things) as I've played the game and I've usually seen something addressing what I've mentioned (text being fixed to make it more clear, cards to fit slots that certain factions were lacking, etc). That said don't expect a quick response to anything that requires input on the devs side of things. My general feeling is that between coming up with new cards and fixing stuff that their small dev team is a bit overwhelmed and while they will get to stuff eventually it might take a few months - really pressing stuff is faster, but don't be surprised if this thing you feel like is really pressing isn't pressing enough to get addressed quickly.Bugs: The game is peer to peer, meaning that desyncs will happen and when they happen lots of things will get screwed up and sometimes the match will just freeze (in game this is refered to as the endless turn bug/glitch). Most often this doesn't happen, but expect it to happen about 1/50 matches on average and when it does happen expect it to either cost you or your opponent the game. This might eventually get fixed, but from the communty managers responses/how long people have been complaining about it, I wouldn't expect it to happen anytime soon (maybe in a couple of years?).That aside the game isn't that buggy, usually there are a few issues after a patch but they tend to get resolved within a few weeks and aren't too major (things doing a little bit different things than what the cards say, UI scrolling being a little off, etc).F2P (free to play): You get IP (in game currency for playing dependent upon how long you play (ip gain for a match caps at 5minutes into the match)) and eventhing in the game can be bought using IP. Also IP works out to being something like $3-4/hour in terms of spending real money on packs. Which is a pretty good rate considering that your getting that for just playing the game. That said, when starting out you will run into people who seem to have all the cards and be able to do these decks that you don't feel like you'll ever have the cards for. In general those people have been playing for a long time. It requires a lot of time and/or money in order to get a good card pool and whether or not the person has been spending money or not if they have a good card pool they have probably played for quite some time (notice my almost 1300hours on the game and I didn't start until this game was advertized on steam). The game does favor more experienced players, honestly less in the card pool issue (since there is a built in draft format that is a lot of fun and honestly better than ranked play, at least in my opininon), more in the fact that it's a deep strategy game and it takes time to learn how to play and then a lot more time to learn how to play well.Overall it's a great game, with some notable drawbacks, but I'd still strongly encourage checking it out if you have time. It's more one of those games to play for awhile, get a good feel for and then come back to it now and then (I strongly encourage long breaks from it when you get bored with it).

content:
Posted: December 8, 2015
												TL:DR Solid Card Game. Gameplay/mechanics are ok but somewhat overpowerd all over the place. Games can be really short cause a 40 card deck is used > faster pulls > faster good cards > faster game. The Cardart is average at best and the "animated" part most of the times is a joke... a really lame one. Please take my low gametime into account on this review.So the Gameplay and Coremechanics of this game pretty much allow for the same things you would except of a cardgame. Control, aggro, ramp, graveyardaction, you want a certain heartstone/magic/yugioh deckstyle? you can build it. At first glance i really really liked this but i wondered why the games always turned out to be very short. Well only 40 cards in your deck so if your used to drafting and get your core combo going fast the game will end fast. Doesnt mean its easy to win. It's not cause its a lot more "poker"-type to play cause the turns are resolved simultanously. you might be casting destructionspells on the enemy killercard... and he just pulls it back to base the same turn. he saves his card, you get nothing for yours. Nice! The reasons i wont be continueing playing and recommending this to any of my friends are simple. The cardart looks like the lower average user of deviantart has created it. I didnt see any card where i just zoomed in on it and was yawdropped by the art. Then there is the "animated cardgame" thing... the battlefield is a bad 3d type and the animation mostly consists of slight breathing movements or fast resovled 3 or 4 single frames. lame and also not of the epic looking kind. Also bad seems to be the way of card requisition. over the 4 hours gametime i had i managed to buy 3, yes three! cards with the influence points i got. yes i got boosters through quests but those where the starter quests. so there is no longterm benifit for this game. you just wont get cards in a good manner of time spent/card.not recommendedDont think this review was helpful? Leave a comment! I'm happy to give you any information you want :) .Dislike this review cause you disagree? Well cant help with that, its my personal opinion. Feel free to leave a comment to corrrect me, maybe you are the one getting me back into this game :) .

content:
Posted: April 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								i love this game!  I have been playing CCGs since Magic the gathering 4th edition came out.  Most recently I played a big name digital card by Blizzard, which i was very disappointed with.  Infinity Wars is the whole package.  Fun gameplay, fantastic card animations, and a HUGE library of cards.Now some specifics:1) there is a fantastic campaign mode that quickly gets you starter sets for every faction in the game, enabling you to quickly begin trying all the factions out to see what kind of decks you might like.2) I felt like I was always unlocking new cards.  after only playing for 4 days I have over 600 cards.3) There is never any need to spend real money on this game.  you can unlock every card just by playing the game.4) You get a random card just for logging in every day.  that card can be any card and rarity.  from common to legendary.5) Theres a reward for playing 3 games in a day, and weekly quests as well.6) You get rewarded for playing against your friends.  More xp, more in game currency, and more cards.7) This is the first digital CCG I have played that actually feels good to play on the computer.  In fact the game itself would not work as a tabletop game. Thats because...8)  Each player plays cards at the same time!  Let me explain.  each turn you have about 2 minutes to spend your resources to summon you characters, use special abilities, attack your foe and defend yourself.  Once you have done everything you want for the turn you simply push the "end turn" button. While you have been doing everything listed above so has your opponent, so when you both push "end turn" the uniqueness of simultanious play really shines.  every happens in a specific order for both characters at the same time, allowing for bluffing, tricking, trapping and utterly destorying your foe in fun new ways not possible in traditional card games.Now for some of not so good things about infinity wars:1) this is most definatly still a beta version of the game.  it crashes, it gltches, cards will be covered by other text, some cards abilities act a little wonky.  the game still has some bugs for sure, but even with its technical issues it is still worth playing.2) the card library needs some work.  when you go in to find a card there are some helpful search options to find what your looking for, but there needs to be more.  there needs to be an option to look up cards by special ability and by resource cost.  you can llok up cards by faction, by type of card, and by which set of cards its from; but with the amount of cards in the game there needs to be a better way to narrow it down.3) This game needs more players!  I dont know how many people are currently playing, but there have been a few times when Ive tried to play some PVP matches and it took 3-5 minutes to find someone to play against.4) It seems to take lots of in game currency to buy anything.  it costs 5200 points to buy a boster of cards that comes with 15 cards.  you get at most 75 points after playing a bot, or 150 for beating a pvp match.  if its your friend you both get 150 win or lose.  you need to play 70 bots minimum to get a booster or 35 pvp matches.  In my opinion you should be able to get a booster in half that many games.so there you have it.  dispite some flaws that will hopefully be worked out as the game nears official release this is still the digital CCG to play.  Fast, fun, and unique in a way no other card game has every been.  Hope to see you on Infinity Wars!

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								A good alternative to Hearthstone and MTG that features stunning card animations and very unique gameplay.Infinity Wars is an easy to learn but complex card game that focuses on winning in either two ways, destroy the enemy fortress (which has health) or kill enough of their minions and deplete enemy morale to zero, forcing their retreat. You choose 3 commanders, of whatever faction you wish, but depending on which cards you want to use, you will need a minimum amount of that factions commanders. An example would be having a specific faction card, lets say (Genesis) that requires you to have 2 of its factions commanders. For this card to be in your deck, you need 2 of those 3 required commanders to be of that faction, in this case Genesis. This allows for unique deck creation as you can have 1 commander from 3 different factions, allowing you to use faction cards with a required commander cost of 1, making it a unique and versatile deck. Or if your like me, use three commanders from the same faction and gain access to its extremely powerful cards.Very noob friendly with a long and informative tutorial that is completely optional to do, but I would highly recommend completing the first two sections to make sure you understand the game. The third is for more advanced play, and can take upwards of an hour to complete, due to learning how to use special game mechanics.To make sure you aren't getting destroyed, multiplayer VS people is disabled until you reach level 4, which will take roughly 1:30 - 2:00 hours to finish.There is a long campaign that is interesting and very fun, which allows you to play every faction in the game to better learn its playstyle and get comfortable with the cards they command. Or if you feel like killing computers for that much wanted experience, just play the AI over and over until you reach the required level.No Pay 2 Win, you can pay for decks and booster packs with real money or use the in game currency to buy cards. (like most online TGC) If you do choose to sink money into IW, the prices are very reasonable and you get a good amount of cards added to your collection.Low player base, as its probably not very popular with the current kings of cards being MTG and more recently, Hearthstone.If you were to ask me to explain Infinity Wars in a sentence, it would be (Its like the middle grounds of Hearthstone and Magic: The Gathering: animated cards, complex at times, simple to learn and very fun to play)Personal Rating: 4/5

content:
Posted: April 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								Rewards for playing are great and it has some very inovative combat that allows strategy, bluffing and prediction.Turns occur simultaniously so no waiting or interupting of play. PVE content is quite rich compared to other games. Still some bugs but plays very well over all. This is currently my #1 TCG.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								It's a trading card game that is beautiful and you'll need to bring some strategics to the board.I've played this game and Heartstone. I prefer IW to heartstone. because this seems to have a bit more depth.I find the diversity in IW a big pro. Also not necessary to buy any cards - because you get quite some free booster packs by achieving stuff (single player campaign, pvp games, by logging in every day and/ or playing three matches).There are a lot of different gameplays (merged for example merges both players decks, rifting which will build a deck befoe you start - and with that one you need to keep winning as much as possible, before losing 3 times).I did purchase some booster packs to help the development - and to enhance my chance on a few cool cards. But really it's completely playable (the campaign) without any purchases - just finished the campaign.Apart from the regular cards, there are also star trek:tng cards - you do need to purchase that if you want. But apart from adding ST:TNG to your deck it's just cards, that you don't really need  of course.The selection of cards to build a deck could be better, but since the game is only in beta - i imagine that this will improve in the next period.All in all - if you like trading card games, i highly recommend this. My referralcode is F9DD5. But the referral system is not yet active - because it's still beta.The game itself is stable, fun, intelligent and... well fun.

number of helpful: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
												I came in to this very skeptical because honestly most free to play card games are garbage. This is not. At a time when f2p companies shill out insults like "dungeon keeper" and refer to gamers as "whales" to be harvested for money, Infinity Wars stands out as a small glimmer of hope. You can unlock everything you need to get started by playing the campaign, they give you a free card daily, they let you earn IP points toward deck and booster purchases that you earn just by playing, and they even give you a handful of free to play decks that are rotated weekly just in case you are too lazy to build your own.     The game mechanics are solid but are a bit hard to explain, there are other reviews that have covered them in depth so I'm just going to say the way the game plays is unique, functional, challenging , and fun. The campaigns are easy to blow through and give a reasonable back story for the game world. The multiplayer community as far as I have seen have been friendly and are generally good sports.    Just try it, it isn't like you will lose anything by doing so, and I have a feeling you will be very pleasantly surprised if you give this game a chance.     Edit Since my initial review they have massively dumbed down the campaign so that aspect is now unfun and provides no backstory.

content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												Hey, it´s free, it doesn´t rub your nose into a puddle of "PAY MONEY HERE" mud and its quite some fun to play. If you compare it to MTG, it has some serious flaws, but nothing that would spoil the entire experience.The design is ok, with some nice card artworks - but the animations are nothing that would save an entirely bad TCG at all. The gameplay is interesting enough to keep you entertained, dividing the battlefield into attacking forces and defending forces gives some nice twists compared to MTG.What I really like about the game is the cast single player campaign against AI. It brings back memories from the good old days when majestic chess tought you the game of the games by telling a nice story of a lost kingdom, guiding you from one chess experience to the next.The campaign in Infinity Wars does a similar job.Give it a try!

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
												Hey.Heres my thoughts of Infinity wars TCCG.I played some (some will say a lot) of MTG , but last time i played is a few years ago. That way i know what to expect from a Card game like this. Was I dissapointet? NO. This game really bring some new and exiting aspects to the genre.Many game mechanics is well known, and some even has familiar names (like haste etc..). The new mechanics are an awesome addition to the genres as well. Gameplay:The first thing you notice is the 3 Commanders sitting on the battlefield right from turn 1 , ready to use their abilities! Technically they're not actually on the battlefield, as the term battliefield is used for specific areas of the entire playing field. This is not a rule book though, so I wont go into further details here. The commanders will decide wich "mana colors" (MTG term), or "Faction" as we call them you can play. By determining the 3 commanders you choose weather you go for 3 different factions, or maybe just a single faction. "Purity" then determines how "powerfull" spell or characters you can have within that faction. The most powerfull will require 3 commanders of the same color.One of the first thing that I noticed was the very fluid gameplay. You have something to play and do every single turn. The way resources are handled are so much better compared to MTG, at least in my opinnion. You start each game with 1 ressource, and you gain 1 each turn. By turn 10 both players should have 10 resources (resources are like mana). There are ways however to speed up the process of getting much mana faster though just like we know from other games. There are ALSO ways to Loose a step in the race for mana. Cards like asassinate will let you asassinate ANY character on the board. But the Price is that you Loose 1 ressource point. You will still reach 10, but it will now take 1 turn more than you're opponent, There are also ways to gain more than 10 total. The way this Works results in a fluid gameplay. Everyone that plays MTG know that even the best deck can have a really bad Draw and either Draw no land, or just land land land. Both ways will destroy most decks in MTG. You will never run short of mana in IW, or get a bad Draw (at least mana wise). If you construct your deck wisely, you can rely on the deck to Work close to perfect everytime. In other words, you know that you have excatly 6 mana (at least) on turn 6 etc...The playfield is divided into zones. This is a huge improvement!!! There is so much more "mind game" going on inside the game, since you can move most Cards from one zone to another, and even from the actual "battlefield" and back to a support zone. Even the most powerfull Cards from your opponent can be countered by simply anticipating what he will do, and move cards out of the battlefield when you expect him to. Awesome when it Works. On the other hand can you move your own stuff away from the battlefield to "bluff" that a mass destruction spell or similar are Brewing, and then ending up with a non defended "defense" zone at your opponent... Great new aspect to the Whole TCG genre :)Is it pay to win? - Both yes and no- You can play ALOT without paying a dime! - playing through the campain will earn you a lot of free Cards and plenty of the ingame points to start playing draft, or rift run as its called in IW.- Rift run is fairly cheap, 1000 in game points, for each run. A run can be several games, at least 3, but if you reach 5 or 6 games you already earned enough points to go Again.- If you wanna play constructed you might want to Invest in som Cards, but you really dont have to.The first time i tried "constructed" mode with the basic free Cards i earned through the campain i REALLY got crushed. Mostly by very powerfull decks with Cards that i never seen before. (read: the first 10 games i lost!!)I'm not sure how the match up system Works? - i find no documentation on that anywhere?It would be nice to have several "classes" so that newbees only match up against similar players with similar strenght.That should apply to both "normal" and "ranked" play. It will be easier for newcomers, and probably also more competitive for the seasoned players. For him Theres no fun in beating a newbee in 5 turns game after game.Multiplayer vs. AIThe AI in the game is very week, and provides no match up at all. As soon as you have played just a few hours the AI dummies will be so easy to beat that you cant really test out new deck ideas etc. in that way. You have to go multiplayer.And of course this game wouldn't be anything with out multiplayer. And funny enough this is both the games strongest point and also the weekest point. The strong point is that the Whole mechanism of doing actions simultaneously and than have to see what happens when your battle orders is carried out is very well suited for multiplayer on-line game. In fact I dont see this concept being ported to "real life" Card games, and the feature would be very uniqe to a digital version of gaming. The week thing though is that there are WAY too many bugs, disconnecting from servers, waiting in infinty for opponents etc... I have lost quite many rift runs due to disconnecting! which really is SO annoying, and by no Means acceptable. It shouldn't be rocket science to make a multiplayer game in 2014 , come on really?I usually sit Down, knowing I have a few hours to play maybe 8,10,12 games one evening. I play 5 games, 3 of them ended in either a win because the opponent disconnect, or I disconnect and Loose... Sure I will quit the game and go use my time on something better. Over time I will not Invest in any Cards, and then I will Loose interest in the game overall. Yes, there have been days where I can play 9 out of 10 games with no disconnection, but I havent yet had 10 out of 10 without problems.These issues have to be fixed.If you asked my if i wanted lightmare to focus on better servers or more great Card expansions, i would definetly say FIX the server issues right now!I know the base game is free, but will there be players left if it doesnt Work,.

												It is probably the best TCG at the moment, I find it better than Magic - The gathering, Hearhhstone and any other card games that is currently out there. Early Access Review
								I've been impressed with this game so far. Neat combat mechanics but with enjoyably complex card text in places. The animated cards are the best I have seen in this type of game; they are gorgeous, atmospheric and fun pieces that do a lot to bring the player into the world, and they justify the time spent building decks. Probably worth the (complete lack of) admission fee alone.More people should be playing this. If you like Hearthstone but want some meatier deck building and card interactions, or just a Magic alternative, I recommend it.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10
												I have thoroughly enjoyed this game and still do whenever I play it. This game has been plagued by bugs from the start and a few tend to pop-up every now and then after a new patch, but it's pretty much bug free at the moment. The game has such a unique playstyle with a battleground consisting of four zones to put your cards in. Besides having to worry about your fortress' health, you also have to take the morale of your troops into account - losing too many valued troops will ensure defeat as much a the destruction of your fortress. Combined with the synchronised turn system this creates a tactical element and a mind-game that is unseen in other card games! The different factions have a truly unique playstyle and some of the animated cards are something to marvel at. The learning curve is rather steep but this just kept me coming back to the game to learn more about it and improve my playstyle and deckbuilding knowledge. Give this game a try: play the campaign and some player matches with the free-to-play weekly decks and I'm sure you will be captivated by the experience.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2016
												Overall:  +ves    Variety, Replayability, Many cards, Customization-ves    Occasional glitches and longer online loading times, Somewhat slow response time onlineInfinity Wars is an excellent card game. Those who like games like Magic and Hearthstone will likely enjoy this free game noting similarities in gameplay. There are 8 factions cards can be a part of but you generally have 1-3 of these types in your deck so the game doesn't try to limit you to specific cards from only one faction. Each faction has a certain advantage and style to the way the cards are. Personally my favourites are the Sleepers of Avarrach (zombies), Warpath (powerful beasts), Exiles (unpredictable demons) and Cult of Verore (Spell focused).Cards can have specific advantages like Charge, Flying, Reach, and special abilities which make the game interesting. Like most games of this manner, the goal is to reduce the opponent's health to zero by attacking their fortress directly, but you can also win by reducing the opponent's morale by killing many of his/her cards. This adds a variety of ways to play and no game is ever really the same.There is a shorter to medium length campaign that is relatively interesting. They did only have it for 4 of the factions but added 2 more which leads me to assume they will make 2 more for the remaining factions. New players can get cards through the campaign and you can get more cards by a) signing in dailyb) leveling upc) buying them in the shop using in-game currency or real moneyThere are tons of cards to collect so don't worry about collecting them all and having nothing left to do.After campaign there isn't too much to do besides online battles. However, there is a decent online community and finding a match for me has ranged from 20 seconds to 4 minutes. There is some options online however I have only done constructed battles. It is completely random I believe because I have ended up playing against people way better than me with very rare cards and also against people not that good. Expect anyone playing online to have completed campaign and to be somewhat skilled. The cool thing about online is that you can use any deck you want (as long as it is legal) so there is unlimited replayability.For someone who isn't very good at the strategy and just enjoys collecting cards, making a deck, and trying to win with it, this game is very fun and although not always forgiving, not overly hard to get a win here and there to keep it fun.

												Probably the best TCG I've ever played.. simultaneous turns make it so games are not decided by who goes first.. you have to anticipate your opponents moves and how they'll counter you. The other thing I like it about it is that compared to other card games it's not a super huge grind to get all the cards you want.. the game is not purely pay to win you can earn packs by playing, completing daily missions(for the currency to buy packs), and by logging several days in a row.Aside from that, it's got everything you'd expect from a tcg combos and synergy and some very fun decks to build and collect.

												Look, it's a great idea. There are so many great concepts in the game, and the animation for cards are pretty good. I will keep on playing this game until it gets shut down (if that ever happens).Why don't I recommend it? The Dev team. From what I've heard, they were good at some point in time, but now they just don't seem to be giving it their all. Not fixing bugs, starting tournaments for a small player base, and upping prices as it goes on, it just seems to be falling apart.If you like strategy and/or card games, keep your eye on it. But for now? Don't waste the space.

												"888 hours of on-off again love making." Infinity Wars is an ♥♥♥♥♥♥ic culmination of the perfect TCG for strategic like minds. Lightmare achieved great success in creating an innovative and pleasurable card game from its competitors; (Hearthstone, Hex, Duelyst, Labyrinth, Spellweaver etc.) The only dysfunction was in the management and disappearance of any sort development or communication to its players. That really hurt the already dwindling player base and left much of the community angry. We felt quite disrespected and discouraged. However, in the past months bugs have gotten squashed and patches are cleaning off the dirt they let collect. They're redeeming themselves and I have hope that the process will not stop. content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								The game is fun and addictive if you are into TCG's like MTG or Hearthstone. Its edge lies in almost endless possibilities of combos reserved on your choice of cards in your deck.Cons: -Matchmaking is pretty much who's currently online in the game, since you don't know how many players are in there. -You end up battling the same player over and over again for about 3-15mins while looking for a normal game or ranked.-most game modes are there for show-Prices of decks and booster packs by IP are discouraging to play more.-Cosmetics are only purchaseable by LP. Only chance to get cosmetics is through pre-order-A lot of imbalances and glitches (common since it is still in beta)-Too many cheesers who will end the game in about 8turns as if they are cheatingPros:-Solid community, since the devs and mods are practically online everyday to chat. Hence, they can improve the game through direct feedback and players will get their news faster and gain a heads up on what's being added/fixed in the game.-Wide range of strategy to choose from be it defensive or offensive type of battle as their is a Morale mechanic to the game.-Great and humorous artwork. Its animation makes it an eye-catcher to new players and veteran players alike as if you want to collect them all.-There's a rift run mode practically the same with Hearthstone; but it gives you an opputunity to buy the deck (hence getting the cards you need or that might come in handy)Overall, I recommend this game. If I were to rate it, I guess it's an ok game of 7/10.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												TL,DR:Pros:    + Free to play (definitely not pay to win, you can get all the cards without spending anything),    + You get plenty of free cards to start with,    + Great training and campaign,    + More complex and interesting that Hearthstone, but less complicated than MTG,    + Great game balance and plenty of unique factions/play styles,    + Easy learning curve if you are comming from another TCG    + Helpful and friendly community in chat,    + Active Devs! They can even be found in chat,    + Simultanious turns means little idle time while in a match,    + It never feels grindy, and if you decide to pay with real money the prices are quite reasonableCons:    - Limited playerbase, I have no idea why,    - Game is not without its (minor) bugs,    - While you do get a lot of cards to start with, they are mostly commons and uncommons, you will need to spend a lot of time trying to get rarer cards and cards that you need,    - Card base is nowhere near as large as MTG, but to be expected from a relatively new game.Long, did Read:Great for a free to play game. Playing thru the campaign gets you around 600 cards (easily enough to make a decent deck) and enough IP (in game credit) to buy another booster pack. It never feels grindy and it is fun regardless of what cards you own.After you have completed the training and campaign there is a solid match making system in place for when you want a challenge. On top of that, if you feel that you can't make a competitive deck with your own cards there are weekly free decks to borrow. While the game is definetely a true free to play (you can get all the cards without paying a cent), you will notice the strength of decks of more seasoned players. The main issue isn't the game itself, but the fact that few people have heard about it. Having said that, the AI is puts up decent fight and if you are prepared to wait a lil while to find a match, you are in for a treat!  Alternately invite a friend (it's free) so you don't have to wait to find a match!Edit: Spelling

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 29, 2016
												A TCG that is hardly pay to win? Yeah, I can win about half the casual games I play and I have only spent money in the game recently.(just to support it, not because I needed anything.) The game gives you a lot of average pre-made decks to start off with and a lot of good cards, including some rare ones, just by playing the campain.(not tradable) Sure if you want to spend $100 in this game you could, but even $5 is enough to get you a good 43 card deck. The gameplay is fairly good and has hundreds of good stratigies to try. The game is still getting updates and being reworked to be more friendly to new players. There are a few things that are not very good about the game. The bugs, the way you can face up againt players much better than you that you never have a chance to win against.(it faced me up against the best IW player in the world, Adorabear once) and the voice acting in the campaign. With those downsides in mind, this is being made by a relitivly small team so the downsides get a pass by me. Over all, it has it's quirks but is worth a try to anyone who even might see this as slightly entertaining. It is free after all.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												tl;dr: I like it a lot.I've never really been able to get into the CCG/TCG scene due to the fact that I'm always poor. Recently I started playing Hearthstone which I love but it doesn't have TONS of depth or strategy. Then, I remembered reading about Infinity Wars so I hopped on Steam to check it out. I love it! With the multiple zones, multiple factions and being able to win by dropping either the health or morale of your opponent, the amount of strategy in this game is ridiculous! Though, the amount of options does add a bit of a learning curve, the tutorials and Campaign are a great way to learn the game before jumping into PvP. Added to the fact that you get a decent amount of cards from the campaign and leveling up you don't actually have to drop any money to enjoy it! I might end up spending some real money down the road but as of now I don't think this is as Pay 2 Win as other F2P CCG's. Add the fact that you can trade (unsoulbound) cards with your friends and you have the formula for an awesome as hell Free 2 Play TCG! Download. Play. Enjoy!

content:
Posted: April 12, 2016
												This game is an unpolished buggy mess.  Mousing over a keyword ability is supposed to explain what the ability actually is, but in almost all cases it just gives you the card's text in another text box.  I've mulliganed and have been unable to drag the only one cost card I have into the play area.  I've leveled up only to not receive any of the rewards I was promised for doing so.  And worst of all are the desyncs that make the game totally unplayable.  On the gameplay side, the non-standard modes appear to be totally barren, those modes being the only ones (other than draft) that eliminate the pay/grind-to-win aspects inherent in any tcg/ccg.  And the draft mode is just a gambling game where you pray to RNGesus to please give you good cards to chose from.  All that being said, it's free to play so I guess there's no good reason for people reading this not to try it.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								Edit: Went back to the game end of 2016 after long break. It is more balanced and polished than ever before. While the playerbase is unfortutanely quite small, Infinity wars is still the best online card game out there. There may be games that have more cards, and features and gimmicks, but they often become very linear an predictable. IW with its unique simultaneous turn based mechanic is still ahead of its time. You can't just make the perfect move as you would in a chess game or other trading card games, you always have to outsmart your enemy and be unpredictable, which makes this game very unique.Old 2014 review:Most addictive game I've played since.... I cant remember!  Get it now!  In my opinion its definitely not pay for win. You get enough cards create nice decks, or you can play shuffled mode where it doesnt matter who has better cards. Personally, I spent some money to support these creative developers, and because I love the Star Trek cards :DBut be warned, you may not get any sleep anymore...

content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												I have not played a better digital trading card game, and I have tried quite a few. Infinity Wars seeks to be truly unique by taking full advantage of the digital space, doing things a normal card game cannot easily do. We see basic things like animated cards and persistant health amounts, but we also see the major gameplay element of simultaneous turns, where both players plan out their turns, then once both players hit End, they resolve at the same time. This creates a game where you have to consider what your opponent might be about to do and predict their plans.As said, I have never had more fun playing a card game, and I suggest giving it a look.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2015
												As someone who goes out every friday night to play FNM (Friday Night Magic (The Gathering)) I can tell you with full honesty that this game is truely unique in its playstyle. The simultanious turn system is absolutely invigorating and forms a whole new way of thinking about which cards to play. The game has a tutorial system for playing and learning the functions that will tell you what the phase or type of card is and then put you in a partial game to use the new fuction or type of card and allow you to learn without shoving information down your throat.The free cards for the day can be both REALLY awesome or a common, but it is one of the few games that stay true to the "consistant login yields better rewards." Somedays I will literally login and play three games to get both free cards, others i'll get on and just play and get them along the way. While the levels themselves seem to have no purpose, every time you level up you are rewarded with a free booster pack (untradeable cards however.) In-game currency can be used to buy booster packs that do contain tradeable cards. Potentially my favorite thing with this game is it's ability to hold true to "No One Deck Wins" (similar to MTG)

content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								Awesome card game. I love how it isn't even possibly to play physically due to synchronous turns (as well as the added tactics that that brings) - really makes the game stand out!It's also got fully animated cards that look amazing. Personally I'm a huge fan of drafting, getting to play with a large variety of cards is really interesting. I've got a few videos of it up here: https://www.youtube.com/user/TheSabre070It's got ranked constructed play, if you're into that. It's not super hard to get a competitive deck going and you don't need to pay money (though it can help to have some variety) and can earn cards with in-game currency. Great gameplay, great art, great community - what more do you need?

content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												I just spent three hours learning the basics of this game, going through the first campaign, and trying to build my first deck. I thoroughly enjoyed it.It is a very fun way to play a TCG with the "simultaneous turns." You have to really think about what the other player may or may not do before you strike out to fulfill your destiny.There appears to be a reasonably priced system to buy new decks, avatars, skins, etc. There are also points that you win in-game that you can use to buy some of those things as well.Admittedly I struggled trying to build my own first deck the the cards I had unlocked, but I am sure I will figure it out soon enough. There are daily and weekly quests as additional incentive to play and... it is a tactic that will probably work on me.As I put more hours in--if anything changes--I'll come back and update my review.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												This game looks amazing and has great and inventive mechanics.I'd recommend it if I could actually play it, but currently the game is as broken as I've ever seen a game be, it's a flip of a coin on whether I'll be able to interact with menus, load into a game with my deck and hand, or even be able to get into the play menu. The game is unplayable without restarting ever few matches, and even when playing it's really clunky. Building a deck is a major pain that takes forever since you have to add cards some cards in an obtuse way to get them into the deck, and if you're unlucky your deck just won't save, or card sprites will stick to the window, or you won't be able to add/remove cards from your deck.The unranked play is an absolute joke. I played two games, went up against people that either grinded for hundreds of hours to buy the cards they had, or dropped few hundred dollars to make incredibly strong decks. I, on the other hand, had only the cards the game had given me for completing 19 campaign missions, and a deck that was legal and possibly decent if it didn't go up against decks that were stacked with Uniques, epics, and rares. The ranked play is locked behind level 10, which is a bit ridiculous and generally just turns me off of the game entirely.The campaigns are okay, but generally they just give you a deck and put you up against an AI, tell you very little, then assume that you can use whatever trick or gimmick of your deck to beat your opponnent's deck. It's unintuitive and generally a slog, though some missions are fun, most are very boring or luck based.The game could be amazing, it really could be; but at the moment it's a broken mess that I will not be revisiting anytime soon. This game is not fit for release, do not pay money into it until you've played at least a few hours and experienced the many bugs and glitches the game has to offer.

content:
Posted: April 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								Infinity wars is like any card game in real life. You gotta buy cards with real money. You kinda can't have a card game that's free and still have trading value and a economy. Well you probably can but let's just infinity wars does it decently enough. It's a card game that focuses around factions or "Purity" as it's called in game. unlike some card games, you don't take turns, you place down your cards and then hit ready and hope you played it right. This makes the game not so heavily RNG based and a bit more skill based. Unfourtunately it has it's cons. It uses in-game currency which is just a big no no in my book. It's also a big grind to get cards without paying. a REALLY big grind. You get a big sized deck everytime you level up (non tradable) but because the game is faction based you may only get a few cards you like or none at all. You can only have 3 of every card in your deck. This means once you get more then 3, the rest are worthless. There are "infinite characters" which you can have as many as you like till you reach the cap point of 100 cards per deck. Trust me, you'll get alot of dupes. It's still a great game and has a nice community. If you can get past the micro transaction part of it, it's a nice game.

I could just "get gud" but the grind is slow, especially with the bugs and like I said it's mehh at best.A solid 3/10 in its current state as it's free2play.

content:
Posted: February 5
												Got this game a few years back, and it seemed like a pretty cool game. The battle mechanics were pretty cool and the decks (and their card art) where really unique. However, the game was riddled with bugs, is still riddled with bugs, and many of those bugs actually interfere with your ability to play the game (freezing up, rounds not playing through, forcing you to leave a game you are in the middle of, random♥♥♥♥♥crashes, etc.).It's not like these bugs are a rare thing either, and for a long time I would look in the steam community and see a lot of people asking for these bugs to be addressed. Despite this, it seems like the devs were more interested in reworking the story mode (which was fine the way it was), making minor UI changes, and shoving out a grand total of ONE deck over the years.The game is also fairly dead now in comparison to when I started, often taking several minutes to find a match, which may crash or freeze as previously mentioned, and the people you get paired up with are either very new (which is not a problem if you're new to the game), or have put four times the amount of hours into this game that I have (which is a massive problem for new players) and no inbetween. The devs promised to fix that by advertising the game so more people would try it out, but I haven't seen any ads whatsoever, so the game is probably going to stay dead at this point.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								First of all, it cannot be overstated that beta is beta. There are missing sounds and animations, placeholder art, the interface needs reworking, and some things are just generally really rough around the edges. I'm going to assume that these things will be worked on and improved before the game is officially released. I have concerns about this, but more on that later.Infinity Wars is, in all aspects that are not likely to change during the beta, an excellent trading card game. The cards look great,  the gameplay mechanics are really innovative and fun, and there's plenty of modes for experienced players and free to play people alike.Speaking of free to play, Infinity Wars makes Hearthstone look like it's made by EA. I got a 15 card booster today just by logging in. The draft mode - directly copied from HS - has an entry fee of around 0,30€ (1,73€ in HS) if you convert the premium currency to real money, or 1000 IP, which you gain from playing. Going straight 0-3 gives you over a third of the IP back, and over five wins pays the whole thing back already. You also get free cards and boosters from simple daily quests, doing the campaign missions and leveling up, which is fairly rapid.While I'm going to recommend the game, I'd still suggest that you don't get into it just yet. My internal alarm bells are going off at the Infestation set preorder boosters. Why are they adding new cards when the already existing ones aren't finished yet? There are much more pressing issues than adding more content right now, and I can't be sure that the game gets to the level of polish I'm expecting it to.It's probably going to the best f2p card game on the PC regardless of how much or little it improves from this point, though.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 11, 2014
												Try Infinity Wars. It's interactive, intellectual and packs some great innovations into a neatly designed TCG. - Simultaneous Turns- Inherent Anticipation & Deception- 3 Guaranteed Cards per Player- Inherent Hand Management MechanicsThe art and lore aren't to my taste, but this is still one of my favorite TCGs. The gameplay relies on your ability to anticipate your opponent and defy their expectations. It's strategic in the same vein as a high stakes game of poker. A lot of times when I play any of a dozen better known TCGs, it feels like my opponent and I are playing 2 independent games of solitaire. This game could not be further from that.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												A good TCG. Innovative game mechanics with simultanious turn resolution and other things that can work in a virtual TCG but not in a IRL one.  Simultanious turn resulution turns it into a real mind game, very strategic. Have to predict the others move in every turn. Commander system:Having three commanders and seting deck (faction) purity with them is very good, makes deckbuilding fun. Need to chose three creatures to be your commanders, can play them straight from command zone or use their ability, but they are vournable to some attacks (Perils of command, assassinate), and are revealed to your opponent from the start.The artwork is good, some are very good ("Give him a jetpack!" XD), the animation makes it look even better.I feel that that those who don't want to pay are not forced to grind for long hours to stand a chance. (Pauper deck format good for new players). Good for casuals too. Campaign to get cards, get to know the factions and gameplay and some backstory. Story is not mindblowing, but this is a TCG so it doesn't need to be.Maybe a bit buggy at times, but the devs are fixing it in good time (nothing game breaking).
