number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												This is a game similar to Magic: The Gathering.  It is different from MTG in many ways.  The first is that the turns are taken simultaneously.  You play all the cards you want either from your hand, or move them around the battlefield.  When you have made all the changes you would like to make you hit end turn.  Your opponent has been doing the same thing on his side.  Once both players have hit end turn the turn resolves, with abilities resolving before attacks.Another difference is the gathering of resources to be able to play cards.  In Infinity Wars it automatically increases each turn, there is no need to play resource generating cards.Scoring is also different.  In Infinity wars you have what amounts to two different damage counters, one for your fortress and one for morale.  If either one reaches 0 you lose.  If one of your creatures attacks unblocked it will do damage to the fortress.  When a creature is killed its morale value is deducted from its owner's total.There is an Academy which will teach you how to use the different types of cards, with Basic, Intermediate, and Advanced areas.  When you complete all the sections in an area you are presented with a graduation challenge to help reinforce the subject areas.  There is also a single player campaign that will help you to learn about the different factions.  The game is currently in Early Access Beta, and there are a few glitches.  I have not run into any that make me want to stop playing.  As you play you earn rewards which can be turned into additional cards and booster packs.  You also earn experience points, and along with experience points Infinity Points.  The Infinity Points can be used to buy additional decks, and booster packs.  If you want to get extra cards faster you can purchase them using funds in your Steam Wallet, but anything you can buy without funds by using Infinity Points which you earn by playing.The game is now out of beta, and in full release.  There have been some balance changes, some good some not, but it is still a great game to play.  There are also new expansion sets which add more cards to the game.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								Infinity Wars chose a desperate time to release. With the recent release of the Hearthstone open beta, many people will be swarming to that and overlooking this TCG. Unfortunatly for them, they'll be missing out on an amazing game. Firstly, over Hearthstone, it actually has a comprehensive single player. It also has numerous factions, all of which have definitive styles of play. Most of the cards are well balanced (With a few exceptions, Verore Death Worshipper anyone?), and it's possible to get cards quite quickly. Additionaly, it has mechanics that shake up the usual set-up that was introduced by Magic:The Gathering, and they work wonderfully. Microtransactions might be a slight problem for some, as not all of the shop items can be bought with in-game currency, but it doesn't stick out too much. There's also a slight problem with the tutorials, as they require you to beat minor puzzles to get through them, and some people might not have the time for that. The biggest problems I've had with the game are glitches. It is an early access game, yes, but it constantly worries me. Firstly by appearantly losing my level 2 reward, then by temporarily getting rid of my progress, it can get pretty annoying. Overall though, Infinity Wars wins my vote over with it's varied card types, interesting mechanics, and beautiful animation.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												Infinity Wars will show you that TCGs were meant to be on a virtual platform.The artwork of its fully-animated cards is absolutely magnificent and supported by a rich and continuously evolving lore. It will satisfy all hard-core TCG fans with its simultaneous turns and strategic mechanics as well as various ladder and competition systems. As for the newcomers, a well designed training ground is prepared for all the factions of the game and will introduce you to all the basics and lore while rewarding you every step of the way with cards and rewards and with each new coming day just for logging in All that being said, its greatest feature is its awesome and welcoming community that you’ll rapidly get to know, especially if you hang around the Live Streams of the game and the entertaining gamers hosting them.Definitely try out this free-to-play, super fun card game and witness with us the exciting adventure that is the Infinity Wars with its community and the passionate team behind the game, working every day on improving, balancing and growing this game into an institution that will revolutionize its genre.See you on the battlefield!

content:

Early Access Review
								Infinity Wars is a pretty decent DTCG (Digital Trading Card Game). I came in to the game, honestly expecting it to suck. I was pleasantly surprised to find that not only was the game fun, it was easy to learn. As the title of the game shows the cards themselves are indeed animated and there is a lot going on besides just the standard "lay card on table" gameplay. I find the fact that there are quite a few modes to play and a large number of themed factions another thing this game has going for it. So far there seems to be a good amount of players but only time will tell if that will last. You have some say as well after all, you should try it you might just find a new favorite.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								Infinity Wars chose a desperate time to release. With the recent release of the Hearthstone open beta, many people will be swarming to that and overlooking this TCG. Unfortunatly for them, they'll be missing out on an amazing game. Firstly, over Hearthstone, it actually has a comprehensive single player. It also has numerous factions, all of which have definitive styles of play. Most of the cards are well balanced (With a few exceptions, Verore Death Worshipper anyone?), and it's possible to get cards quite quickly. Additionaly, it has mechanics that shake up the usual set-up that was introduced by Magic:The Gathering, and they work wonderfully. Microtransactions might be a slight problem for some, as not all of the shop items can be bought with in-game currency, but it doesn't stick out too much. There's also a slight problem with the tutorials, as they require you to beat minor puzzles to get through them, and some people might not have the time for that. The biggest problems I've had with the game are glitches. It is an early access game, yes, but it constantly worries me. Firstly by appearantly losing my level 2 reward, then by temporarily getting rid of my progress, it can get pretty annoying. Overall though, Infinity Wars wins my vote over with it's varied card types, interesting mechanics, and beautiful animation.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2016
												TL:DR ; The game is amazing , Best Tcg out there but is almost dead now. So do play it even if you are not into card games , i think its a must play for every gamer.  just Dont spend money on it beacuse of its current state Full ReviewBest TCG ever  in terms of mechanics and startegy ,every other TCG out there is a distant second. This game is the best as well as my fav. But the bugs , sheer negligence of the community by devs  has ruined this masterpiece.WHAT IW can offer that no one else canAnimated cards - Seriously at first they dont seem too big of deal but once you get used to it you wont be able to go back to any other game, the art of some cards is really amazing Game mechanics - the presence of 4 diffrent zones ( command zone is an IW exclusive thing and is a game changer) , the purity combinations (the fact that you can mix diffrent classes adds so much verstality to the game )Morale as a winning condition - In almost every game "Health" is the decisive parameter using which a victory is abtained but IW adds another parameter "Morale" , Its not only the  health of your fortress you have to take care of but also the morale of your army allowing immense variety of strategies and playstylesTHE FLAWSLooks Shabby - The cards look amzaning but overall the game looks quite dull Bugs - This game has a lot of bugs , the game will often crash , trade will freeze, desyncs in matches ,the list is quite long tbh, but not a dealbreaker just close to itFuture is uncertain - the final nail in the coffin , the game  is almost dead , most of the vetrans have left the game , rest are planning to , no communication from devs ,there are talks that some other team/company will take over IW and start it from scratch To be honest no one knows your guess is as good as mine I would recommend that you atleast try the game once , its a F2P so there is nothing to lose

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 11, 2014
												Try Infinity Wars. It's interactive, intellectual and packs some great innovations into a neatly designed TCG. - Simultaneous Turns- Inherent Anticipation & Deception- 3 Guaranteed Cards per Player- Inherent Hand Management MechanicsThe art and lore aren't to my taste, but this is still one of my favorite TCGs. The gameplay relies on your ability to anticipate your opponent and defy their expectations. It's strategic in the same vein as a high stakes game of poker. A lot of times when I play any of a dozen better known TCGs, it feels like my opponent and I are playing 2 independent games of solitaire. This game could not be further from that.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								Ok, after giving the game a real try, i've seen some really cool things that i've liked. First off, I love card games so this game suckered me in when I saw it in the free games tab. One of the coolest features I saw and enjoyed, was the attack and defence zones, it makes way for real strategy, for example if you have a monster with loads of defence but very poor attack, you can put it in your defence zone to soak up damage your enemy is dealing, and vice versa wih cards with good attack but poor defence. This game reminds me of magic, not In a ripoff way, but In a good influnce sort of way. it's good to have a foundation somewere, and face it, even if it's not had any influence from MTG, fanboys are gonna rage hard simply because It's a card game where you attack people. I haven't played the game long enought to report any bugs, but for now, with the interesting tactics thrown in, I'm going to give this beta a 7/10. It's free, so download it, what have you got to lose?

content:
Posted: November 11, 2016
												Okay, after a long time of playing this I am finally going to write a recommendation.Infinity Wars is simply awesome, I've never felt compelled to play a game for this long. (Seriously, check my Steam account.)It has an amazing deep strategic background and even without paying a single dime you can become one of the top 100 players in no time. I see enough people in top 100 already that didn't spend a single cent on the game.You get plenty of cards for each campaign you complete, as well as every time you level up.You cannot compare this game to something like, for example, Hearthstone. It's not a very casual game. You need to devote time and effort to learn everything but once you figure everything out you will be dominating your foes within days. The tutorial missions are funny and nicely done without being too boring. The campaign is exciting and definitely one of the strong points about the game. (A bit of fanboy hype here, since I'm really invested in the lore of this game.)If you want a good cardgame and something you don't need to fear that P2P players will have an advantage, this game is for you.PS:The Devs answer Steam forum posts nearly hourly, are always helpful and really really kind.Update:After a long time of not having played this game I came back too see that a new dev picked it up and made it even better.This one seems honest about the game and I am so exited too finally start playing it again!So see you soon ingame!

content:
Posted: February 17
												I was schocked to find out it is possible to haae a tcg with a low entry level and high skill cap. Ontop of that that may have been the first tcg I've played that you can acquire every card without spending a dollar. Quite simply the art is amazing beeing animated and most likely like nothing you've seen before. I've spent roughly 400 hours in this game in the last few months and hoepfully that can be a testament to the quality of the gameplay. If you're shacky on trying IW give the campaign a shot, each time you level up you get free packs and various tokens/items as well as teaching you how to pay with an interesting story, albiet not the best voice acting. To top that off I don't think I've met a more welcoming community, alot of vets had helped me build the decks I need giving me cards for nothing in reutrn. anyways10/10 tcg,

Early Access Review
								I have to say that i got real addicted to this game. I love the animations and and artwork put into this. I especially love the gameplay, it's not like every other card game out there where one person goes first then its the other persons turn. You actually have to plan ahead first before making your move while your opponent is also making their move. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								This FTP strategic card game is really addictive.  It has a great campaign mode where you can use premade decks to learn the different factions, all the while unlocking loads of cards to build your own custom decks.  The campaign is great to train on before you go pvping.  The cards have motion animation and look fantastic.  The overall aesthetic is impressive too, with so many cool cards.  If they ever sell physical cards of this game, I would totally buy them.  Loads of deep strategy fun here!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								"A card game where players play their cards at the same time." -a good friend of mineI thought at first this would be a hearthstone rip off with no turn advantage, based on the FTP climate right now. To my surprise it is actually quite different from hearthstone. Here is how you should understand card games right now, I will only list pros for simplicity's sake)Hearthstone - League of Legends (simple, large community)Infinity wars - DOTA 2 (advanced mechanics, very skill dependent)MTG - Smite (stylish, very balanced)Go Fish - Adventure Time Battle Arena (lolwut)

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 2, 2016
												I took time to read the Negative Reviews (Often offers Insight) ... Yet, not being a "Card Game Fan" Decided to see for myself how terrible this game MUST be...I created my account, and within 20 Minutes of playing... I noticed I was at the edge of my seat, listening to the story unfold. I felt like I was observing these characters interact; along with the voice acting 9/10.Then this map appeared, and asking me to join a Faction... I followed the quests, and gain "Packs" that I went to main screen to open... I realized I could name my "Packs" based on what I had earned while playing- Forshadowing - PVP -3 Hours later, I had to "Retry" a scenerio where I had 30/100 Health, and a few "Morale" pts... (This is impossible... I was feeling more inclined to figure a way to make it through, or I was going to give in to what I had read in the reviews)... Through careful planning, and obversation, I felt something I rarely ever feel these days... When I won... I felt I could breath again! ... At this point, I needed a break.So... Those that have reviewed this game; most had already invested 30hrs to 200hrs and some more...- Anyone who plays that much needs a break!- I figure all the annoyances, come from PVP - Which, there's no way I'm even thinking of that.Since this game is FREE to play .. Download it... Go through this really planned out "toturial"- Simply listen to the story;as the Map unfolds...- When you read, and actually play this Card game... Keep in mind, I don't play these "Card Games"Yet, later I will log in again, and continue my Journey...

								Great game! I played MTG for a number of years and enjoyed it but for online TCG this game is better. For new players there is also a system that lets you play with someone and you both get xp an infinity points(in game currency) as well as free cards. Must play!!

												Very easy to pick up, and can pick up hundreds of good cards without paying. But to get to ranked play, you have to be level 20, and that takes like 40 hours of sheer grinding. And in rift-runs, you will get annhilated by better veteran players, so those aren't a valid option early on. It's a bit more strategic than Hearthstone, though.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												First of... What a unique new style of TCG and I love it.  The simultaneous play makes it so strategical as you discover the game that it's hard to stop trying out the various game styles.What about the price? I want to emphasis this because people always talk about 'pay 2 win' in these kind of games and it is logical that if you want many cards really fast, you'd have to spend a few dollars. Imagine if Magic Cards were all free. + there are many ways to get free boosters if you don't feel like spending right away. The price of a booster is as little as a dollar so nothing to complain about on this section. - Finally you can still really enjoy the game without paying anything.MAIN ISSUE ABOUT THE GAME!- This is a real problem. You'll probably encounter many server disconnection at first due to your firewall or antivirus, so put them down or let the game go through your firewall. Once you've done it, it is fine. Although, many times the game freezes or disconnects because of the other player maybe, or I don't know why. But when you are in the middle of a rift run, which you are only allowed to loose 3 times, as soon as the game freezes, that's a loss. This is very frustrating and I hope that some kind of system will help recognise which player f***¨s the game up and let's the other safe.That's it. I have been playing for 10 days, love it and I want to keep playing. Haven't tried trading yet or ranked pvp but looking forward to discover more about this awesome game!

content:
Posted: July 18, 2015
												The game is fun but lack incentive to go on. I am really on the verge of uninstalling this game because there is nothing to do except play a normal match against other player and to gain level and eventually get booster packs. The main fun in this game is getting new cards and emplying those cards to play. But i am limited to the basic decks given after the opening mission and a few boosters. And the only way I see about getting more cards are 1. log in daily and get ONE card. Come on man. One card is not even worth the log in. And another by daily playing three matches. still not worth the log in. And level up which takes too long. It would take me years before I could get going with a deck beyond the basic core decks. Probably a decade to get the perfect deck. Why bother?  If you want to see a good marketing which build incentive for players go on see the game called "puzzle and dragons" in iOS. it the perfect model for getting ppl hooked.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								Oh man, what's with all the great CCGs lately?The obvious comparison is the other big F2P CCG, Hearthstone And I'd say that this... isn't as good. It lacks Hearthstone's puzzle element and simplicity, there's just not the same feeling of trying to predict and counter the opponent's strategy. The simultaneous turns helps with this a LITTLE bit, but it's just not good enough. Also, cards aren't as easy to come by without trading. And in comparison to Magic The Gathering it just doesn't have quite the same level of depth and option that MTG's massive amount of cards has.But I'd still put this as miles better than any other TCG! So yeah, I'd really recommend trying it out.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2015
												Downloaded and had a couple of days fun but this game, along with other card games (CCGs in particular) suffers from the fact that there are just too many cards in the card pool, which is a barrier to entry. I probably could have got into it when it came out but its just too much of a time investment to learn all the cards in the card pool before you can even begin to play properly. But hey cant complain about the few hours I got out of it for free. Just a warning for new players - Prepare to spend a lot of time grinding in order to even think about making a deck that isn't just a bunch of cards mishmashed together.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												I was very pleasantly surprised by this game! I was expecting something with boring minimal strategy like Hearthstone, but what I got is a system akin to Magic the Gathering; it's just as complex and engaging with a few of its own unique mechanics. I appreciated the tutorial battles, which had minimal hand-holding while still explaining everything very well. The few AI battles I’ve had outside the tutorial so far were challenging enough to be fun, but not so challenging that I felt like the AI was cheating. I look forward to learning more about the system and building my own decks!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 24, 2015
												Even if you're not a trading card game person like I wasn't, give this a try. I've played this a lot on and off for a couple years since when I've tried other TCGs such as Hearthstone too. And my final conclusion is that Inifity Wars is the best digital card game out there. Here's why:- F2P model is fine. Free cards every day you log on/Play you first few game/Complete Quests & Acheivements- Incredible art on the cards- Brilliant universe for the cards... it's creepy and enthralling with a great take on the undead- Final Fantasy grade soundtrack- The deepest strategy out of any TCG I've played by far- Simultaneous turns (Less waiting around and it allows for more complex strategies)- Wonderful, imaginative faction/classes which are MIXABLE in each deck you create.- Massive amount of cards and strategiesThe only cons that I can see really are:- Why isn't this game getting more attention?- Although the game itself is very tight, the program and gui itself could use a little work.- The menu system could be better, smoother and streamlined etc.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								Well there are some things the devs can do to improve this game! Namely separate the login server from the game servers. Hope they do get more servers. The lag now and at the release of the Infestation is unbearable. The draft freezing and never recovering is a common bug REAL BUG that requires a relog. But that should all be resolved soon! I would hope to see some more variable play in the bot decks. I would also like to see less distractions in the drafting - ie no relogs. In the draft there should be a way to see your cards. But zooming in on them in the battles is unneccessary. I'd like to see longer campaigns and more trading options. I really want to see more player communications in the drafting - at least hello and good game! But none of that will matter if they don't fix the lag issues.On the positive side this game really rocks! The game play is quite deep and really addictive.

												Downloaded and had a couple of days fun but this game, along with other card games (CCGs in particular) suffers from the fact that there are just too many cards in the card pool, which is a barrier to entry. But hey cant complain about the few hours I got out of it for free. Just a warning for new players - Prepare to spend a lot of time grinding in order to even think about making a deck that isn't just a bunch of cards mishmashed together.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												First of... What a unique new style of TCG and I love it.  The simultaneous play makes it so strategical as you discover the game that it's hard to stop trying out the various game styles.What about the price? I want to emphasis this because people always talk about 'pay 2 win' in these kind of games and it is logical that if you want many cards really fast, you'd have to spend a few dollars. Imagine if Magic Cards were all free. + there are many ways to get free boosters if you don't feel like spending right away. The price of a booster is as little as a dollar so nothing to complain about on this section. - Finally you can still really enjoy the game without paying anything.MAIN ISSUE ABOUT THE GAME!- This is a real problem. You'll probably encounter many server disconnection at first due to your firewall or antivirus, so put them down or let the game go through your firewall. Once you've done it, it is fine. Although, many times the game freezes or disconnects because of the other player maybe, or I don't know why. But when you are in the middle of a rift run, which you are only allowed to loose 3 times, as soon as the game freezes, that's a loss. This is very frustrating and I hope that some kind of system will help recognise which player f***¨s the game up and let's the other safe.That's it. I have been playing for 10 days, love it and I want to keep playing. Haven't tried trading yet or ranked pvp but looking forward to discover more about this awesome game!

content:
Posted: March 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								Oh man, what's with all the great CCGs lately?The obvious comparison is the other big F2P CCG, Hearthstone And I'd say that this... isn't as good. It lacks Hearthstone's puzzle element and simplicity, there's just not the same feeling of trying to predict and counter the opponent's strategy. The simultaneous turns helps with this a LITTLE bit, but it's just not good enough. Also, cards aren't as easy to come by without trading. And in comparison to Magic The Gathering it just doesn't have quite the same level of depth and option that MTG's massive amount of cards has.But I'd still put this as miles better than any other TCG! So yeah, I'd really recommend trying it out.

												The game is fun but lack incentive to go on. I am really on the verge of uninstalling this game because there is nothing to do except play a normal match against other player and to gain level and eventually get booster packs. Probably a decade to get the perfect deck. Why bother?  If you want to see a good marketing which build incentive for players go on see the game called "puzzle and dragons" in iOS. it the perfect model for getting ppl hooked.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
												For an online TCG, it's great. The best one I've played. I can't say much about it, cause it's pretty much just what you'd expect. MTG + Hearthstone = Infinity WarsPros: * Trading concept. Although you can't trade certain cards, you can still trade which is part of what makes a card game fun IMO.* There's a fair bit of helpful players in the community willing to help you.* It's got a good start for new players, IE, the pauper game mode to allow you to level up and not have to worry about the meta game.* You level up and get cards from fighting your friends, so, even if no one plays pauper, you still have your noob friends to farm on.Cons:* No one plays pauper.* If you want to get anywhere you have to play infinity. The downside to playing infinity, anything is allowed, which means all trump cards and meta game, so not easy for new players.* ♥♥♥♥ing zombie decks. Anyone who is new in these times apparently, have to wathc out for zombie decks. They are horrid, and they can't be stopped. I've tried so many different decks and I still can't beat anyone who uses zombies in their deck. ♥♥♥♥ zombies, they're overpowered. They're like MTGs black hydra decks. They power themselves up through the deaths of their own, and have other things from other deck types to power them up. Unstoppable. No not the card type, they're literally unstoppable.* The match ups in this game is just horrid. They pair you with a guy who's been playing for maybe a year even though you started yesterday, who the ♥♥♥♥ do you think is gonna win in that scenario?

content:
Posted: November 8, 2016
												Infinity Wars is the type of digital TCG that blows you away on many fronts.  It has many innovative features and in a lot of ways it is the best digital TCG out there (though it has some shortcomings).  Why do I believe this?-  All the cards have animated art!  Yep, you heard that right.  This gives the game an aesthetic value and beauty that is unmatched by most other digital tcg's.  Some of these cards have full animations!-  The tactical depth of this game blows away all other TCG's.   You have a support zone, assault zone, defense zone, and command zone.  It's easy to get used to and allows for a lot of tactical depth.  If Hearthstone is checkers, this is chess.-  The factions are cool, cards have a lot of flavor, there are custom battlegrounds, card backs, avatars, and card effects you can purchase.   But it is NOT pay to win.  You can unlock packs pretty easily without spending a dime; trust me, I didn't spend any money for a very long time.  But eventually I started to spend money on some of the preorders when new sets were released.   -  Yes, you can actually trade cards with other people so it is a true TCG.-  The draft format is fun and doesn't cost a lot of points.  And yes, you can buy in using Infinity Points that you earn in the game so once again - you don't have to spend money.-  There are ranking systems, prizes, etc.  Some of the Downfalls:-  It needs more players so I'm hoping this new release draws in a new audience.-  There were bugs from time to time in the past, though ever since a new company bought the game, I haven't run into any more bugs.  So this seems improved.Conclusion: This is an amazing game.  Play it, get a couple of your friends to play it, and help it blossom.  There is real potential here.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 9, 2016
												I've been playing for several years now, and I wanted to write an honest review, so here it is.tl;dR: skip to the Conclusion at the bottom.This game is an exceptionally good DTCG (Digital Trading Card Game), it kicks MtG and other cards games (Hstone) butt by far, which is saying a lot considering both those games are made by huge companies.OverviewThis is a Free game that manages to give a balanced and challenging experience while avoiding P2W (Pay to Win) altogether. It focus on strategy, anticipating your opponent's moves (thanks to simultaneos turns, see below), and its artistic aspect is excelent (all cards are fully animated).Pros:+ It's Free! You can play this game for free, or you can choose to spend some bucks in it to get more cards. Even if you don't want to spend real money, you can still get the same cards by playing and earning in-game free currency which will allow you to get boosters with more cards. You also get free cards almost daily.+ Real TCG. There's a reason TCG are called that way, Infinity Wars Reborn lets you trade your spare cards to get the ones you need, be it for building a better deck or just to complete your collection (there's a collectible aspect with premium cards that have platinum or gold borders, and foil effects).+ Simultaneos Turns: One of the strongest points of this game is simultaneos turns. Unlike MtG where you play, then your opponent plays, and so on, in Infinity Wars Reborn you both play and the turn resolves at the same time, so you need to try to anticipate if your opponent will attack, defend, use abilities, etc, which makes for some very interesting mind games, and actually requires skills, not just having 'good cards'.+ Animated cards! Each and every card is animated. I dare you to find another free online card game that offers you the same (100% animated cards). Not only that, the artwork is just amazing, professional artists work on this game and the quality is superb.+ Competitive, challenging and balanced gameplay. Infinity Wars Reborn has many factions you can play with, they are all balanced and they can all beat each other in many (I really mean it: many!) different ways. The amount of strategies and combinations is endless, and two people using the exact same deck can still use the cards in very different ways to win.+ Good starting card collection. When you make an account and start playing, after you go through the tutorials, you can play the Campaign, and you'll be rewarded with pre-made decks of each faction (WIP) after you complete each campaign. Not only that, you get a free 5-cards booster each time you level up. As if that wasn't enough, you can complete daily quests to get in-game currency (which you can spend to get more cards), and you also get a free daily reward just for logging in (cards from different rarities, XP boosters, and even 5-card boosters). It's incredible the amount of cards this game gives you for free.+ Store. When you play you win IP (Infinity Points), these is the free in-game currency which you can spend to get more cards. You can also spend real money if you want, either to get more cards or to dress up your battlefield and decks with beautiful artwork.Cons:- Some minor bugs that are still being worked on. Development is slow from time to time, but these guys aren't Wizards of the Coast or Blizzards, so it's to be expected.- Lacks proper marketing, this game is ideal for streaming and chilling, but somehow it's not that known (yet).- Addictive, you'll find yourself wanting to play moar and moar. You have been warned.Conclusion (rating: 8/10):If you like TCGs, if you have ever played MtG in real life and miss the feeling it gave you the first time you played it, then you need to try Infinity Wars Reborn. It's a rock-solid card game with beautiful artwork.

												Very good concept. Goes far and beyond with the strategic element of predicting and simultaneous turns [think a bit like competitive pokemon style]. Previously it's actually been pretty decent with around 8 top meta decks. Although they tend to revolve around 2-3 factions, all of the factions were included at least somewhat in the top meta decks. Caveat with that is, some factions require rarer cards [epics legendaries] to be more viable than other factions.Would recommend, but with a grain of salt:This game doesn't seem to be progressing very fast. Various bugs plague the interface while the new publisher for the game has been more active in stamping bugs out, it seems to still always be rather buggy.

content:
Posted: November 20, 2016
												IW:ATCG is the next step in strategic CCG's. They build upon previous popular CCG's so if you are new to the scene, it may be difficult to catch on. Hell, I've been playing MTG for years and I had a bit of trouble. While the verbage on the card is not always clear, there is a wiki on the different types that can help you get a grasp of the concepts. This is where experience comes in handy. There is also a twist on the "stack" that many MTG players are familiar with. While cards play out in order, any character cards placed in the way of the effects after the fact are affected. There is also the concept of "initiative," which begins randomly with either player and causes that players "stack" to resolve first. It's an interesting concept that creates a whole new dimension to gameplay and is used to develop strategies that would never be considered outside of this particular game. I enjoy the new rule and look forward to using it. However, the game still seems new. There are many details that could be worked out for rules and what is considered a "character." This is the verbage I was speaking about above. Sure there are more examples, but most can be worked out while playing the tutorial campaigns and there are sufficient AI's to test your decks prior to delving into PvP. IW:ATCG does have an arena style mode where you create a deck from random cards ala Hearthstone. I have yet to test those waters. Overall I think it could develop into something fun, and is already interesting. I look forward to playing more and will update my review accordingly.

												I have been playing this card game off and on for over a year I think. It started out just looking for something a little different from other card games. Saw this was free to play and bam! I got hooked to it. The fact that it has a single player and many different types of ways to play with other people. There is a cool campaign mode where you can play as a faction from anywhere between 4 to 6 missions. Each mission getting more difficult, to make you find combos and learn some important mechanics to the game that will help you play against other people. This also rewards you with free decks of cards. After you beat all the campaign you end up with a pretty decent card pool to make decks that you want to experiment with and play against other people. This game also has an group of advanced tutorials (aka Academy tab) where you learn some excellent strats to help you win future matches. I enjoyed this game so much i got a few family members to play it with me and they have really enjoyed it as well. It has a lot of different factions that each do something a little different or have completely different strats. The Community seems to be really awesome and helpful as well. It isn't toxic like a lot of other games I have played in the past. The only negatives I think I have about the game have to do with connection issues I've had personally lately. But the Studio behind the game is helping me to fix it. So give it a real shot, play more than 2 or 3 games and you will be hooked too.

number of helpful: 13 of 28 people (46%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 9, 2014
												Infinity Wars tries a lot of bold new things. Some of these succeed, while others do not.Firstly, and unfortunately most importantly, the game is genuinely free to play. It isn't Heartstone free to play, where non-paying players need to grind for years to accumulate the same quality of cards as someone who spends $1000. IW lives up to its name. A new player has the potential to build a competitive deck from just the cards he receives from the tutorial, and initial booster packs ('soulbound packs'). Those who choose to spend are able to gain platinum cards (just shiny), better artwork, sounds, effects, etc, and more cards to play with, BUT THESE CARDS ARE NOT NECESSARILY ANY BETTER. They are just more options to explore should you get bored of using the same, but highly effective, strategy every game. No cards are locked behind a pay-wall, although if you want to build a deck with 10+ legendaries in it (that is NOT NECESSARILY BETTER THAN A DECK WITH 0 LEGENDARIES), be prepared to pay or grind.There isn't much to say about the artworks or effects. If you like them, great. If not, you don't. There's no option to turn them off, but then again, we aren't playing Microsoft Excel.The community is also extremely active, for its size. It is certainly no Heartstone, which has the publishing collosus of Blizzard behind it, nor is it Yugioh, where even in my relatively small town there are frequently 20-30 player tournaments with prizes. The developers, too, are frequently active on the forums, and this game has been patched at once a month since I began to play. I say this with absolute confidence; if this game has a larger player base, it has the potential to lead the market with its innovation and new ideas.Why, then, do I NOT recommend this game for you?It's free, so there's no harm trying. But as you progress beyond Puffy the Fish and encounter more and more cards and combinations, you will realise one serious flaw in the game design. The devs have shown they are not a money laundering scheme, and genuinely wish to see this game develop into something for the gamers to enjoy. They design and maintain their game with all the best intentions, but unfortunately in this case it does not equate to results.Infinity Wars has a unique turn system unlike Heartstone, MTG, Yugioh, etc. I remember something similar in some Marvel DC comic card game ages ago, and that is that both players have their turns at the same time. Not only is this extremely confusing for new players (this, and the copious amount of addon-systems that are needed as a result, to determine things like card resolution order, etc), it is also fundamentally incompatible with their card design, which follows a far more traditional MTG/Yugioh approach.In short,  the cards for this game do not match the rules for this game. It is like eating Butter Chicken Flavoured Ice Cream, driving to work in a $2999 bottle of wine eating your favourite hamburger while diving into a beautiful coral reef. Oil and water don't mix. Or, for a more contextual example, like throwing a pokemon card into Yugioh. What are energies??? At best, this system leads to frustrating gameplay, where both players are reluctant to do anything out of fear, that they will incorrectly anticipate between two WHOLLY VALID courses of play and thus screw themselves over for the rest of the game. At worst, this creates massive imbalances in the game due to some cards being overpowered in the context in which they are placed. For example, 'draw 3 cards' is a common effect in pokemon. Put that card into yugioh, and it will completely break the game.The game has a great community, great ambitions and has the potential to change the face of TCG games. However, this is no easy task, and despite the best intentions of the DEVS, clearly indicated by the fact that the game is not pay to win, the gaping flaws in the game's current fundamental design will not allow it to provide a largely positive experience.

number of helpful: 9 of 20 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31, 2014
												Final Review 9/5/2014Honestly, I'd like to say that I had a whole bunch of information to drop upon IW's release, but I don't. Release for this game was not so much a bang but a very timid whimper. My honest opinion is that it felt rushed if solid, giving it a very mediocre launch.There are no big changes so I can't find my revised review changing all that much. Several much-needed card fixes were implemented, but that's not what should set a gold release apart. The truth is there's no point in adopting this game at all as it sits, if you played beta you're not missing anything. If you have to pick up this game might as well wait for 2015. That's when most of the launch features a TCG should have wil be implemented. The game is barebones at the moment. It didn't launch with any kind of card recycler or revamped rewards system. The developers think that's fine, I find it a grind. Even something as basic as a tournement mode didn't make it into release. The truth is they're still on a player-to-player system and, you guessed it, serverside matchmaking won't be making it until the year after release, and dysincronizations and endless turns are still very much a reality. Current plans for IW 2015 make this feel like Beta Mk 2 not Ver 1.0.I'm out of room. Can't recommend.Revised Review 5/5/2014----So, I decided to give the game a more in-depth review at the behest of some of the developers. My main review is mostly still intact, so I'll detail where it changes and my new experiences with a month worth of play. Despite what Steam says it's over 40 hours (I dont' play with Steam in online mode a lot). Like I said before the game has potential that's almost all it's working on. I saw that patch .96 was live so if convention is to be believed it's very close to release, so I don't buy that, "It's beta" excuse everyone from the developers to the community likes to foist on you. It's way too close to a 1.0 version for that to be a sufficient. Still, if you're a person who like to play games based on the promise of what they might be (a la Dwarf Fortress or something). I'm not really going to convince you. I'm here to report on what exists. I can't critique things that don't exist. The AI is horrible (They've "got plans"). I beat the most difficult AI routinely and draw it out if I'm lazy. I think I lost once to it because I wasn't paying attention. You can beat the AI with just about any deck you can put together. The campaign serves as less of a story and more as an extended tutorial to get you cards. The bugs and glitches are still pretty bad. At .96 you'd expect most of the core modes to be at least pretty solid, but Rift Run (there version of draft) didn't work right for about two weeks I was there. Every patch seemed to make the game worse. While they'd fix some things they'd introduce two issues for every issue they fixed. Some people tell me that's "how development goes" but I'll let you realize who paradoxical that is. Speaking more on the modes. Rift Run (again their Draft) is actually an exercise in how much money you're willing to pour into it (thankfully not real world money). At one-thousand Infinity Points (the free currency) it's actully quite cheap to at least make sure you have ideal commanders, cheapinging the spirit of the mode. The factions: The game is pretty strong, it still feels really random to me, but you learn a few tricks. It still does feel like you're throwing cards. One faction (their first post-core faction) is basically unplayable by itself and is generally in need of reowrking. It's been through one already. That gives me pause to invest in the next non-core release, Ascenscion.The only way to get free card packs after a while becomes leveling up. Which is fair. They don't have to give you free packs for everything. You get a few single cards for weekly quests and the fee card for your daily login and first three games of the day, which makes sure you get a card for participating, but the leveling up is purely geometric in scale (one more thousand exp to level up) in scale. You get one pack no matter how much it actually took to get to the next level. So the rewards remain the same while you're doing more work for the same thing. That naturally make leveling up a grind. If you're the kind of person who can do PVP all day long with no change then more power to you. If found the community by in large hostile if you didn't toe the general opinion. Any critique of the game is met with "It's in beta' again remember they're at version .96, that's almost release, or it's met without outright nastiness, which I suppose is just the nature of the beast when you're dealing with anything over the internet. The inablity to take and evaluate criticism is only going to hurt the game in  the long run. They'll probably say bad things about me, but I don't really care. There are a few other small issues that give me pause to invest anymore time into the game. A sale was held on a deck recently. The sale was in LP (Lightmare Points the real-money currency) and not Infinity Points. I asked around and that wasn't something done before with both currencies being slashed for the sale. That smacks of riding the P2W line. So be careful if you do decide to adopt this game. All in all, I still cannot recommend this game. It's an okay TCG and it's probably the best F2P digital traiding card game I've played recently, but remember that the lesser of two evils is still evil. These are my opinions, but I did not enjoy the first time I played it, and I did not enjoy the month I spent for this review. There came a point where I wanted it to succeed, but if I'm going to play a game I don't want to feel like I'm just hitting my head against a wall, which is exactly what Infinity Wars feels like, except the wall has spikes. I'll be making a final review when it hits release. Though my expectations are markedly low.----While this game has a lot of potential it falls down in a few key areas one would expect a trading-card game to flourish in. Turn length is painfully long and busy, and their are far too many mechanics to keep in mind as you play. Including what order your creature cards are in and where they are on the zone. While the simultaneous turn mechanic might seem like it speeds up gameplay the uneeded general complexity of the game at large keeps it from being effective. Also, the simultaneous turn resolution (though there is initiative to keep in mind as well) gives the game a painfully random element beyond simple luck of the draw. It felt more like I was throwing cards at a brick wall and seeing wich ones took rather than leading an army in a grand strategic victory. Instead of skillful counters and repostes it feels more like you're constantly punching in the dark at one another. In this regard the mechanics of the game shine a light on a dominant strategy that shouldn't be so dominantly effective in this genre as to be the go-to strategy: The rush. Rush decks are the majoiry and the game tends to punish slightly slower than rush decks. It makes the game feel stale and samey. That being said collecting cards is fun, and the game does offer up many rewards. If you can get past the cumbersome mechanics progress feels nice. The cards are animated with looping gif-like pictures on each and every card which is pretty, but also fees gimicky. Battles aren't fought in any cenematic way. Cards bump into each other doing their damage. The factions are fairly distinct and the art is nice with shades of Warhammer 40K in a blend of sci-fi-coated fantasy. The game is in beta now, but as a representation of what we can expect it leaves a lot to be desired. The lovely if pointless card animations and promise of what are supposed to represent battlefield style engagements are marred by stilted and random mechanics. There are no doubt better card battle games one could be playing.

number of helpful: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2014
												At this time, I just cant give this game a thumbs up.  Between the account creation issues everyone is experiencing, and the actual gameplay itself..  it's just not worth it.First, the gameplay itself..  it's ok, but it's SERIOUSLY flawed.  The game has no built in "counter" system.  This is rather hard to explain, but the BEST way I can describe it is by telling people to imagine the old Super Nintendo Mario Kart vs a Friend.. the first one to get smacked by a power up... lost.  It's the same here.  The first player to plop out a stupid amount of 10/10+ creatures in rapid succession ... wins.  Period.  There's nothing  you can do about it.  Decks are 1 dimensional this way as well, as there is no point trying to get creative.. just create dozens of mega creatures (Which ANYONE can do... even with the worst possible deck.) and swarm the opponent.  Honestly, it's hard to describe properly unless you experience it for yourself.Now, in OTHER cardgames, the Matchmaking system will provide a check and balance to this..  not here.  First, you wait an average of 10+ minutes for a single game.. and then it  pairs you (just starting out..) against a guy who's spend $4-500 in cards.  You get smashed in 4 turns.. (about 3-5 minutes.) back into the que for another 10+ minutes.  Repeat.  In fact, in the 8 hours I have played.. I have not played a single other "newbie" player.  Just people with a bunch of gold medals, custom avatars, custom cardbacks, custom battlefields and decks full of Rare powerful cards.  It's INCREDIBLY frustrating, and basically forces you to flush MASSIVE amounts of money to compete.  (Which yes, of course, is a staple to any cardgame.. but here they practically wave a banner at you screaming "BUY CARDS OR YOU'LL NEVER ENJOY THE GAME HAHAHAHAHA!)  The matchmaker woes continued for me as I played the SAME player 4 GAMES in a row.  ..  well.. it TRIED to anyways.. after he completely stomped me in 4 turns the first go round, I didnt waste my time on subsequent attempts, just immediately quit out.  This game, while cute for a VERY short time.. just isnt worth a long term investment.5/10

content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
A polished card game that is lacking depthThis is more of an initial review, as i decided to try this game out as it looks great visually.This is how the game is played:Each card has a certain amount of points it needs to be played, and each turn you get one more point than the last turn. For most cards you have to wait until your next turn after playing it before you can place them on the "battlefield". So basically... you put down all the cards you can each turn, and then put them all in the attack zone, and then hope your units are stronger than whatever units your oppenent has.There is "a little" strategy as you can move your cards around so that someone with a large amount of hitpoints gets attacked first, or perhaps you can sacrifice someone with low hitpoints so that your stronger units take less damage.------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------So basically.... it's a game of "who has stronger cards wins" and it's very hard to recover if you start to fall behind...In a way it reminds me of old-yu-gi-oh, where you place all your cards in attack position and just overpower your opponent. However, in YuGiOh you at least have plenty of other cards that can counter this style of play, but this game feels a bit mindless. --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Things I did like though:+ Animated Cards are a nice touch and bring cards to life+ Visually the game looks great in all aspectsThings I did not like:- Story is awful, and is very hard to follow what is happening- Voice Acting- Not enough depth in the card-game- Lots of Microtransactions everywhere you look(I did not play this game very long so take it with a grain of salt)

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												Will keep the review basic and since it's F2P, you can give it a go yourself to check whether the game suits you. This game is not very well balanced, more a Pay To Win, and I have played other games, like Magic The Gathering and Might & Magic: Duel of the Champions and there new player actually has some chances to win in PvP. This coupled with slow game look up process makes me want to switch to other games rather than spending time waiting for game to start only to get some experienced PVP opponent with deck that kills me in sometimes even less than game start waiting time (not sure if the player base is so small or whatelse..)Pros:- Nice graphic- Animated cards- Variety of cards and sides you can take on (each having it's own weaknesses and advantages)- Many campaigns (and you can get some free decks by doing them)- In-game challenges & achievements (who doesn't like them)- Background story- Rift Run - seems to be interesting concept. Played only once, but that seemed to be giving some chances to new players (considering you can pay the entry fee that is). It does make you draft your deck from random cards, so you don't have to have them yourself.Cons:- Slow PVP matchmaking - on average it takes couple of minutes to find a game. Not once, I was able to get myself some coffee or even eat something while waiting for game to start and when returning, it was still trying to lookup.- Bad matchmaking - in 9 out of 10 cases I have been playing opponents with lots of gold or higher medals on profile, meaning they did spend a looot of time in PVP (and the game) polishing their decks and getting lots of cards- Pay to win - some say you can get cards - sure, you can get. It's a slow process though and you have to play really a lot of games to get some. Mainly you get them by playing campaigns, and that's the easy part, but you don't get anything too fancy. Sure, you get also in-game money, but it trickles like from closed but leaking tap and again, play A LOT and you can eventually get few cards - still though, if you want to go PVP, you better consider spending some money to get better cards.- Still has bugs - didn't see anything major, more like a cosmetic and graphical mainly on claiming rewards where you may need to claim same twice or the interfaces are overlapping (reward claim interface with others)All in all, over Infinity Wars I would much more prefer for example Duel of Champions where matchmaking is way better and some seasonal player can actually get chances to win without spending real world money and get some fun rather than just waiting to be pwned. If you're only going to play Infinity Wars occassionally, then rather look for an alternative.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								It's no Magic: The Gathering, but Infinity Wars is a solid, free-to-play digital TCG. Being digital does allow Infinity Wars to do some pretty cool things that aren't possible with physical TCG's - like simultaneous turns and actively creating cards during gameplay. The simultaneous turn system adds an interesting, poker-esqe level of strategy. It allows you to guess, or force, your opponent's moves rather than simply react to them. There are several factions from which to build decks, but each faction seems so lazer-focused on a single mechanic that there is little room for building a "unique" deck. This will probably improve as cards are added over time, and it doesn't keep the game from being fun in the meantime.

content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												Time ago I was about to try the game, then I read the various negative reviews and disinstalled it before trying because they claimed it was a PTW and unplayable for new players, so I tried other tcg. I was an avid Hearthstone player and tried Hex and Magic. Well, after a while I tried anyway IW because I wanted to give it a try. Well, it was a blast. NOTHING of what those reviews said was true after trying the game. I don't know if they changed something, but it's just a week I play and I have 400+ cards just by playing the campaign and logging in.I receive free cards every day for logging and another for playing 3 games in any mode.Plus I can even sometime win against ranked veterans with just a week of playing under my hood. Granted there are great decks and players out there that can blast me away, but is more a matter of experience and missing maybe some card here and there.Plus there is the fact you can even play legendary free decks that they put up every week on rotation, and even if you don't have enough cards those decks are good and also train you to new strategies and combos and explain you new cards.So, don't let those old negative reviews discourage you, the game is completely playable FOR FREE, and you can become pretty competitive given a bit of time (not too much too!).The game is fun also, very interesting factions and strategies, different ways to win, a lot of sinergies and different decks variants.I played Hearthstone, Hex, magic and none stands up to IW.Try it for a week, then decide!

Posted: November 17, 2014
												One of the best out there with nearly unlimited deck building options, and most importantly a good player base that never takes more than a few seconds to grab a live match. AI is pretty good for Easy mode even if its kinda derpy at times. Can't wait to see the harder modes unlocked. Already some skill out there too, good players and new alike, matchmaking seems to be good too. Campaigns and leveling gives all kinds of booster packs as you progress so free to play is certainly true. Though (as with most all tcg) you can pay your way to a better deck it really doesn't do more than give you a head start as all cards are freely obtainable (all level reward packs are random boosters), and having a bunch of good cards will never guarantee victory with this game. True TCG where tactics reign. Good luck to any wanting to try it out, don't wait its definitely worth it.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 5, 2016
												A Wonderful Card game. Recently a friend and I were reminiscing in all the old card games we used to play. So we decided we wanted to play a new trade card game but we didn't have much luck on finding any old games online such as Yu-Gi-Oh and other card games we grew up playing. So I decided to search on steam and found this game. The game is great but there a few connection bugs I have come across in my time playing. The campaign was really fun and was a great way to do a tutorial. After playing through the campaign/campaigns I knew exactly how to play and how I wanted to play. I would like the campaign to be added onto however. There was not  much backstory on the factions and I would love to induldge into their lore/history.The game is fairly simple, there is a defending side and an attacking side. Place you cards in either zone to try to win. However it's not always a case of whoever has the stronger cards wins. I mainly use Verore characters and my friend mainly uses the zombie ones (I forget the name at this time). He gets his power from reviving dead cards. I get my power by killing his cards. We cancel each other out and have lost track of time in one game. Yesterday we started a game at 1:00AM and  finished at 3:00 AMI definetly recommed this game to anyone who likes TCG, or are looking to bring back the fun they had when they were younger with TCGs.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								Putting a fresh spin on card games in a digital format is difficult.  Getting beyond the set standards and being successful in a genre that has been dominated by a single entity for years even more so.  But what Infinity Wars does great isn't beating anyone, but offering a new, fresh perspective in a universe filled with enough lore to write a full book series.  The stories of the factions are rich, they each have their own unique play style, and game mechanics offer a new look at card game strategy that you wouldn't see anywhere else.  This may just be a beta, but I constantly find myself saying "One more game" far beyond the point that I should have gone to bed.  A truly amazing experience, and definitely a highly recommended one.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								Putting a fresh spin on card games in a digital format is difficult.  Getting beyond the set standards and being successful in a genre that has been dominated by a single entity for years even more so.  But what Infinity Wars does great isn't beating anyone, but offering a new, fresh perspective in a universe filled with enough lore to write a full book series.  The stories of the factions are rich, they each have their own unique play style, and game mechanics offer a new look at card game strategy that you wouldn't see anywhere else.  This may just be a beta, but I constantly find myself saying "One more game" far beyond the point that I should have gone to bed.  A truly amazing experience, and definitely a highly recommended one.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								This the future of TCGs, A trading card game that is able to bring new elements never seen before on other carg games. It is not a MTG clone , nor a clone of TCGs / CCGs you might find elsewhere on Itunes store or android. Infinity wars has an unique battle system where you have several zones that must be used in harmony: attack zone , defence zone , support zone and commander zone ( kinda like the commander in MTG commander style , but a bit different ). I highly recommend for everyone that loves card games to check this one out !  Despite it being still be a beta and be a game by a small team IW is unique and already very playble and enjoyable ! ! !

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								If you're into ATCG's, then you'll love Infinity Wars! It has a a small learning curve which is great for newcomers,  and overall is very balanced! The game is still in beta, and therefore has slight matchmaking issues and other network bugs, but it still makes for a great game. The tutorial is very short and fluid, so you'll be diving into the core game very quickly. Also, once you start leveling and opening booster packs, you won't be able to stop! Also- Microtransactions. Yes, they are present, but they aren't even close to the gamebreaking micro transactions that EA and King put out. They merely offer cosmetic changes, as well as a faster way to purchase more booster packs/decks (which are already available through the game's in-game cash). Infinity Wars will also have a mobile game dropping later this year for Android and iOS devices, be it a phone OR a tablet! With the few minor matchmaking glitches and bugs, this game still deserves an easy 8/10!

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								First I'll start with the good qualities of the game.It's a fairly easy game to pick up and very easy to construct a deck to play with. 40 cards is the minimum.You get to choose 3 commanders - these are creature cards that start in a special section of the board called commanders and their abilites can be used at the offset but if you want them in battle you still have to pay the cast cost to get them out. It's fairly easy to get booster packs without actually having to pay anything. All you have to do is complete achievements and earn the ingame currency. Since you earn every time you win a battle (you earn in PVP even if you lose) it is easy to just keep buying boosters until you get the cards you want.The bad side?There are some bugs that prevent a game from completing (rarely).The matchmaking can be a little daunting but I think this may be because of the lack of players.All up, a great card game that is an enjoyable alternative to MTG with some surprises.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								Infinity Wars is a "trading card" game much like Magic where players face off against each other using creatures, abilities and strategy to bring down either a player's morale or fortress strength. With many gameplay options including campaign and PvP you can be playing for hours on end without realising it. With each achievement and level up you are rewarded with a random booster pack of cards which can be used to build your own deck combinations. However, PvP can be somewhat unfair with a chance of your first game being against someone at ANY level for example a level 20 vs a level 5. I would recommend Infinity Wars to people who like trading card games and don't care too much about being pitted against someone 2, 3 maybe even 4 times your level.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								Infinity Wars (IW) - is a great dCCG! I found it quite innovative in comparison to more traditional collectiable card games (such as Magic The Gathering, HEX, Shadow Era and others). In addition to different strategies thinking it also makes you think of bluffing and assuming your opponents moves in planning phase as a turn actions then resolve simultaneously. It's easier to see how it plays or try it by yourself then to describe it!A great art, animated cards makes this game highly enjoyable!Also a lot of game modes available: Academy (which learns you the basics and more advanced rules of the game), campaign (8 missions per each faction) rewarding you with starter decks and even more cards, AI battles and different PVP modes, quest system also rewards you for your in game progress!Though IW still in beta, the game is still under constant development and sometimes some bugs could occur and some issues in the game could be noticed (For me the UI should be more user friendly for example). But I am sure it will become better and better.Really waiting this game to be released for mobile devices (iOS, Android) so could play it when not at home.As a conclusion, this title has a great potential and I could recommend it for every TCG player.

content:
Posted: April 15, 2015
												I find this game very fast fun with very interesting decisions to make durring play and deck building. You can assign 3 cards as  your commander which determine your faction. You can assign commanders with a focus on using there utility, or intending to deploy them as threats. 8 factions allow 512 different faction combinations. Picking more factions allow for a increased varity of the card pool but picking the same faction multiple times allows you to get cards to focus more heavily on a factoins tactic.Durring play you have to position your characters accordingling in the correct order to best combat what you predict the oppoment will do. Positioning wrong can result in you just throwing your characters

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												I have to say, this game is genius. It manages to utilise the digital medium to a large extent to do what physical card games cannot, such as simultaneous turns. Game balance is pretty good as well.The game is not pay-to-win, given the large amount of ways one can earn the in-game currency, and the amount of free card drops they give. Additionally, the quality of a card does not scale with rarity; you could win as easily with a deck made without Epics and Legendaries, as a deck filled with them.Instead of a crafting system, it has a trading system, which in some ways is better than the former. The majority of the community is quite friendly, so feel free to ask if anyone has any spare cards willing to donate.The 2 main issues are the tendency for bugs to pop up now and then, although the devs are working harder in preventing the game from becoming unplayable, and the relatively small player base, because unfortunately Hearthstone came out at around the same time, and Lightmare didnt do much marketing. Players are steadily increasing though.10/10

content:
Posted: January 21
												The game has some very interesting ideas; with the three (4 if you count command) different zones to play around and move your characters. However, in practice this often just equates to a massive guessing game that makes the whole thing feel more like luck than actual skill. In addition, there are several cards that once they hit the board are basiclly an auto win. Once such noteable card it the zombie city that makes it so that when an undead kills a creature that creature is brought back under your control as an undead and the cycle repeats. Combine that with the lack of good non-creature removal and the game often is just not fun and unfair.

								Compairing this to Yugioh or Magic or Toontown trading cards, it's an alright card game. When I was at a con recently I saw yugioh players. It was a 14 playing against a 47 year old. I was able to obtain a deck of my own. But later I mixed my Yugi stuff with my nazi stuff resulting in an honorable sacrafice to the god John Wood. I decided to play this game because of how digital it is. After 2 games, I was MLG and got a triple kill. I got on an MLG team and are first game is tonight in an alley on main street. Hope I win.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												This is an excellent trading card game.  The free-to-play works well; I've been tempted to buy cards, but I can play Draft as much as I like without spending money, and there are other modes (Merged and Pauper) that exist to help newbies be competitive without having great cards.  I win reasonably often in the unrestricted mode, especially now that I've completed the (rather enjoyable) single-player campaign.If you've ever enjoyed a trading card game, you should try Infinity Wars.

												This game mixes a lot of the card games together. Other people have done well giving a good overview so I'm skipping that. ;)  It's a fun card game to play, the in game currency like any other game of it's type is difficult to obtain so expect to be playing for a week to buy something but I've found the default cards you win are enough to make clever decks. All in all I would give it 9/10 it loses 1 point for shortness of PVE content. It could be expanded there 10x over and make it a much better experience imo. content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												As i now have about 300+ Hours on this, I'd Like to explain why.This is the most Balanced card game I've ever seen. It has an incredably Smart resource system: you start with 1, gain 1 per turn until 10, and spend 9 to increase it by one, or use a character card who affects are only active until they die.Cards have different abilitys, such as charge, vigulance, haste, and meny others. But the Main one is Flying. Flying characters, unless defending, cand only be blocked be other flying characters or characters with reach.A deck has 3 commanders, Each belonging to a Faction with a certain purity (Single, Double, Triple, Dual (2 Factions) and Hybrid (Either of two factions)) of that faction. Each deck, as you may guess, has 3 puritys, and they all can be the same faction or 3 different factions. A deck can only have cards of the Commander's Purity. And Each faction has it own benifits and downsides. Also, Each faction has an unlimited Card (A card that you can have unlimitly in a deck.) Now to talk about them:1. Warpath: Coming from the untamed world, they are mostly made up of various creatures of the wild. It was a natural Ecosystem watched over by the Immortal Aleta, One of the two humans left after the calamity, until the rifts opened and Atlas and the Flame Dawn Came and Started ♥♥♥♥ing♥♥♥♥♥♥up. So they were forced it Fight Together against them, and the other factions that come through, Espesialy the Sleepers.Warpath is a Late-Game Faction, it's cards cost lots of resources, but are also very powerful. They're very good at taking out flying units. The unlimited character of this faction is the one of many, a wolf/lion thing.2. Genesis Industrys: Hailing from Talich, the same realm as the Flame Dawn, they are Very Technologicaly Advanced, And have Robots do most of the fighting and work. It was an Ally of the Flame dawn in their conquest of Talich, until they turned on them. They fought until the rift to the untamed world opened. Then they teamed up again to fight the Warpath and then the Sleepers. Then the Overseers Came along and intended to destroy all traces of the sleepers, including anyone who was infected. Genesis didnt want their infected slaghtered, but the Flame Dawn Teamed up with the Overseers, and now they're fighting both forces.Genesis is a build up faction. It has lots of varying cards of Cost and strength, but canpower up any card to be more powerful. Has lots of weak flying units. The unlimited character of this faction is the Unending Drone.3. Venore:-Will Add more when I have time.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												This and Solforge are probably the two best collectible card games out there. Having simultanous turns is a sweet concept that is executed very well and leads to a lot of interesting decisions and mind games. Lots of potential there. It's free to play and the initial campaign is short, so giving the game a try is a good idea. During the campaign you already earn a good amount of cards that go towards various starter decks, jumping off from there is easy.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								Infinity Wars is my first trading card game and also my first free to play game on Steam. If you are new to either of these type of games then this game makes a good start.The game is not to complicated however some cards can be a little cryptic to understand. But with a little experience you will understand what they actually do quickly.The game board graphics are very simple but do look good. I have noticed that when using a location card, sometimes your other cards do get concealed by the graphics of your location on the board. I am sure this is just a bug and will be fixed by the time the game is out of it BETA phase. The illustration graphic of the animated cards are specially good. Of course some are better than others.The sound in the game, again is very simple but OK. This is a game were sound is not important. I play with the sound off not because it is bad, I just don't require it in the game. The sound effects do not effect the game play what so ever.Now for the free to play issue. It is possible to play this game without paying a penny however you will need patience. There are many opportunity to collect cards in game without buying them. There are many rewards for completing campaign stages and there is a daily and 3/4 day challenges to increase your card collection. There is also in game credit system to accumulate as you play to buy more cards. I have manage to get quite far by just buying the starter deck which is advised but not essential and one pre-ordered Infestation deck.This card game makes a good side game to play while playing other games. If you do decide to go hardcore on this game then like any other free to play games it become a pay to win game and can get expensive. I don't find this game addictive but it is enjoyable to play for a good few rounds.
