content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												As i now have about 300+ Hours on this, I'd Like to explain why.This is the most Balanced card game I've ever seen. It has an incredably Smart resource system: you start with 1, gain 1 per turn until 10, and spend 9 to increase it by one, or use a character card who affects are only active until they die.Cards have different abilitys, such as charge, vigulance, haste, and meny others. But the Main one is Flying. Flying characters, unless defending, cand only be blocked be other flying characters or characters with reach.A deck has 3 commanders, Each belonging to a Faction with a certain purity (Single, Double, Triple, Dual (2 Factions) and Hybrid (Either of two factions)) of that faction. Each deck, as you may guess, has 3 puritys, and they all can be the same faction or 3 different factions. A deck can only have cards of the Commander's Purity. And Each faction has it own benifits and downsides. Also, Each faction has an unlimited Card (A card that you can have unlimitly in a deck.) Now to talk about them:1. Warpath: Coming from the untamed world, they are mostly made up of various creatures of the wild. It was a natural Ecosystem watched over by the Immortal Aleta, One of the two humans left after the calamity, until the rifts opened and Atlas and the Flame Dawn Came and Started ♥♥♥♥ing♥♥♥♥♥♥up. So they were forced it Fight Together against them, and the other factions that come through, Espesialy the Sleepers.Warpath is a Late-Game Faction, it's cards cost lots of resources, but are also very powerful. They're very good at taking out flying units. The unlimited character of this faction is the one of many, a wolf/lion thing.2. Genesis Industrys: Hailing from Talich, the same realm as the Flame Dawn, they are Very Technologicaly Advanced, And have Robots do most of the fighting and work. It was an Ally of the Flame dawn in their conquest of Talich, until they turned on them. They fought until the rift to the untamed world opened. Then they teamed up again to fight the Warpath and then the Sleepers. Then the Overseers Came along and intended to destroy all traces of the sleepers, including anyone who was infected. Genesis didnt want their infected slaghtered, but the Flame Dawn Teamed up with the Overseers, and now they're fighting both forces.Genesis is a build up faction. It has lots of varying cards of Cost and strength, but canpower up any card to be more powerful. Has lots of weak flying units. The unlimited character of this faction is the Unending Drone.3. Venore:-Will Add more when I have time.

content:
Posted: May 16, 2016
												Basic TCG, but can shift cards between defense and offense -- two battle fields.  Cards that would have "summoning sickness" go to support field and can only be attacked by spells or other special cards.  They can stay there, ramping up based on other events (other games accomplish this with stealth cards, but in this case, it applies to all cards).Also dividing field between support and offense is a good way to visualize "summoning sickness."  Didn't play very far, but interesting as far as I got.  Out of courtesy to developer, rating up.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
												The game is just a blast.  Factions are balanced and the card animations are a mildly entertaining Gimmick.   If you're a CCG player, you'll have a blast with this game.Summary:  Game is fun, there's a good number of different rulesets, and the cards/abilities are different from other card games I've played.Pros:--A refreshing challenge for a CCG (collectible card game) vet.--Balanced play, a fair system of resource generation that doesn't feel pay-to-win (which is surprising considering most other card games are totally P2W when you think about it).--Earning points is slow if you're not buying points, but it feels REALLY good to unlock a deck you earned.--Varied Game types that aren't locked at any level, but may take time to build up to.--Random shuffle programming they use is more random than fricking Magic The Gathering 2014.--I loved the mix deck matches when I started because it shuffles both your decks together.  So you get to play with their more varied cards and your own (also, it requires more thinking on your feet with the cards you get).--Constructed deck matches are really interesting too.  I suggest looking it up on youtube or try it after you download the game (practice mode).Cons:--Some people quit when they start to lose, but they quit by dodging rather than concedeing.   You still get the win and they still get the loss, but you have to wait 1 minute because it treats the quit like a disconnect.  Can be annoying.--It can be frustrating playing ranked matches because people frequently try to bum-rush you with death by speed rather than have a fun / drawn out game.   Just prepare yourself to fight for your life in the first 8 turns.--Finding a late night match tends to pit you against some crazy pros in the game.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								The game is definitely fun and has some good mechanics going for it, but digital ccg developers have a really ridiculous antiquated view on pricing structures. It's a good game, it's just not worth spending the type of money they want for it. I've read the asinine rebuttal from the developers on the forums about how people are just getting sticker shocked because the game doesn't have all the rewards in place.No. That's not it. It's that when someone makes a CCG, they somehow think that there's a standard and acceptable pricing structure and that they should be able to get people to pay like people have paid for MTG/Pokemon/Yugioh. Sorry, you're not those games, the only reason those games can even charge what they do is because they've been around for ages.So, while this game is good and I highly recommend a play through of the campaigns and running some drafts with the free currency, this game does not understand opportunity cost. $50 for 20 packs when there's 3 sets - You can buy multiple full games for that amount, why spend that money on a handful of cards, getting duplicates, not having the cards to play what you want to play, and then playing with your lame deck using their terrible matchmaking which pits you against people who are way ahead of you in terms of card collection.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												This is what Free to Play should be!  10/10To many, Free to Play games are a nasty affair.  Constantly forcing you to pay to keep playing, or wait for a timer.  Maybe making it nearly impossible to get anywhere without spending your money on single use macguffins.  Or worst of all, locking large portions of gameplay behind the dreaded pay wall.  Infinity Wars does none of those things!  Sure you can drop some cash to unlock some cosmetic options, or decks of cards, or booster packs.  But you never feel like you HAVE to, and for the most part, you can earn enough in-game currency to purchase them through normal gameplay.The team at Lightmare do it right.  Regular patches, content add ons, and updates, all without nickle and dimeing you every step of the way.  Along with a dedicated community, all working together to make Infinity Wars the best it can be.  What's not to love?

content:
Posted: March 9, 2015
												This is a fantastic deck building and card battle game.  The campaign is quite long and contains unique battle setups, decks, and comes with a little bit of story.  It has a great tutorial and a selection of puzzle battles to test your understanding of the game.  PVP modes include standard deck battles and a deck random draft mode where you play until you get 3 losses.  After finishing the campaign, training, and leveling up to 9 I had enough card to build a few decks.  You can earn enough cards to at least mess around with friends just by playing the game.  It feels like a supremely fair and respectable free-to-play model.

content:
Posted: September 4, 2015
												A good, deep, tactical card game,Not really a trading card game thoughTL:DR - I like it, worth playing, but a pretty stiff learning curve once you play vs. others.the long-  it's difficult, I'm at 60 hours about, and level 13I have with a little grinding, getting my♥♥♥♥♥kicked, some incredible♥♥♥♥♥kicking actually under 10 turn losses.BUTI now have a few decent decks, I did pay about 3 us dollars to get some more cards.But even so I have honestly made my winning decks through playing.When I first started playing the matchmaker was pretty broken, I think it was because there were not always newer players on all the time, I used to get matched to real terryifying opponents early on.I stuck it out thoughNow I feel that I feel comfortable with the matchmaking, it has improved a great deal.New rewards systems, that give boosts, and card packs just for logging in and playing daily.I think it will help get some fresh blood into the scene, The games mechanics are deep, and each race/deck can be customized, mixed, or take on a wide range of play styles.Aggro, Defensive, Juggernauts, Boost, magic...+++, all different play styles are here, Players really weild some wild, and effective decks using all manner of dirty rotten wish I'd thought of that kind of♥♥♥♥♥♥The animated card backs also add a nice punch, the art style is original, and I really enjoy the musicFor a casual player this game may not be for them, hearthstone is more forgiving and easier to play(the only other TCG game i'd really played on pc)Infity wars is good, even great has its problems, but for a free game, thats honestly free I love it.Hands down worth learning and playing.Its filled a big gap in my travel/down time

content:
Posted: November 11, 2016
												By far the best TCG I've played in years, Infinity Wars brings something to the table that many other card games fail to deliver on. It has an interesting universe it plays in, it's well balanced and most importantly, it's fun.The game is a mix of different elements you've seen from various other TCGs, it has factions akin to Magic, but it plays out uniquely, the resource system is very much like Hearthstone, however I believe this was a decision consciously made before development, and not copied from Hearthstone, like in many other games.I'm not going to go into detail about much of how the game plays, as you can find that out faster by yourself, but just know that this game does have it's fair share of bugs at the moment, none of which are game breaking, but they do impact some of your games. On the same note I'd like to address that the devs know about this, and are hard at work when it comes to fixing these. Many have already been fixed over the years, it's only a matter of time until they get the rest.Essentially, if you want a unique TCG experience unlike anything you've ever played, give this game a try.

number of helpful: 13 of 29 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								For those looking for a good online trading card game, this might be it, BUT NOT YET.  The game currently has a crippling desynchronization bug with no fix in sight ('being worked on'), that happens as frequently as every other game and is widespread (both constructed and paid drafts). I would advise anyone to try it and make sure stability issues are worked out before putting any real money in.The free campaign gives you decks in each faction. quests and a daily login bonus, but all completely NON tradable. So if you are looking just to casually play without putting money or trading with decks that'll get beaten by anyone, you'll do fine.There's a pretty nifty 'merged deck' feature that combines your opponent's deck with yours with two results: it gives you access to any of their unbalanced cards but it blows any synergy you have as you will now get your draws 50% less than you would normally.As far as free to play:  You can earn a 15 card pack with one rare in about 50 games played, with currently no daily cap.  Those cards are tradable, which leads to another big issue.  The game ACTIVELY encourages third party sites for selling cards, and people have been in for many, many months.  It's very easy to buy a deck that you'll have no chance against from those sites (and if there is any sort of ELO for non-ranked, I haven't seen it).The arena version ('rifts') has a no pay alternative which has no rewards, which is great for beginners.  You can literally just practice drafting and not play, over and over again which is definitely unique and new-user friendly (and no desyncs).  However, the competive draft, while being low on cost, suffers from the crippling desyncs mentioned above.  So in the middle of a game that you're winning, you'll think your opponent is slow, and then time ends and the turns don't go, another loss.The production values are top notch, and it's certainly more complex (in a good way) than some other card games, but the complexity ultimately boils down to 'Did I swap between my attackers and defenders while my opponent did not' sort of thing. The factions have not been balanced yet.All in all, I'd wait a while until things are stable before putting any money in.

number of helpful: 10 of 23 people (43%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												I think people are very upset because they don't accept losing. They can't fathom the fact that they spent hours, if not days, planning their starter decks with a few boosters for the perfect play and still lose. (Read the most helpful review, the dude lost because his opponent outplayed him so he posted a Negative review lmao!)I've not once ever seen a paper TCG/CCG that you can't get s**t on for playing basic, common, starter-deck, builds. All the way from Magic to Yugioh to Pokemon. If you didn't expand your deck and you build strategies, people will take advantage of that and beat you. Starter decks are literally what they say, it's just that start. They aren't meant to be the most optimal decks straight from that bat that beats everything else with a few clever moves. Building successful paper decks have always taken a great amount of time, energy, and sometimes even money. People love to be hand-held through every game now a days. They rely on streamers and youtube to actually enjoy a game, but they have no idea how much fun everything was when none of that stuff existed and you had to travel out of your computer seat and search for those NEW cards. Sometimes even get in your car and drive for an hour to a tournament to see those cards you've never heard of before because your friends or yourself have never picked them up from boosters. It was all part of the adventure and charm of these games.I truly do enjoy the game even when I get my butt handed to me because it's a learning experience. Each time I lose to an opponent, I learn how to counter them a little bit better. I learn the pacing and when I finally do get those cards I want/need, I will have everything in my wits to beat them and man is it rewarding as heck when you do.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2016
												Summary: Very clunky and unintuative. Might be good, might not be,  but I could not figure out enough to find out.Review: Really unimpressed. I saw that the game had pretty much all good reviews, so I decided to try it, even though I don't generally like this kind of game.Played the first couple of missions. REALLY boring stuff. I imagine that it's only the tutorial, but still. At this point I got a couple of packs. I was like ok... now it gets interesting. So I went to go make a deck. This is where I got really disillusioned. I could not make heads or tails of the deck making area. One or two of the factions available seemed to have thier icons off the side of my screen. The game showed me every card in the game whether I owned it or not in a scrolling view that made it hard to find even one card that I owned. I could not figure out the rules for deck building...I finally realized that there was a box I needed to click next to the statement that said Hide unknown cards. The box was really hard to see so I had not been able to find that previously. Took me a while. I figured out that I don't have enough cards to make a deck. So I tried to get back to the map to play some more boring missions... I could not figure out how to get to the map however...Maybe I'm dense... but the game seems incredibly unintuative and clunky for new players. It may be a good game... though the first two missions of the tutorial were very boring indeed. Not much to judge a game on. Normally I would go farther before judging a game... but in this game I'm having a hard time figuring out how to do much of anything. Spent around an hour so far... just can't figure much out. Not the way to attract new players.PS. Ok... now I found the campaign map, so I go to it and my only option is to go back to the main menu screen. Maybe because I messed with my deck? Not sure. But since I don't know how to make a deck I'm a bit stuck. Maybe I'd eventually figure it out, but I doubt I'll stick around to find out.How this game got so many good reviews is hard to figure. Must be pretty good once you figure it out. But unless everyone on steam is much smarter than I am this game will never retain its new players, as I simply could not figure it out.

number of helpful: 5 of 13 people (38%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 23, 2015
												I don't understand how all these reviews do not label the game as Pay-2-Win.Don't be mistaken, this game is absolutely pay-to-win, and worst off, its pay-to-win in a game with a playerbase in the hundreds.  If you spend money on booster/decks/singles, you will have an advantage over non-paying players.  That is pay-to-win in my book.  Granted, it isn't pay-to-play.  There are ways for non-paying players to earn packs (5250 IP for a pack, you gain 150 IP per 5 minute win, 75 for a 5 minute loss.  That means anywhere between 30-40 games for 15 cards.  Did I also mention that there are 9 factions (colors/classes)?  So yeah, good luck building a deck in a short amount of time without spending money.I would have enjoyed this game a lot more if it were still Early Access, but this game has been out for 2+ years and still has many problems.Card interactions are buggy and the text isn't standardized across cards.  Morale values are not balanced, and card costs/purities aren't balanced either.  Many games end because of bugs or because it is just a death race or a coin flip.  There is some strategy there, but the results often boil down to luck because of the simultaneous turns.  You'll find yourself in draws very often.There are also so many board wipes, its ridiculous.  Wrath of God/Armageddon used to mean something, but in IW prepare for Mass Death, Heat Wave, Yuanshi's Wrath, The Calamity, Shikana, MU, the list goes on.  There are many many cards capable of clearing the board of all creatures, and many decks built around those cards.Low playerbase, no matchmaking system, so newbies are forced to play against pros, wasting their currency (it costs 1000 IP to enter a draft -- if you lose 3 games you're out).  There are separate queues for ranked/unranked but its meaningless because you don't get anything for playing ranked.  The only reason to play unranked is for the EXP and the only reason to get EXP is for the cards (assuming you're non-paying).  So you have to grind this treadmill for weeks just to be able to play the game in a meaningful way if you don't want to pay money to a game that is basically still in beta, but released for the public.TL;DR:Just another Pay-2-Win card game with lower playerbase than other games and worse player incentives.  The reward structure will make you scratch your head, as the game itself is a bit of fun, but the MMO treadmill they expect us to run is ridiculous.

content:
Posted: October 18, 2014
												I'm giving this game a thumbs down by the slimmest of margins only because I don't want to truly recommend it and there's no "meh" button. I'd give it a 45/100 really.Good:- It's simple, entertaining, and fun- there's at least a campaign/story mode unlike a lot of other card games- the cards look niceBad:- said story mode is quite thin and shallow, very minimalistic dialog- nothing new brought to the table. There's a seemingly unique "morale" attribute that functions like health, but it rarely affects the outcome of any matches- very minimal animations, not only on the individual cards themselves but even during combat- the story mode is mind numbingly easy, the only true difficulty comes in certain matches when trying to figure out what the one, and only one, way to beat the undead opponent is.Bottom line is: overall it's not a horrible game, it's just really lacking and doesn't live up to the hype at all.  You read all these reviews and figure this is gonna be the omgwtfbest game ever and it's really, really "meh".  It's a fun few hours of entertainment, but really needs more polish and features to be worth the hype.- no eyecandy, there only seems to be one set windowed size and no graphic options

content:
Posted: November 24, 2015
												Overall flow and pace of the game feels worse than both Magic and Hearthstone, mainly that you get too many extra abilities at the start with the extra command zone and can freely shuffle around all of your creatures every turn. It feels very chaotic and not in a good way.Simultaneous turns seems like an interesting idea but ends up feeling a bit like a cup game. Guess wrong targeting a creature and the spell is pointlessly wasted. You can't really strategize consistently, just fire off some spells and hope for the best.For some reason they decided you needed two health totals, health and morale. Both kill you at zero, but do nothing till you get there. Seems like a design band-aid to awkwarly punish decks that burn through creatues, but feels really stupid in practice.Visual style is a bit of a mess with knights shooting handguns, robots and magic all haphazardly thrown together.Honestly I wouldn't suggest even trying it. The effort it takes to understand this game's many unintuitive mechanics would be best spent on more polished and fun games.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 21, 2015
												I must say this is the best game I've played in years.  Its so darn good.  Back in the day I played Collectable Card Games such as Spell Fire etc.  This game is better than all those.  The GOOD:      1. You need skill.  No point and click.  You have to think about what move to make next.  You need to build a good deck, you just can'r slap cards together. You have to weigh which cards and combo's of cards to want.2. So many ways to build a deck, so many combo's. Plus they give noobs free weekly decks which match many built decks.  3. Game play is so good.  There is an Attack Zone, Defence Zone, Support and Leaders Zone.  Not just one big area like others. 4.  The developers are right there making changes and fixing bugs.  It is a small company but they fix things right away.5.  Fun.  Against humans you'll have a blast.  You'll loose at first but keep note of what cards and combo's the good players use and copy them!6.  Just like any CCG, Buy boosters and create the deck you want.The BAD1.  Match engine is getting an over haul. It's not that bad but you sometimes meet a really good player as a noob.2.  Rating system is getting an overhaul too.  It can be cruel is you're high up.  Gain little for a win but loose lots if you loose.3.  Trading is good, but they players are hard to trade with, I spent 20 minutes trying to trade for a few rares and the deal didn't do through.  It's easier to go to a broker and buy the card you want.Over all it's worth it if you like CCG's.  If you play the AI you get a bunch of free cards and you can earn points for cards and they are always throwing free ones at you.  This game is so darn good, it's "Crusader Kings Good."

content:
Posted: July 30, 2016
												Hi! I`ve read some reviews on this game and I`m amaized on how many positive reviews it has. And most of players have 20+ hrs in this game. Is really ridiculous!!! Why I find that ridicoulous, I will explain in the following review. SPOILERS AHEAD!!! TLTR and also game is about to be explained!!!I want to start by saying I don`t have many hours in game at the moment of this review (only 7 hrs) because I started just today, even tho I previously downloaded the game and after I saw you actually need to make an account to play it, I bailed out.So, today (16 July 2016) I`ve redownloaded this game, because a friend recommended to me and said it was fun and cool. It was anything but fun or cool.I have to say that I didn`t really enjoyed it! The fact that you must create an account ONLY inside game and not on their website (there`s no option to make an account on their website nor to log in), extremelly long Training (took me 2 hrs to complete it, with fails), tedious leveling and IP (Infinity Points) grinding, Predictable A.I. and also the fact that if you want to PvP, the game queues you against someone who cleary knows how to wreck you in the first 5 minutes in the game and who cleary spend Real Money to buy packs, you don`t have any option to play against new players! These things are a major turn down for me!!!Pros:- Animated cards and battlefield;- Simultaneous turns for both players or A.I.- Resources increase automatically so no need to sacrifice any of your monsters or spells to gain more resource;- Inside match "Trading post", where you have the options to shuffle your hand only 1 per match and get a different hand, draw a card (all of these cost Resouces, of course).- Beautifull graphics (at least not too bad or shady for my taste) and really nice designed artstyle on cards;- Ability to farm for card packs and avatars;- Ability to Trade;- Ability to gift store items to your friends or other players;- Ability to challenge your friends to duel you;- Low resource game (just 1.5 GBs);- Free to play;Cons:- You can create account only inside game and not on their website;- Long Training (2 hrs took me to complete it). Please name 1 more game where you have to spend 2 Hours in the tutorial because mostly of the fails!!! What tutorial is that where you can actually fail?!?;- Factions and Lore are not explained (who is against who and why);- Functions and main Menu are also not explained (how to return to main menu, how to add players as friends, how to ignore players, how to trade with other players, how to duel with your friends/other players, how to change your title/profile picture, basically ending up with default one);- Leveling and Grinding for XP and IPs is verry long and tedious (at least for me, it kinda feel like a waste of time, like I haven`t accomplished anything in this game);- No Achivements, Trading Cards or at least some freaking Badges;- A bug where your cursor is invisible (or disabled) during dialogues (mainly in Tutorial).Thank you for reading my review!!! I personally don`t really recommend this game but if your curious what`s about feel free to try it and later on, post your own review!!! Have fun!!!

content:
Posted: April 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								A great game worth many hours of fun for those who love Trading Card Games. Not recommending based solely on the fact that you really have to love TCG's to like Infinity Wars. A casual gamer who isn't crazy about TCG's would probably not like it.  I would be swayed to recommend the game if it stepped outside of the TCG box and did something no other TCG has done. Close, but no cigar. You dont have to spend a dime to enjoy the game. It helps, but like angry birds you don't HAVE to pay to play. If you love the structure and format of how MTG plays then give Infinity Wars a try. It took me over 60 hours to decide If I would recommend it which says a lot. I've edited my original review upon reflection of the comments. I've also edited down my review because I really do like the game even though I wouldn't recommend it to everyone.

number of helpful: 6 of 17 people (35%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								While the bluffing part of the battlfield makes for some interesting games the overall play is fairly simple and hardly engaging. The animated cards are nice and the graphics superb, making the game easy to get into and nice to look at while playing. The tutorials are good though the campaigns very short with the scenarios presented very limited, no real story or IP building going on here, though this area may be being worked on. The game doesn't appear to have a balance formula applied to the cards as some are outright broken and can drastically affect the outcome making it a clear have vs havenot affair. While they tout their variable play modes (eg pauper/merged deck (both players decks combined) or drafts, in the end the game appears to be heading directly towards pay2win area. They will of course say its not since you can theoretically farm IP and buy cards, the reality is that these lines have been used on players far to often. With no backing IP and a potential constant releasing of sets this feels very much like a M:TG style investment without the actual physical cards as proof of such.I have enjoyed playing it, but cannot justify any investment beyond the thankyou for the fun I have had "demo'ing" the product. Your mileage may vary of course.

number of helpful: 5 of 15 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												Don't let them kid you. If you want to be competitive when you start it IS P2W. Don't even waste your money in the blister or bundle paks. You could spend a fortune trying to get the cards you want. The pre-made decks are the way to go but don't buy them with real money just save your IP credits and buy them with those and don't waste 1000 credits (which is too much) to play draft or rift games.Be prepared like others have said cause you won't have near the cards that these veterans do in pvp. It's a joke to play pvp because they match you with just about anyone because the que is so empty in all the catagories. Basically it doesn't seem like anyone is playing this except the fanboys in the chat room.At first I liked this game but once I saw the structure and how the game really works no way am I wasting my time on it. MTG is a much better game and I've put too many years into it already and having to start over collecting just a "handful" of cards compared to MTG isn't my idea of fun.You will see a LOT of the same cards and same templates in pvp. Already in chat some players are coming in there asking for links to another players deck. Already just wanting to copy someon instead of using their own brain. There's only a handful of templates that win and win constantly and that's what you will see everyone playing. It get boring pretty quickly.For the most part the game has NO ai just scripted matchups to let you see how your cards play. It gives you false hope because you can pound the ai but as soon as you get in a real match you will see cards you've never seen before and plays you've never seen before.It's free if you can stomach the loss after loss after loss. But, what fun is that taking newbie decks into a battle of veteran decks and cards?You heard it from someone who knows trading card and collectable card games. This one has a long ways to go. Especially more cards and deck templates to play.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2016
I M O - My Thoughts on "Infinity Wars," the ACCGThis game is unforgiving and a lot remains to be desired. After a certain amount of time played, it becomes more than a challenge. I feel as though a lot of the game needs to be nerfed a pinch, the tutorial needs to be more subtle and slowed down (because, frankly, I felt rushed through it) with less horrible voice acting and dialogue from the "Campaign Story," and maybe to be more specific it the rules and match types. Granted, I haven't played that long, but I've only emerged from the tutorial/prologue, and it's been over 2hrs of gameplay, which just seems to keep droning on. In a nutshell, the game needs a lot of reworking before I even consider redownloading it again.

number of helpful: 11 of 28 people (39%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								You supported him when he asked you for a small investment from your nice thick wallet, and in return you got a macaroni collage from a 30 year old.It's like playing Magic: the Gathering with that creepy older kid who spends all his money on cards and misrepresents the rules.  He knows every exploit and glitch in the game yet refuses to tailor his game to even out the odds or make it more fun.You will go up against common, bread-and-butter creature cards that started as 3 att/ 3 def cannon fodder, that have become 100/100 and unstoppable within a reasonable time, for no investment, for very little cost to play, that you have no way to counter or get through to attack OR defend.  This card also happens to be unrestricted and can appear infinite times in your deck.  This is only one example.You will go up against his favorite, all-star deck even if he knows you only have the starters.You will be told that you cannot undo a move you made mistakenly due to unclear wording, and will have lost your turn.  You MAY be allowed to keep the card in your hand, but its cost is gone and your turn is wasted.You will be attacked and hit for 1/4 of your total health, first or second turn, many times.He will not play fair in ranked matches or tournaments.  You will never see a reward for the draft tournaments you enter.  You will spend 1000 points (average win gets `150 in other game modes) and win 5 games if you're an exceptional player, just to break even.  You will not be able to choose your three most valuable cards freely, not even their type, and will be shafted completely for your tournament because your commander cards are 3 fodder critters that offer your other 40 cards no benefit.You will very rarely get more valuable, different or rare cards.  The ones you do can't be traded for things you want.You will grind for days to afford 15 random cards - 1-3 of which will be new to your deck, MAYBE.  More often you'll get the same cards.  That can't be traded.He will tell you he's trying to change and get his act together, but the last time you saw him shave, bath, self improve or de-roach his house was October of last year.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												The game Is good on the outside and I spent many hours in it. However as you get into the game, I found that the game developers themselves are not in it to make a game, just to make money. Massive bugs, broken game mechanics, and deceptive tactics are to name a few. In the midst of this they where making expansions too add more cards to buy, while the game was in beta. They broke immersion of the game to put star trek cards in the game(that are naturally more powerful than regular cards).  Support for the game is abysmally terrible, I went THREE MONTHS trying to fix an issue that should have taken three minutes, and the problem is now even worse in the game. The last email on the issue is “The Management Team has not yet made a decision.” If you want to play this game, you will enjoy it for at least a while. However, expect it to get old quickly, but don't put any money into it. Because if anything happens don't expect support to help you.

number of helpful: 5 of 16 people (31%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												This TCG says free but its not, its so heavily pay to win it makes Magic the Gathering look like pokemon...The cards in this game are so hard to get that for 3 days i played games and still didn't get anything useful. They have a joke of a currency that you can recieve by playing games, its called Infinity points...But if you start new you will face players who have tons of cards and usually wont ever win a game (which losses give 75 IP, wins are 100)...A booster pack of cards would take roughly 40 wins to afford, which is about 12-13hrs of game play if you win all your games. On top of the heavily pay to win aspect the game consitist of too many abilities and broken combo's that a player can actually win turn 3-4 if he draws a good opening hand. I do not see a point in have 5 abilities that do roughly the same thing nor do i respect a game that doesn't ban card combo's that are instant wins...Even MTG bans cards that are broken. This game will be fun for about the first 5 levels till you start playing against players, then at that point you wonder why you wasted the time. I'm giving this advice so that you guys don't waste time trying to play this game as a "free" player...if you have a deep pocket then go ahead and credit card warrior it up and enjoy picking on players that just wanted to play a "free" game.

number of helpful: 2 of 11 people (18%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game started out really well and had I reviewed it earlier it would be a recommendation but it has lost its way.To its credit the simultaneous turns is a great mechanic and the payment model is really well done (not pay-to-win but payment does feel like you are getting something). Also the cards (mostly) avoid being ridiculous and thus having decks that will never be countered except by a deck built just for that purpose (a problem Magic hit years ago and never found a way to fix other than limiting card choices).However, there are 3 reasons that you shouldn't bother with it;1. The support is mediocre (which is a better than most I suppose). They are supposed to refund you if bugs cost you in-game currency but they have never done so for me.2. They created a brilliant, immersive, fantasy world in which all the cards make sense. The races have their place and they all fit together well. Then they added Star Trek... No, really. So now your beasts from the nature themed faction can take on dudes with phasers... wait what? It's the most immersion breaking design decision I have ever seen in a game (and at my age, that experience goes as far back as the Commodore). It screams of a 'Trekie' designer desperate to include it just because they got the IP licence. And it plays about as well too.3. The community. I have lost count of the number of times I have been flat out abused in private chat by opponents just for running particular combo's and/or cards that they don't like. I have reported each case and non have been banned. This includes some extreme language, bigotry, personal attacks etc. yet the devs take no action to control it.

								This game shows much promise. There is an element of lots for the person that enjoys trading card games. For the gamer that does not have real money to play this game you may run into others that do, and it doesn't end well for you. The grind for cards is steep and there is not much at the top when you get there as someone else has already been and you realize the climb was not worth it after all. There is some bugs still in login, loading, store, avatar/game and others that need fixing. I think this game got green lighted a little too early still. For folks that just enjoy watchin developers for games grow and thrive, I like this game for that reason because this game developer has a lot of cool ideas and I hope he gets some time to hone his awesome skills!

content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												Was having fun untill the matchmaking started puting me against people who played for a year more or less, some of them had p2w cards that nothing in my deck could do anything about.And even if I did have such a card in my deck, able to deal with something, I have to rely soley on the RNG of card games for it to pop up, otherwise I lose.My first couple of pvp games were fun against one new player, and some friendly veteran players, after that I started getting peopel who threw vulgar insults at me in chat while throwing down some p2w cards that can destroy everything I have, 4 or 5 turns into the game.Game is fun, it's pretty quick, tutorial is pretty nice,gives you plenty of cards to start off with after you finish the (rather short and unfinished) campagin, and there are "free weekly decks" that you can play with. But sadly none of this matters when most of the people you are going to face are both more knowledgeable and skilled at this game than you are, and have superior cards that you may often not have any means to deal with.Had one guy put down a card that alone killed me, because it ignored every card I had in the defence zone (both flying and non-flying) with no way of attacking it or stopping it.Another player constnatly discarded any half decent cards I had while constnatly throwing endless amounts of cards to attack me, didn't have a single card that could do anything to them and within 3 turns I was dead, unable to place a single card down that entire time.Complaints aside this is a very fun game, when you're not losing to things you literally cannot do anything about, and so are forced to sit there and watch your health dissappear.

number of helpful: 11 of 36 people (31%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								in short meh.settings - far future sci-fi... not very exciting. but that is a question of preference I guess.mechanics - pretty weak imo. there biggest mechanics difference is taking a turn together with the enemy but all that does really is make the game a bit like blackjack but worse (since you know what is in the deck and here you don't.) also this mechanic basically makes it so there can be no interrupt cards which usually adds a lot to strategy.the resource model... pretty generic and limiting. you can at most play 3 factions together and each faction you play limits the power level. so while technically you can splash for 1-2 out of faction cards it will usually be too expensive. and also with the resource model you cannot do full fledged resource strategies. the zone management (especially combined with the same turn mechanic) is unexciting and limiting to strategy. and when i say it is limiting to strategy i don't mean there is no strategy involved, only that is it is less than other models.cards - due to the mechanics of the game the cards are very limited. without interrupts(because of same turn) and without unit enchantments you are literally left with creatures, board enchantments, and one-effect spells. so the deep strategy people talk about is arranging "on enter effects", optimal resource use, effects that move between zones, and contusion effects which are generally +/- effects. all in all i can say i don't like it at all. but if you are new to the genre then i would say go for it, a card game like that no matter how lacking is still better than most anything else. and you can use it as a stepping stone to something better. and frankly when i say something better there are not many products online that are better than this unless you want to go the underground route with things like lackey and octgn.

number of helpful: 11 of 36 people (31%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								In all honesty...this is borderline for me. The story is short and offers some cards as rewards. You also get booster packs with every level and such. Got through 2 stories before I got bored. Went into PVP and wow was I blown away. People had jacked up cards that I could not even come close to. Whats a bit annoying also is I was "randomly" set up with the same guy 3 times in a row, each time being destroyed and not even coming close. You earn ingame money slowly but if you go to the shop you can pretty much buy all the jacked cards you need for some premium currency. Now I realise yes yes, free to play games need to make money, as does everyone. The game itself is cool, and I really liked the ideas and the graphics. Puts a whole new level on TCG games. Even has a trading post which I found super neat.Pros:-Cool graphics-Level and objective rewards-Trading PostCons:-People who have the best cards basically with no skill-Low money gain-Story is only 8 missions long each, and its boring and more of a tutorial-PvP match up is not awesome

content:

												Yawn*Pay-to-win garbage just like Hearthstone and Magic.Feel free to try it out though. You get rewards up to certain level but after that its endless grinding IP to buy more packs.You can't buy decks with ingame currency that is earned by playing and you are forced to pay with real money.Game also has serious balance issues and rift drafts are more broken than Arena runs in Hearthstone.Im talking about cards that can negate your entire turn and prevent you from winning right from the start.I never thought I would play as bad card game as Hearthstone but Infinity Wars sure earns its place among the worst ones.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
Early Access Review
Revised:Options menu is rather poor in terms of actual options.All that's given is sound adjustment, there is no graphic modification.Personally, I wanted to turn off the animations of the cards, because it really didn't add anything to the game.Seems that the game is fairly slow-paced, which I guess is meant to give more time to think since it is strategy, I just don't find it entertaining.And I'm not so fond of this "Morale" feature, while others may argue that it adds a different challenge, I just find it as a way to win if a player has high-hp cards, which from my perspective, isn't balancing and isn't very fun.I will give the game props for its "Breeding" system (where you can actually "breed" a card). Seems to allow a new passive strategy where a player can make a surprising comeback with overwhelming the board.Is this game unique?Yes.Is it enough to entertain?At this moment, no.I lost interest when I started going to the Dragon Campaign (Don't know if that's the actual name, but it had a dragon) and lost simply because I could not kill one card in one hit, and my morale started dwindling down even though I was doing significant damage to his fortress...Then again, this might all be personal preference as some users enjoy this feature.

								TL;DR: Trash.Warning: If you don't like this game people that work on it will harrass you!Updated Review:Because this game is *so* bad, and because Teremus wanted to argue every point... I've re-written the review.Why Does Infinity Wars Suck?============================1) Why does this review have so many thumbs down? - Lightmare staff. I know for a fact that 3 Lightmare members came here specifically to give my review a thumbs down. (Note to Lightmare: thumbs down is not for reviews you do not agree with.) They are constantly monitoring reviews. Especially Teremus. If you look at all the negative reviews for this game, (And there are many.) you will find that all of them have at least one thumbs down. Why? Teremus. He and the rest of Lightmare are attempting to bury negative reviews. Especially reviews that show any level of intellect.2) What's the problem? - Well... it's complicated, and there's actually several problems. To explain them, would mean explaining the entire game system, and well... I'm going to try to avoid it. I'm sure you don't want to read it anyway. (You either know it already, or you can look it up.) It should be sufficent to say that this is basically Magic: The Gathering. There are differences. The main one is that there are no "Land" cards for mana. You simply gain one "Resource" point per turn. (Which is equivelant to Magic's mana.) This brings us to a problem...3) Potential Lawsuit - A few months ago Hasbro subsidiary Wizards of the Coast (You may have heard of them.) sued Cryptozoic over their digital card game Hex: Shards of Fate. WotC claims that Hex is virtually identical to MtG. Hex had a successful kickstarter that raised over $2,000,000. Which is probably what drew the attention of WotC. The results of this legal battle will impact Infinity Wars. If Cryptozoic loses, then Lightmare will likely be sued sometime in the future. I mean, why not? With legal precident, all WotC would need to do is point their finger, and Lightmare could be destroyed. (Because Lightmare is very small, and merely the threat of a lawsuit would be devastating.) I sincerely hope this does not occur. If it does, it may herald an end to digital card games. With this in mind, I am uncomfortable spending any money on Infinity Wars. At least, until the lawsuit is resolved. (And who knows how long that could be?)4) Not Pay-to-Win But... - Over the years, I've played many card games. They all work the same way. You play for a while, you come up with some decks, and the game seems fun. Then... you face someone with some ridiculously overpowered combination. A person you simply cannot defeat... no matter what. The only way you could possibly win is by having specific cards to beat that specific combo. Don't have those cards? You gotta spend money, or trade. - Paying money doesn't necessarily make you any better at the game. However, it will give you many more cards than you would have otherwise. Just like any TCG, more cards means more options. More options is generally better, and should give you the advantage. Whenever the game is called-out for being P2W, the response is always, "You can earn everything for free." This is true, but the grind is excessive. You can either re-play the campaign over and over or you can face human opponents. However, many of human opponents have spent money and have extremely powerful decks. When you lose a PvP battle, you get maybe 10-20 points worth of in-game currency. To purchase cards, you need (at minimum!) 1000 points of game-currency. Unless you are some kind-of card game genius, chances are high that grinding for cards isn't feasible. It's possible, sure. However, the time it consumes means that purchasing cards makes more sense. That's why people say the game is P2W. It's not correct, but it isn't quite a lie either.5) Pricing Structure - It doesn't help Lightmare's case when they provide an option to spend over $900(USD) in their in-game store. What does $900 get you? In-game currency that is non-refundable. (A premium version of standard form of in-game currency.) It actually provides more in-game currency than you can actually spend. You can literally buy everything that exists in the game, and still have a fortune leftover. (and probably everything in the future.) It begs the question: Who would want to do that? You could easily spend far less, and still own every card. Why is the option even there? I can only conclude that it exists for some form of exploitation. You'd have to be quite well-off to have $900 just lying around. The average person isn't going to drop that much cash on a digital card game by an indie developer. At least, not all at once? No way. To me, this is evidence of a serious disconnect between Lightmare and potential players of Infinity Wars. - Teremus says that the people of Lightmare are gamers. They love TCGs. I imagine then, Lightmare wants to create the best possible dTCG. Start by fixing the core problems with TCGs. What is the *worst* part of TCGs? Do you remember, or were your lives that much different than mine? I'll skip to the point... The worst part is the cost. You pay money, and you may or may not get ANYTHING you wanted from a card pack. This is wrong. It's exploitative. It's basically a 100% legal form of gambling. (Especially when you consider that some cards are much more valuable than others.) With a dTCG, there are many opportunities to mitigate or eliminate this issue entirely! You could reduce the probability of pulling a rare from a pack you already own. Once you have six copies of a card, the probability would drop to zero, unless you have six of everything else. Alternately, you could take this in an entirely different direction. You could just make cards available to buy. Yeah, just let me pick the card I want, and then I pay for it with in-game currency. You could even monitor which cards are being played the most and purchased the most... and adjust pricing based on those figures. Also, real-life TCG cards are expensive. It's understandable though. You are paying for the cards themselves, the artwork, printing costs, shipping, et cetera. Infinity Wars boosters cost ~$3 per pack if I remember correctly. (Essencially the same cost as if I didn't have to "middle-man" through premium in-game currency. It assumes you spent less than $100 on currency. Which is fair.) Why can't it be $2 or even $1 per pack? At $3, I had to consider the value of such a purchase. At $1, I probably would've spent $10 or even $20 on my first day. I have even more ideas, but... Despite everything I can think of, Lightmare went with a traditional cost, and a traditional way of buying cards. I'm sure they've had similar ideas. - I guess Lightmare is really caught-up on the idea of selling digital cards the same way that gaming stores sell them. 16-17 years ago, I was a big fan of SWCCG. The game has been dead for quite some time, but I still own THOUSANDS of cards. On which, I spent hundreds of dollars. Sometimes I regret spending the money, but I still own the cards. No matter what, I still have the cards. If someone is willing to learn, I have enough cards to build many decks. The cards may be sitting in boxes, but I manage to play a game every few years. Digital cards do not leave the game. I don't get to keep those if Lightmare(or just Infinity Wars) shuts down, or I lose internet access. I can't play Infinity Wars offline. Therefore, digital cards have significantly less value to me than real cards. Lightmare needs to realize that Infinity Wars is more of a video game than a card game. It's competing with other video games for a player's time and attention. So, it needs be of a similar value to a console game, and not an offline TCG.Apparantly, Infinity Wars is for "Hardcore" TCG gamers to "Dominate" opponents. (See below)


YouTube™ Video: Reddit Asks: Infinity Wars

content:
Posted: March 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								I absolutely love card games, especially well designed and unique ones, and this one really got it down! I love just about everything about this game. It's got the perfect design; easy to pick up, hard to master. You can plan and strategize through multiple available factions, and even mix and match through them, which I really love, since I hate faction-locking in most other TCGs. They've got it very well designed for both players that choose to play free or pay, and paying gives no extra advantages. They've already got more than 300 cards to choose from, and plan to release more regularly, and I seriously love the fact that they're all animated! If you like card games *at all*, I strongly suggest this game!

I think the game does a very good job with not being pay to win because although you can purchase cards, you can also get the majority of them just from playing. Early Access Review
								So far i'm enjoying the game alot. I really enjoy how they made morale it not only makes the game feel unique it also helps when your having long drawn out games. The animations are cool and very well made. I only wish the campaing went longer than 8 missions. I realize the game doesn't revolve around campain mode ,but a stronger story would be great. For example I didn't feel really engaged story wise in the warpath campaign ,but the A.I is really good. One of my largest complaints which is a very small one at that is that you can't mulligan a hand or redraw a new one. Athough my deck has pretty good synergy it just seems a bit odd. Although that doesn't keep you from enjoying the game it's a very small problem. The game is also in beta and I must say it's very well polished and playable compared to other games in beta. Overall if you like MTG or card games in general I would reccomend this.

Posted: February 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								Very fun game. The gameplay doesn't feel as slick as Solforge and Hearthstone, but it does some things - a lot of things - I got from MtG those games don't - silly, silly jhonny combos, largely due to a system where you can hold your creatures back and build up. It also has a /brilliant/ way of balancing Faction mechanics with the Command zone, where you choose 3 creatures as 'commanders,' which you have access to each game - this further encourages the ability to build decks around paticular cards.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								I absolutely love card games, especially well designed and unique ones, and this one really got it down! I love just about everything about this game. It's got the perfect design; easy to pick up, hard to master. You can plan and strategize through multiple available factions, and even mix and match through them, which I really love, since I hate faction-locking in most other TCGs. They've got it very well designed for both players that choose to play free or pay, and paying gives no extra advantages. They've already got more than 300 cards to choose from, and plan to release more regularly, and I seriously love the fact that they're all animated! If you like card games *at all*, I strongly suggest this game!

								This game actually has an amazing amount of depth. I consider this to be one of the best tcgs right now, in my opinion better than solforge and on par with hearthstone. I'm looking forward to a ton of hours with this game and the best part is that it's free. I think the game does a very good job with not being pay to win because although you can purchase cards, you can also get the majority of them just from playing. There is also a mode where you and your opponent's cards are mixed up together so that makes it pretty fair. All in all, a superb game!

Early Access Review
								So far i'm enjoying the game alot. I really enjoy how they made morale it not only makes the game feel unique it also helps when your having long drawn out games. The animations are cool and very well made. I only wish the campaing went longer than 8 missions. I realize the game doesn't revolve around campain mode ,but a stronger story would be great. For example I didn't feel really engaged story wise in the warpath campaign ,but the A.I is really good. One of my largest complaints which is a very small one at that is that you can't mulligan a hand or redraw a new one. Athough my deck has pretty good synergy it just seems a bit odd. Although that doesn't keep you from enjoying the game it's a very small problem. The game is also in beta and I must say it's very well polished and playable compared to other games in beta. Overall if you like MTG or card games in general I would reccomend this.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is fantastic. The learning curve is a bit steep; lots of cards and mechanics to get a hold of. The time it takes to unlock decks doesnt take long, and the actual deck building reminds me a lot of Magic. I was playing Hearthstone pretty religiously and can honestly say that I find Infinity Wars to be the superior game. They both have their pluses and minuses, but as an actual Magic player I found this game the more rewarding option. Give it a chance, you wont be disappointed. If you want, my invite code is D55C4; add me to friends, I can help if you need any, or join you in trading cards or draft.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
												The Game is fun and has a number of cards,however half of the cards your gonna get are probably not going to be tradable,next you can buy card decks (with IRL money) which are garaunteed this ultra card or this rare,however all cards are obtainable through several ways.Now if the game had more card variety, and wasnt based of getting better cards there would be a improvement.The game has to restrict you however of using a large variety of cards with something I call the 'loyalty' system,where basically if your commander(s) (unit cards that are garaunteed for you to have (theres a commander panel) with a max of 3, where if you have a commander for this faction you get 1 'loyalty'(my own term) cards which are relatively weak,but if you get 2 commanders of one faction you get cards of that faction that may need 2 'loyalty' which are pretty strong,now once you have 3 commanders for 1 faction, you can get any card for that faction.THe thing with card variety in Infinity Wars is that you pretty much are limited to have a really weak variety deck or a single play style strong deck, which severely effects deck variety.A alternative with this is to add more commanders or make less dependency on commanders.Strong cards cost alot of resources (a thing which lets you use unit cards,spells,or alternative ways to spend resources which effect the game,resource is increased by 1 every turn and it is completely replenished each turn) to prevent it from being used too early in the game,and so that the game isnt based off just whoevers gets a better draw.The game is good but doesnt have enough cards and deck variety at the moment so I rate this game 7.5/10

												+Pros~Decent campaigns~Not a Pay 2 Play, getting the cards is quite easy not to mention the free daily log-in bonus card~Rift runs are quite challenging (in the fun sort of way not the bash my head in with a pry-bar kind).~Trial by error, you make mistakes and you learn from them.(Even if you lose a match you dont lose money but gain it , you just dont gain exp).~The Dev's are on every day available for questioning.-Cons~The tutorial doesnt really explain too much, (points you in the right direction and tosses you in the deep end). ~The trading is a tad confusing, mostly giving you a link to a (un?)offical website.Overall I would definently sugest this game to any fan of Cards (MtG or otherwise)

												Brilliant! I would happily pay for this game, the fact it's free means there's no reason you shouldn't own it. Having spent 7+ hours playing, I've still got a good deal of campaign, practice and online modes to complete. There are a huge variety of card types, more of which can be paid for, though spending no money in-game does not diminish the experience one bit. You can play so many different ways, using custom decks, starter decks and a TONNE of different abilities, both offensive and defensive. Download and play NOW! You won't regret it.

												A very cool TGC with some unique stuff and complex play, but while I've really enjoyed it I can't quite fully recomend it.Pros:Simultaneous turns - this is one of my favorite things about this game, more turn based games need this! I wish working toward getting cards was more fun.  I think there is a lot they could do here.  Making trading easier would even help a lot.  Right now it feels like you have to wait forever to maybe get one new useful card, or throw quite a bit of money at it.Too varried in terms of decks and play styles you can end up with decks that are too specialized or you need to know the trick to beating them.  This gets frustrating and reminds me of playing old magic where there are these trick cards and combos that just feel out of the blue and unfair.I think it's worth trying but just know what your getting into.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 11, 2015
												Read this review first. Also, I started playing this game two weeks ago from the post date of 8/11/15, so everything I'm saying is current.This. Game. Is. *Awesome*.I played Magic The Gathering my entire childhood, MTG Online, WoW TCG, Hearthstone, and Hex, and they all pale in comparison. I've heard nonsense in these reviews ranging from matchmaking issues to.... "ths game sux cuz not nuff dbl xp wkends".... (seriously? lol)At the end of the day, TCG's (or CCG's *shrug*) are *all* about the cards, and mechanics of the game. This game is So much more fun, complex, and strategic than *any* other game in the genre, bar none. Anyone who tells you differently is lying, an idiot, or rage-quit because they lost their first battle and got angwy.I'm not just some fanboy. There are a couple of glitches, and from what I hear, there could be a better matchmaking system I guess (though I find I win a completely reasonable amount of matches, regardless of being new). However, the game itself just can't be beat. Try playing this game for a few days and going back to Hearthstone. Go ahead, I just did it. I was literally *bored* to tears. It doesn't have one tenth the depth or strategy that Infinity Wars has. It's just a fact, guys.The cards are *beautiful*, *all of them are animated*, and...you...can... *trade* with your friends... (or enemies, or strangers... whatever). For those of you who have actually played other online TCG's, I'm sure you can appreciate putting the 'T' back into the acronym. I don't know about you guys, but that was half of what it was about when I was a kid. There are *8* incredibly distinct and well-designed factions to choose from, each with their own goals, combos and strategies that make sense, and carry a personality of their own. You can *combine* them into a deck of your choosing, and the combinations really let your own deck designs shine. The game has 4 zones during play. One of which is the 'Commander' zone, which is a set of 3 characters of your choosing that start on the board from turn 1. While I, myself, found it a bit 'too much' when i first started, it's come to be one of the most amazing and distinguishing mechanics this game has to offer, bringing a new level of customization and gauranteed strategy to your deck.Don't listen to the nay-sayers. If you're here on this page because you're bored of what little Hearthstone has to offer, download this, and thank me later.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												I haven't played any card games in a while but I'd definitely have to reccomend this one, the gameplay is pretty well balanced. And games tend to be fast paced but still incredibly engaging, The card art is very nice and the factions are varied and interesting, all with different playstyles. They've got a very nice FTP system as well. You're able to obtain every card in the game without paying any real currency, In game money is used to buy booster packs while premium currency can be used to buy additional "starter decks" (which free players can obtain through playing a factions campaign). As well as different aesthetic card backs or playing fields. There are many gameplay options, including mixed decks, and a drafting mode called a rift run in which you're given a choice of 4 cards at a time to build a 40 card deck and compete against other players doing the same.Overall 10/10 cardgame very fun.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												If you're a fan of MTG and want a digital TCG that's not as simple or luck-based as Hearthstone, I highly recommend this game. The mechanics do take a bit of getting used to. Both players plan their turns at the same time, click a button, and the system sorts out how it all works. It's a rather unique and interesting way of going about a card game that leads to lots of extra strategy and complexity, in a very good way.The game can be a bit buggy, something the small team is always working on, and the player base isn't massive since it hardly gets any marketing. Yet, there's a lot of fun to be had with the game, just check my time played with it. The new questing system helps explain the game in easily understandable ways and gives you lots of free cards just for completing it. There's also plenty of free cards from leveling (easily a bunch of booster packs in the first few hours of playing). IP (free currency) does build a bit too slowly to buy new packs in a timely manner, but they're tweaking those values while still trying to keep the game balanced. And balance is key. While there's some really rare cards that can be hard to get, having them is not pay-to-win. Some good strategy and a  well-built deck can beat those cards, because everything is fairly well balanced and the devs  frequently adjust cards to maintain the balance.So, totally check this out!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 19, 2015
												TL;DR Good concept and potential, but nagging problems prevent it from being goodInfinity Wars has a lot of innovative ideas: the command system, the different battlefield zones, players having both health and morale that they have to watch, but in the end the game is bogged down by a clunky progression system. It's very difficult to get new cards (two cards free per day, 3,000 IP (the free currency) for a booster pack, which takes a while to earn considering you only get a few hundred IP for a win, at most. Leveling is slow and eventually becomes a ceaseless grind at the higher levels, with no incentives or rewards other than getting a free pack every levelup (the game has 30 levels in all. I'm level 26) But the biggest problem isn't the price, it's the fact that the game offers no way to get rid of excess cards. You can include three copies of most cards at max in your deck, but the vagaries of luck and rarity have caused me to have over 10 of some common cards, and only one of others. As of this writing, I have 27 Wealthy Nobles. The game has no disenchant option, so the cards just sit there, effectively wasted IP. This also makes building your own deck difficult, as you can't get the cards you need. I still think the game has potential and I would return if some of these things were fixed, but right now, I can't recommend it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 6, 2015
												Very uneven TCG.On the positive side lie the mechanics and card design. Developers used clever solutions to reduce influence of rendomness on the results of a game and introduce a high skill ceiling. Command zone mechanic makes decks much more consistent. This diminishes dependance of having good draws and puts more emphasis on deck construction. Meanwhile, the way targetting works with different zones of play leaves a lot of space for bluffing, mind games and outsmarting the opponent. Finally mechanics are rich and complex, allowing for variety of strange, powerful and sometimes even silly combos.Another strong point is the art quality. As always, there are some hits and misses, but the style chosen by creators works well. Also, each card is animated and while some of animations are very simple (say, a billowing cloak on a static character), some cards are short animated stories in an of themselves (Give Him a Jetpack taking a cake in this category).All of the above makes for a card game that, in my opinion, is much more satisfying than the biggest F2P TCG at the moment, that is Hearthstone.The negatives are mostly of technical nature. From time to time strange bugs crop out, servers can be problematic and functionality of client is debatable. Interface works passably well, but is not the most comfortable. Deck building window and trade window spring to mind as examples of less than stellar when it comes to quality of use.Also, the in-game economy may be unwelcome for some. Trading cards is a staple of the genre, but ability to craft a card that one requires at the time is definitely convenient in comparison to looking for someone who both has it and wants anything of what you want to trade. Infinity Wars is however based purely on interplayer trade in that regard (and of course purchasing boosters for either in game currency or cash). This can be either positive or negative, depending on preferance.I still recommend the game, since positives outweight the negatives by a large margin and it is worth giving it a try.

content:
Posted: October 13, 2015
												Solid card game! It's no Magic the Gathering but it definitely holds some charm on it's own. The interesting mechanic is the "Simultaneous Turn", both players plan their turns at the same time and then they play out.  It eliminates the 'weakness' Hearthstone has of once your turn is over you can just sit there and watch yourself get destroyed.  The Factions have interesting card mechanics, nothing that hasn't been seen before though.  The art is very nice I must say but I reckon they could have gone for some smoother animations on the cards themselves.  For a game that runs in 60 FPS having the animations on the cards be anything less make it stick out a bit.  Do I recommend this game?  Hell yeah, it's got style, character and an inovative turn mechanic.  If you're looking for a new online card game that isn't as basic as let's say, Star Realms, not as random as Hearthstone and not as time consuming as Magic the Gathering.  Then this is a decent little card game one can get into! Game On.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 9, 2014
												(I really play a lot of card games..)But this one is above most of those I played yet.The game is still in developpement. The menu is not always intuitive. There is often bugs.But, in my opinion, the game system is amazing.Each player have a deck of 40 cards and 3 commanders. The commanders are regular creatures but they start in the game. You can use their abilities but you can't use them to fight until you play the on the battlefield like other creatures.You can put your creatures in three zone: Assault, Defense and Support. The creatures in Assault will fight the creatures in the opponent Defense and deal damage to his fortress if you can. The creatures in Defense will prevent the opponent's creatures in Assault from damaging your fortress. Creatures in Support will be out of combat and protected from some spells.So, your fortress have 100 health but you also have 100 morale. You lose morale each time one of your creatures dies.And, each player moves and play spells at the same time. You must anticiapte your opponent moves.There is many factions in the game and the cards you can play in your deck depend of your commander's factions. Different factions will give you more variety while three commanders from the same faction will give you stronger cards of that faction.You will soon unlock starter decks for each factions. These decks are obviously weaker than most of the decks you'll see online but they are still very fun to play (at least against AI) because each faction have excellent synergy together.Even better, each factionis better than somes and weaker than others, like a rock, paper, cissors game but with eight factions.In my opinion, this game is among the best cards games even if some parts still bug. If you love strategic games, I highly recommend you to try this one!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 13, 2015
												Solid card game! It's no Magic the Gathering but it definitely holds some charm on it's own. The interesting mechanic is the "Simultaneous Turn", both players plan their turns at the same time and then they play out.  It eliminates the 'weakness' Hearthstone has of once your turn is over you can just sit there and watch yourself get destroyed.  The Factions have interesting card mechanics, nothing that hasn't been seen before though.  The art is very nice I must say but I reckon they could have gone for some smoother animations on the cards themselves.  For a game that runs in 60 FPS having the animations on the cards be anything less make it stick out a bit.  Do I recommend this game?  Hell yeah, it's got style, character and an inovative turn mechanic.  If you're looking for a new online card game that isn't as basic as let's say, Star Realms, not as random as Hearthstone and not as time consuming as Magic the Gathering.  Then this is a decent little card game one can get into! Game On.
