number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												I came to this game as a complete newbie to trading card games in general and I love it!The game is pretty good at telling you how to play and teaching you little thigs you might miss through features such as the Campaign and more importantly the Academy missions. These are really good for getting your mind thinking in the way it needs to.Also getting cards is so simple when you start. I first looked on the store and was tempted to spend some real money on the Cpollection Booster cause it would you know, Boost my Collection right? It is not needed, ever I wwouldnt think. You get a complete Starter deck for each faction for free just by playing through the first three campaign missions for that faction. You get more cards for that faction after completing 5 games of their campaign and then more when you finish their campaign (8 missions). And that is for every faction in the game. You also get a fre login bonus evry day and a free bonus when you have played three games that day. These bonuses are usually a single random card but can be booster packs of 15 random cards too.Playing the game is great fun, requires alot of thinking, but also a ton of luck too. You can build the best deck you can and as the card draw is random you can still find yourself struggling or even defeated by turn 3! I am fairly sure it will be the reliance on luck that will eventually turn me off playing but for now i am enjoying it immensely.The one major downside i have foud is that all the cards you gain in the ways I have outlind above are 'Soulbound', that is they are locked to your account and cant be traded as bought cards can be. This wouldnt be so bad except I have already got 8, 9, 10 or more of some cards that you can only ever have 3 of in a deck. i have no way of getting rid of these extras.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
												Let me start out by saying that I love CCG games.  Infinity Wars has not dissappointed but for me it leaves a little to be desired.  I know it is out of the norm that someone who enjoys playing CCG games prefers to strictly play offline against the AI, but that is me.  With that being said, if you're looking for a type of review based on the online PvP of the game you won't find it here.On that note, I'll go over the good features of the game.  I love the illustrations and the variety of cards in themselves is great.  Also, the animation on EVERY card is a nice touch.  The cards are well-thought, mostly balanced with some Epic cards being game changers but in my opinion, thats the great thing about the CCG game.  The gameplay, process, and strategy that are involved is also very good.  Without getting into it too deep, you basically have your character cards, gear cards, location cards etc.  Your main goal is to destroy your enemies fortress by attacking with your characters.  A nice twist on this game however, is that each character has a listed morale.  Now if that creature dies, your faction loses that much morale.  Your starting fortress and morale bars start at 100 each.  If either reach 0 then you lose the game.  Like I said, just the basics as there are certain strategies to get you to that goal.  You can also completely customize your decks with cards awarded after receiving new booster packs after each level gained or through their online store for purchase.  I've played about 11 hours on this game so far and have not spent anything as of yet and have several Rare cards, 1 Epic, and 0 Legendaries at this point to give you an idea.  One major love of mine regarding the customization is that there are 3 slots for you to choose which faction you want in that slot.  You can assign a Commander for each one of those 3 slots, ensuring those cards are on the battlefield for you at game start.My only negative point with this game is that there really isn't any other mode for me to play other than "Practice".  And this mode only allows me to play against 4 specific decks with a rated difficulty.  Therefore, 11hrs in I'm getting a little bored.  Other than that, if you're into the online gaming then this might be for you as I feel like the gaming mechanics and overall replayability of the game is right on.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2015
												I have to recommend this game, but I need to warn people of something now.This IS a Trading Card Game. It is not a pure Free to Play, or a Pay to Win game. If you don't like the idea of buying boosters or organising trades, don't get this game. YOu will end up with extra cards and there isn't a craftign system like Hearthstone, that said there's also no secondary market so unlike MTG there are no rares worth  thirty quid by themselves, most are on a rarity to rarity basis.The game itself is a blast. The rules and flavour are fresh and original and it does things you simply can't do in a physical TCG, the gameplay is fun and they hand out a free rotation of decks for people to try every week. Want a totally fun experience? Get a friend when the Rift War deck is available. Two opposite decks of forty 'Add a Random CArd to you Hand' makes deck games that can be insane. This is a great game for people who want a legit Trading Card Game with the unique mechanics, this is not a game for people who want a totally free or a pay to win game

Posted: April 3, 2015
												If you like TCGs then you should definitely check this one out. Beautiful, animated artwork is a great touch. Gameplay is fairly intuitive and basic, however there are tons of rules that need to be learned. Just the right amount of challenging without it feeling unfair. I really like that any deck is fair game; ie. there are no go-to decks that are a guaranteed win. The more you play and unlock achievements (in game, not steam) you get more cards so it doesn't feel pay2win. There is a store available just like any other free to play game where you can buy booster packs, decks, and aethetic changes such as icons, card backs, and battlefields (the area in which the cards are played). All can be purchased with money or points you accumulate from playing. Although, between the ability to buy cards and decks with points, and being able to trade with others- you should be able to make any deck you desire without spending a cent.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												I'm not playing this for long but i was suprised how much of a copy of MTG it seems to be, positively. Surely it looks different but if you know MTG well enough you will notice that its basically the same with slight changes. You will declare attackers and defenders aswell, just not in the form of tapping but in the form of moving the cards to specific areas. Cast creatures cant be moved to any of those areas instead they are resting in the Support area whey they cant attack or block.The biggest Changes to MTG are:No mana cards - You get +1 Mana every turnMana is colorlessPlayers make their moves at the same timeMonster HP does not reset at the end of the turnAnd the most weirdest part, 1 Monster can block every attacking Monster if it has enough HP and propably destroy every attacker.So basically it feels like a slightly easier MTG and fans, just like me, could enjoy it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 9, 2015
												A game that can actually burn time without you noticing it. Would actually give it a high rating, were it not for the large gap between old and new players. Although basic cards can be received from playing the campaign and finishing quests, they are not enough to be able to compete with the higher level/older players. This becomes a bigger problem due to a seemingly broken matchmaking system. It's either a few players are playing or bad matchmaking since a player can get paired up with a high-ranking/veteran player, which can demoralize a player.Sure you can say that when playing the game more, you earn in-game currency to buy booster packs/decks, but it is not enough to actually bring the new player to compete or at least have a chance. For example, a VICTORY gives only 150 IP tops but not guaranteed, while a booster pack costs 5250 IP, which means a required minimum of 35 wins. Decks, on the other hand, cost 12,950 IP, which reuires a minimum of 87 wins with maximum IP gained. Considering loses only give ~50 IP and new players rarely having good cards, it makes the game into a grind of a sort. Of course, there is the last resort of actually purchasing cards with real money for those who want to support the game. With the low amount of IP gained per match and expensive cost of card packs/decks, the game seems to tell players to "buy or suffer grind."I'd recommend the game since it shows promise, but due to the current system it may dismay some players.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
												This is a great game.  I've always loved TCG's (mostly MTG and Yugioh back in the day) and they were fun but I've always known that they could be done better on a computer.  An online digital card game can do so many things that a physical TCG can't (like animated cards, auto match-making, zero rule disputes) and Infinity Wars totally nails it.  If you've ever played MTGO *shudder* then you'll be dumbfounded by how poor an it is in comparison to IW.   Solid excecution aside, Infinity Wars also succeeds on the artwork side of things.  Any collector/player would probably agree that card art is an important part of getting involved with these games.  The artists for IW know what they're doing.  The cards look fantastic and they're animated to boot.  It's dark/gritty comic-book feel and just looks awesome.  Finally, and most importantly, we have gameplay.  Here is where I think the game should really take off.  It's completely original and operates totally different from any TCG I've ever playeed.  One of the most interesting things about it (going back to what a digital game can do that a physical one can't) is that people plan and execute their turns simultaneously.  Nobody gets to go "first" and you're generally not having to deal with a lot of the annoying "priority" issues that you find in games like MTG.  This completely changes the dynamics and tempo of the gameplay and it's a lot of fun.  I would recommend anyone who likes TCG's to try this out.  It's free to start and you can actually get a lot of gaming in without buying anything.  So far I've spent about $25 and I'm holding my own in the ranked queues pretty well.

Any collector/player would probably agree that card art is an important part of getting involved with these games.  The artists for IW know what they're doing.  The cards look fantastic and they're animated to boot.  It's dark/gritty comic-book feel and just looks awesome.  Finally, and most importantly, we have gameplay.  Here is where I think the game should really take off.  It's completely original and operates totally different from any TCG I've ever playeed.  One of the most interesting things about it (going back to what a digital game can do that a physical one can't) is that people plan and execute their turns simultaneously.  Nobody gets to go "first" and you're generally not having to deal with a lot of the annoying "priority" issues that you find in games like MTG.  This completely changes the dynamics and tempo of the gameplay and it's a lot of fun.  I would recommend anyone who likes TCG's to try this out.  It's free to start and you can actually get a lot of gaming in without buying anything.  So far I've spent about $25 and I'm holding my own in the ranked queues pretty well.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 9, 2015
												A game that can actually burn time without you noticing it. Would actually give it a high rating, were it not for the large gap between old and new players. Although basic cards can be received from playing the campaign and finishing quests, they are not enough to be able to compete with the higher level/older players. This becomes a bigger problem due to a seemingly broken matchmaking system. It's either a few players are playing or bad matchmaking since a player can get paired up with a high-ranking/veteran player, which can demoralize a player.Sure you can say that when playing the game more, you earn in-game currency to buy booster packs/decks, but it is not enough to actually bring the new player to compete or at least have a chance. For example, a VICTORY gives only 150 IP tops but not guaranteed, while a booster pack costs 5250 IP, which means a required minimum of 35 wins. Decks, on the other hand, cost 12,950 IP, which reuires a minimum of 87 wins with maximum IP gained. Considering loses only give ~50 IP and new players rarely having good cards, it makes the game into a grind of a sort. Of course, there is the last resort of actually purchasing cards with real money for those who want to support the game. With the low amount of IP gained per match and expensive cost of card packs/decks, the game seems to tell players to "buy or suffer grind."I'd recommend the game since it shows promise, but due to the current system it may dismay some players.

												The Game is fun and has a number of cards,however half of the cards your gonna get are probably not going to be tradable,next you can buy card decks (with IRL money) which are garaunteed this ultra card or this rare,however all cards are obtainable through several ways.Now if the game had more card variety, and wasnt based of getting better cards there would be a improvement.The game has to restrict you however of using a large variety of cards with something I call the 'loyalty' system,where basically if your commander(s) (unit cards that are garaunteed for you to have (theres a commander panel) with a max of 3, where if you have a commander for this faction you get 1 'loyalty'(my own term) cards which are relatively weak,but if you get 2 commanders of one faction you get cards of that faction that may need 2 'loyalty' which are pretty strong,now once you have 3 commanders for 1 faction, you can get any card for that faction.THe thing with card variety in Infinity Wars is that you pretty much are limited to have a really weak variety deck or a single play style strong deck, which severely effects deck variety.A alternative with this is to add more commanders or make less dependency on commanders.Strong cards cost alot of resources (a thing which lets you use unit cards,spells,or alternative ways to spend resources which effect the game,resource is increased by 1 every turn and it is completely replenished each turn) to prevent it from being used too early in the game,and so that the game isnt based off just whoevers gets a better draw.The game is good but doesnt have enough cards and deck variety at the moment so I rate this game 7.5/10

content:
Posted: September 20, 2014
												As with any card game, there's ins and outs to know for mastery of a game, and with simultaneous turns and a rather fun deck building system, this game may heavily appeal to some players.However, as of right now, I wouldn't recommend this game. The game itself isn't bad by any means, it simply hasn't grown enough, and feels as if it still needs to establish itself. Different paths for different factions are available, but at the same time it's readily apparent that some vastly outclass others, and not enough options as of yet exist to balance that out in a truly feasible way. Many times the recommended counters can alter the structure of a planned build too far to have remained true to the original intent, limiting the truly 'good' builds. On the other side, being able to mix and match factions can be rather fun, and I've enjoyed being creative, as well as playing against other creative builds, even if it's clear that one is stronger using aforementioned faction paths. Utilizing commander abilities also added a rather nice edge to the game, swinging games from victory to loss (unless playing against verore since they can just kill them outright, which sadly happens frequently). It adds a stable foundation to your builds, and enhances synergy. Along the same line, being able to swap your resources for drawing cards, swapping cards, and increasing resource cap can also help players stay in the lead or bounce back, even when seemingly out of any other options, as when given a bad hand.So overall, I'll be looking to come back to this game in the future, but not right now.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 26, 2015
												Infinity Wars is, for me, one of the best TCG's out there. Most may argue that it's not as good as MTG but still, compared to most other popular card games... *ahem*  Hearthstone  *ahem* it get's the golden medal.One of IW's main feature is the "simultaneous turn* mechanic. Both players have about a minute or so to plan out their turns. When they are done, the cards are played out simultaniously. This feature might seem pointless just by itself, but in conjuction with IW's multiple zones, it makes the game a ton of fun. It adds a new element to the genre, the element of  Bluffing  and  Prediction. Here's an example on how this works: The Assault and Defense Zones are the Battlefield, The Support Zone though is not part of the Battlefield. Most cards are useless if they sit on the Support. Now here's where it gets interesting. Many cards target specific zones. Most "kill" cards ,for example, target cards on the Battlefield. If the targeted card is moved outside of the Battlefield the turn the "kill" card is played, it has no effect and is thrown to the used pile. Players can predict such cards or even try to waste them by bluffing (ex. playing a strong character but not moving it to the Battlefield).  This adds huge amount of strategy and depth to the game. Not only does it make it very interesting but it limits the cards' power, a player with a great mindset will easily outplay his opponent even if his cards are much inferior.Another small positive is that every card is animated. Some may have a very simple animation , like a character moving as he breaths heavily, while others can have up to 5 wooping seconds of animation. In addition, the devs are pretty generous towards new-comers. Cards can be earned very easily and most cards are balanced. Not to mention the community if pretty friendly and welcoming. The only negatives are the bugs, but still the devs are constantly working towards removing them.  It's a must-try if you are a TCG fan!

content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
												Pros:Simultaneous turns make combat hard to predict, keeping the game moving and you thinking.Many viable combos.Weekly decks let even new players try out rather advanced decks.Free play viable.Win or lose, it's often spectacular.The cards are ANIMATED.Single-player campaign.Community full of good sportsmanship.Chat turns all cuss words into "puffy", named for the silliest test AI bot.Multiple play modes to mitigate power creep.Cons:Simultaneous turns make playing counters a gamble.No "combat log" to explain why a given action failed (or succeeded).A long-ish ramble I made a video of on the subject: 


YouTube™ Video: Ramble #1.5 (Hi-Fi remake)- Infinity Wars 

			Views: 30		

			A collectible card game, free-to-play, locatable on Steam. Showcasing what I like about it, and a quick game-and-a-half play example.		

This game's fun. I highly recommend playing through all the training, academy missions, and the single-player campaign. Good free way to get a solid starting understanding of the game and a good untradable library. And probably enough free points to buy some extra cards.Obvious question with any F2P is if it's P2W. You can buy card boosters with real money. And with fake money. The only thing you can't buy with the fake points are... cosmetic. Different avatars, card backs, particle effects... and I think one deck of the oldest cards. I remember playing Magic in high school. One kid had a lot more money than sense. Mox everything. Multicolored lands. I had a beginners deck a card shoppe had assembled as a way to repackage a lot of low-value cards. I beat that rich kid's pants off every time. Scrib sprites make life better.Now, more relevant, this game has some good ways around that problem. The weekly decks are often quite potent. But there's also several game modes. Infinite (anything goes, including star trek cards); Core (standard deckbuilding rules apply); Merged (both players cards shuffled together into one stack of chaos.); and Pauper (common and uncommon cards ONLY)That's without even looking at the draft game, which is cheap and can be entered with free points. Ranked play could be cheesed, but the only rewards there are cosmetic. And ego.And you can punch a few AI opponents when you have the itch.

												Sooo...lets start with yeah its a f2p tcg, people who put money in have an advantage, kinda how those games work. That being said I've put nothing in and spent 6 hours or so playing and here are my thoughtsArtwork: Not MTG lvl, but really that'd be asking a lot from a non wizard TCG so fairly standard but lots of use of colors, its nice.Card spending: Its more streamlined than MTG, hell everything is and yes the review is gonna go around MTG as sort of the top of TCG...why...well because it is and if you think otherwise, you're most likely wrong. No mana to tap, get resources which increase per turn, spend them to summon cards, magic, abilitiesCard range: Pretty normal variety: Creatures, abilities, location, artifacts sooooo yeah normalDepth of Game: I'd rank it above Hearthstone which to me is about as casual you get without the game being a bore and lets say Yugioh. There is enough variety and ability to make mixed decks and them be functional (often better) and some strategy based on who you are playing.Generals: So purity is a deciding factor on generals, some cards require two gens from that card type, some 1, some all 3 gens must be of that type this both limits and creates variety in gameplay as the gens you pick can have a huge impact on ramping up bigger high dmg cardsWhere the game excels? Draft mode, which is one of two modes players get ranked; which is the most just system of ranking possible, the draft mode however is slow as frak to set up due to load times and revamps due to crap generals. But money doesn't matter in draft, it won't help you win so balanced pvp existing in a computer TCG? Yeah that's a major win in my bookOh rights: HP and Moral, two ways to win/lose. If either (both start at 100) hit zero its game over, but unlike many games where zero cards in deck means gameover Infinity War lets you keep playing with a "dead" deck for a lose of 10 morale per turn. Shot clock which frankly not a bad way to manage itLacks: A decent RFP, its there and its okay but it feels really limited and return from graveyard is barely there at all, more fill the grave then empty it

content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												Updated review after many months away.Same story as in the early access. Lots and lots of potential here. It just oozes it everywhere. However there are 3 big things that made me uninstall this for the last time.1. Most importantly is bugs. Bugs everywhere. I have lost so many matches that I actually won because the game froze and I was forced to quit out. Not to mention endless animation loops that force you to quit. also there are constant disconnects mid match. This is crippling in rift running where you only get 3 shots and your done. When you have a killer deck and end up losing it because bugs force restarts then it really kills your joy.2. Booster packs take foreeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeever to earn once your boosted xp from low levels goes away. you get 170-350 currency for losing/winning. a booster costs 5250. as you can see you need a lot of wins or even more combinations of losses and wins to get 15 cards. There is trading but no auction house which this game desperately needs. 15+ wins for one booster might be tolerable assuming you win all matches except for problem 3.3. The community is very very very veeeeeeeeery small. I have sat in queues for unranked or ranked for 30-90 minutes with no matches. If you play at the peak hours its tolerable, but god forbid you want to play on non peak times. There just isn't a large enough player base for a pvp focused game. Even hex, duels of champions, and sol forge have larger player bases. Another consequence of the small player base is you are much more likely to get constantly steam rolled by the people that can dump hundreds and even for some thousands into this game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								If you'r a fan of TCG's, this one is a must to try.the game is quite complex and tactical. The game actually allows you to build decks around distinct tactics you may think of, and each group has a istinct playstyle.Building a proper deck and learning to anticipate your opponents moves is essential.Dont be put off by the initial campaign and challenges, which at times are a bits silly and frustrating puzzles with pre determined cards. Once you get to building your own decks and playing other players it realy is a good card game.Completing the campaigns (one for each faction) gives you a decent set of cards to start building your own decks with.While it takes quite a few games to gather enough game credits to buy a (15 card) booster - this takes between 35 (all wins) and 70 (all losses) pvp games - you get a decent amount of (15 card) boosters by leveling up, comleting some achievements, and sometimes even for just logging in that day. giving you a good amount of cards to build your decks with reasonably fast.The only limiting factor of the cards not obtained through premium or game credits is that they cannot be traded to other players.The only thing limited to premium credits are some cosmetic things like different card backs or battlefield visuals, everything that matters for gameplay can be obtained through playing the game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												Pros:I enjoy the tutorial system in this game. Rather than having one session to cram all the knowledge you need, you are given a set of books, each focusing on one aspect of the game.The simultaneous/initiative action mechanic is a unique way to play, allowing players to create a strategy, lock it in, and see what the opponent decided to do with the same information you had.There are 8 different factions and you can use up to 3 different factions when making a deck. Each one is distinctive, but chances are you will latch onto one that fits your playstyle.The animated cards are enjoyable to watch and really brings life to the game.Cons:The game is a little buggy, with a few text descriptions missing, forcing you to guess what is going on, but it does not derail from the game experience.The lore is absolute crap and they stole a Star Wars quote and put it as flavor text for one of their cards.Getting daily rewards is a little unclear, and booster packs tend to give you cards you already have, but I guess that's expected.

content:

												as far as free to play CCG's go i can reccomend this one.  it does an excellent job of easing you into the gameplay and mechanics, with the single play experience offering difficult challenges and rewarding you with new cards to play with.  you get bonus cards just for logging in daily.  the game play structure is rich and rewarding, and i feel you can play effectivly without feeling forced to buy cards.  definitely a plus.  the animated card backgrounds are simple, but add to the feel of the game, and some of the flavor text is very... flavorful. :)  try this out if youve ever been a fan of CCG's like magic or vampire or netrunner or yugioh

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 23, 2016
												Great game, very deep strategic decisions to be made, very complex deck building and it's more than just a TCG going digital, I don't see, how you would have fun with this on a tabletop as there are very many things to keep track of. Highly recommended!!!Update:I wish, I could give a "partially recommended". What I wrote above still stands, but I have to say, after a while, you find yourself either compelled to spend a lot of money to get the cards you need or to spend a lot of time to try and trade them, whereas you have dozens of surplus copies of useless cards rotting in your account. In short: the trade system sucks! You look for single cards and hope to find someone offering it for the stuff you have. Why not do an interim resource for which you can trade in your surplus cards to buy cards you need directly? Hearthstone (which I deem the way less interesting game) does it, Faeria (which is very nice, but not as good as IW) does it. What's the problem then? Hopefully someone looks into this, because the game itself is still my favourite digital TCG!!!

content:

												Please note that I haven't played this game for a long time; it's just my first impressions.This Trading Card Game is quite fun.Gameplay:4/5It requires lots of tactical and strategical thinking. For example, when to play good cards or when to not. That's just one of many scenarios where thinking is required. However, it gets complicated at times. The time for a match can really vary. Also you can train offline if it is needed.Environment:3.5/5The visuals are cool with all the animated cards. The video and the audio gets very repetitive through a game.Controls:4/5The drag-and-drop-your-cards-onto-the-battlefront system isn't hard to master. However, it is pretty unwieldy.Replayability and Dev Support:5/5The game constantly keeps you playing with many cards to collect. Also the developers give you free cards daily. The devs listen to anything you have to say, and they constantly release new updates.Overall8/10Great game, definitely recomended.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												I'm not playing this for long but i was suprised how much of a copy of MTG it seems to be, positively. Surely it looks different but if you know MTG well enough you will notice that its basically the same with slight changes. You will declare attackers and defenders aswell, just not in the form of tapping but in the form of moving the cards to specific areas. Cast creatures cant be moved to any of those areas instead they are resting in the Support area whey they cant attack or block.The biggest Changes to MTG are:No mana cards - You get +1 Mana every turnMana is colorlessPlayers make their moves at the same timeMonster HP does not reset at the end of the turnAnd the most weirdest part, 1 Monster can block every attacking Monster if it has enough HP and propably destroy every attacker.So basically it feels like a slightly easier MTG and fans, just like me, could enjoy it.

												What can i say about Infinity wars? Well to be honest in my opinon this game has far out reached most CCGs out there are far as well..... the whole game! it has a very unique play style compared to most CCGs does very frequent updates (the most recent is the reward system where you can get ip and LP as well as a full booster pack and boosts ) everyday you get rewards when you log on and it forces you to think and stadegize more so than any CCG or TCG ive seen!!! where a starter deck is basically just that not over powered to where people who make good actual decks get ♥♥♥♥ed over by a stupid common deck that everyone has and can get. so all you newbies who downrate this game bc you cant think without the game holding your hand giiving you everything from the start this game is not for you.Now on the other hand it has its flaws as well like every game in existance. it frequently lags here and there like loading the batlle sequence or let alone loading the whole match between 2 people. it also matches you up poorly and i mean poorly where a low level  is paired with someone whos level 20 or higher sometimes instaed of matching someone based off of level and or how well your gaming skills are at your current state. alsoa s a blow to some newbies they are confused as to how to use certain ablities of cards plus let alone how it works need to work on this as its very unforgiving but to be honest the best thing that i can say about this game is the fact that theres a TRADING SYSTEM !!!!!!!! yes this is the only game in existance of all CCGs ive seen and played wher ethey incorperated a trading system in their game for players to trade cards and actually functions properly !!!! unlike MTG especially ones i have plaed never had a trading system incorped in them at all once so ever. this is a major awesome PLUS!!!my rating would be 9/10 a msut play for anyone whos crazy about TCGs let alone CCGs

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 29, 2015
												Very Fun card game revolving around the deck you build, there are almost unlimited choices you can make with the decks that are already given to you right when you enter.The decks that you build require you to have a minimum of 40 cards but its maximum is unlimited, you can have anyamount of cards if you have the requirements for them to be in your deck. Some people say its a Pay To Play, but the game it self rewards you with cards, booster packs, and the 2 types of points used to buy the booster packs or even Deck packs for just logging in for a few days straight!There are 3 ways you can win if you choose to play this game, by reducing your opponents health from 100 to 0, or doing the same with there Moral from 100 to 0, or by accomplishing the requirements from certian cards that you play when you have them in your hand. And unlike Hearthstone or Magic the Gathering, this game has alot more original and creative aspects to a card game that i have seen. There is a market DURING the games you play to Draw a card, Swap a card out for a random one, or To increase the Maximun resource counter you have. There is even a commander out post for 3 creature cards of your choice (which can be immediatly played if you have the resources) and thoese creatures can have amsome abilities, like " Pay 2, Summon a 3/2 minion in to your safe zone". Most creature and character cards have that awsome aspect to them that make this game alittle bit complicated but still fun in the end.To just simplify, its a really fun game that is original and should have some time in the spotlight for its amazing gaming concepts.

												Really a surprisingly good game.It has a lot of mechanics that makes the game very interesting. Both players play their turn at the same time, there is a stat called morale that works a bit like health but provides a different win condition and there are 3 different "zones" on the battlefield that impact the game differently. 												I really want to like this game…However the amount of broken combos is crazy. And trust me there are plenty of people who will use them. My opinion is it will take months if not years to clean up the amount of broken card combinations that will destroy a well thought out deck. It really gets down to just studying the cards, and creating a deck to exploit combos and you will win…simple as that. The game is not pay to win, and it is fun initially, until you start running into said players and decks mentioned above. When you point out this fact to the players utilizing these types of combos/decks, a simple “lol” is the typical response. The elitist I have run into don’t have any desire to admit their deck is broken, instead to them it’s perfectly legit. The Game should have started with a far more simplified game play and stuck with an overall tactical approach to winning a battle... instead of the current game mechanics are gather a few cards and exploit said combo…then gg. They have a massive uphill battle to try an undo this as the current inventory of cards/abilities/clans/etc are endless…as soon as one exploit if finally exposed and corrected two more will pop up. A CCG should start simple and small and work towards complex and large…this game did the opposite. So if you want to take the time and exploit some broken card combos, then this game is for you.For now I’m changing my negative to a positive. After playing several more hours I have determined that a lot of the broken combos I stated in my earlier review can be countered. However I do think there are some cards and combos that are broken and too powerful. For now I am enjoying the game again, but there is a huge learning curve with the vast amount of cards, so unless you are willing to dedicate some serious time this is not a game for you. This is without a doubt NOT a PAY to Win! And I love that! More to come.Yea, too many broke cards and combos...but game could be good after some major tweaks.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
												Let me start out by saying that I love CCG games.  Infinity Wars has not dissappointed but for me it leaves a little to be desired.  I know it is out of the norm that someone who enjoys playing CCG games prefers to strictly play offline against the AI, but that is me.  With that being said, if you're looking for a type of review based on the online PvP of the game you won't find it here.On that note, I'll go over the good features of the game.  I love the illustrations and the variety of cards in themselves is great.  Also, the animation on EVERY card is a nice touch.  The cards are well-thought, mostly balanced with some Epic cards being game changers but in my opinion, thats the great thing about the CCG game.  The gameplay, process, and strategy that are involved is also very good.  Without getting into it too deep, you basically have your character cards, gear cards, location cards etc.  Your main goal is to destroy your enemies fortress by attacking with your characters.  A nice twist on this game however, is that each character has a listed morale.  Now if that creature dies, your faction loses that much morale.  Your starting fortress and morale bars start at 100 each.  If either reach 0 then you lose the game.  Like I said, just the basics as there are certain strategies to get you to that goal.  You can also completely customize your decks with cards awarded after receiving new booster packs after each level gained or through their online store for purchase.  I've played about 11 hours on this game so far and have not spent anything as of yet and have several Rare cards, 1 Epic, and 0 Legendaries at this point to give you an idea.  One major love of mine regarding the customization is that there are 3 slots for you to choose which faction you want in that slot.  You can assign a Commander for each one of those 3 slots, ensuring those cards are on the battlefield for you at game start.My only negative point with this game is that there really isn't any other mode for me to play other than "Practice".  And this mode only allows me to play against 4 specific decks with a rated difficulty.  Therefore, 11hrs in I'm getting a little bored.  Other than that, if you're into the online gaming then this might be for you as I feel like the gaming mechanics and overall replayability of the game is right on.

												I'm not playing this for long but i was suprised how much of a copy of MTG it seems to be, positively. Surely it looks different but if you know MTG well enough you will notice that its basically the same with slight changes. You will declare attackers and defenders aswell, just not in the form of tapping but in the form of moving the cards to specific areas. Cast creatures cant be moved to any of those areas instead they are resting in the Support area whey they cant attack or block.The biggest Changes to MTG are:No mana cards - You get +1 Mana every turnMana is colorlessPlayers make their moves at the same timeMonster HP does not reset at the end of the turnAnd the most weirdest part, 1 Monster can block every attacking Monster if it has enough HP and propably destroy every attacker.So basically it feels like a slightly easier MTG and fans, just like me, could enjoy it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
												This is a great game.  I've always loved TCG's (mostly MTG and Yugioh back in the day) and they were fun but I've always known that they could be done better on a computer.  An online digital card game can do so many things that a physical TCG can't (like animated cards, auto match-making, zero rule disputes) and Infinity Wars totally nails it.  If you've ever played MTGO *shudder* then you'll be dumbfounded by how poor an it is in comparison to IW.   Solid excecution aside, Infinity Wars also succeeds on the artwork side of things.  Any collector/player would probably agree that card art is an important part of getting involved with these games.  The artists for IW know what they're doing.  The cards look fantastic and they're animated to boot.  It's dark/gritty comic-book feel and just looks awesome.  Finally, and most importantly, we have gameplay.  Here is where I think the game should really take off.  It's completely original and operates totally different from any TCG I've ever playeed.  One of the most interesting things about it (going back to what a digital game can do that a physical one can't) is that people plan and execute their turns simultaneously.  Nobody gets to go "first" and you're generally not having to deal with a lot of the annoying "priority" issues that you find in games like MTG.  This completely changes the dynamics and tempo of the gameplay and it's a lot of fun.  I would recommend anyone who likes TCG's to try this out.  It's free to start and you can actually get a lot of gaming in without buying anything.  So far I've spent about $25 and I'm holding my own in the ranked queues pretty well.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 11, 2015
												Read this review first. Also, I started playing this game two weeks ago from the post date of 8/11/15, so everything I'm saying is current.This. Game. Is. *Awesome*.I played Magic The Gathering my entire childhood, MTG Online, WoW TCG, Hearthstone, and Hex, and they all pale in comparison. I've heard nonsense in these reviews ranging from matchmaking issues to.... "ths game sux cuz not nuff dbl xp wkends".... (seriously? lol)At the end of the day, TCG's (or CCG's *shrug*) are *all* about the cards, and mechanics of the game. This game is So much more fun, complex, and strategic than *any* other game in the genre, bar none. Anyone who tells you differently is lying, an idiot, or rage-quit because they lost their first battle and got angwy.I'm not just some fanboy. There are a couple of glitches, and from what I hear, there could be a better matchmaking system I guess (though I find I win a completely reasonable amount of matches, regardless of being new). However, the game itself just can't be beat. Try playing this game for a few days and going back to Hearthstone. Go ahead, I just did it. I was literally *bored* to tears. It doesn't have one tenth the depth or strategy that Infinity Wars has. It's just a fact, guys.The cards are *beautiful*, *all of them are animated*, and...you...can... *trade* with your friends... (or enemies, or strangers... whatever). For those of you who have actually played other online TCG's, I'm sure you can appreciate putting the 'T' back into the acronym. I don't know about you guys, but that was half of what it was about when I was a kid. There are *8* incredibly distinct and well-designed factions to choose from, each with their own goals, combos and strategies that make sense, and carry a personality of their own. You can *combine* them into a deck of your choosing, and the combinations really let your own deck designs shine. The game has 4 zones during play. One of which is the 'Commander' zone, which is a set of 3 characters of your choosing that start on the board from turn 1. While I, myself, found it a bit 'too much' when i first started, it's come to be one of the most amazing and distinguishing mechanics this game has to offer, bringing a new level of customization and gauranteed strategy to your deck.Don't listen to the nay-sayers. If you're here on this page because you're bored of what little Hearthstone has to offer, download this, and thank me later.

Posted: April 3, 2015
												If you like TCGs then you should definitely check this one out. Beautiful, animated artwork is a great touch. Gameplay is fairly intuitive and basic, however there are tons of rules that need to be learned. Just the right amount of challenging without it feeling unfair. I really like that any deck is fair game; ie. there are no go-to decks that are a guaranteed win. The more you play and unlock achievements (in game, not steam) you get more cards so it doesn't feel pay2win. There is a store available just like any other free to play game where you can buy booster packs, decks, and aethetic changes such as icons, card backs, and battlefields (the area in which the cards are played). All can be purchased with money or points you accumulate from playing. Although, between the ability to buy cards and decks with points, and being able to trade with others- you should be able to make any deck you desire without spending a cent.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 9, 2015
												A game that can actually burn time without you noticing it. Would actually give it a high rating, were it not for the large gap between old and new players. Although basic cards can be received from playing the campaign and finishing quests, they are not enough to be able to compete with the higher level/older players. This becomes a bigger problem due to a seemingly broken matchmaking system. It's either a few players are playing or bad matchmaking since a player can get paired up with a high-ranking/veteran player, which can demoralize a player.Sure you can say that when playing the game more, you earn in-game currency to buy booster packs/decks, but it is not enough to actually bring the new player to compete or at least have a chance. For example, a VICTORY gives only 150 IP tops but not guaranteed, while a booster pack costs 5250 IP, which means a required minimum of 35 wins. Decks, on the other hand, cost 12,950 IP, which reuires a minimum of 87 wins with maximum IP gained. Considering loses only give ~50 IP and new players rarely having good cards, it makes the game into a grind of a sort. Of course, there is the last resort of actually purchasing cards with real money for those who want to support the game. With the low amount of IP gained per match and expensive cost of card packs/decks, the game seems to tell players to "buy or suffer grind."I'd recommend the game since it shows promise, but due to the current system it may dismay some players.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								Its a good game.On the topic of Digital TCG and it being pay2win I gotta say no.Well, the difference between good cards and common cards can often be pretty drastic.However - the game uses a system in which one has to declare 3 of your own cards to be commanders - and the difference between a good Deck and a bad One is often decided by how well these three synergize.Which is a strong point of the game, because grinding just 3 cards together who do synergize is absolutely possible by just playing the different Solo-Campaigns - ofcourse this relies quite a bit on luck.However i've experienced the Reward and Achievementystem of Infinity Wars to be really fair - the game awards you quite often with a series of cards or single ones. In just some days I had quite a lot of the rare cards of the game - however the turning point for me was just getting that one commander who could win me games by being good as a standalone and synergizing with pretty much every faction.Unlike games like Pox Nora - i appreciate it that the starterdecks you unlock via the different campaigns are freely adjustable and every card goes in to your collection - so one can build quite diverse decks from the getgo.The thing is - when I start games like this i want to build my own decks right from the start and play even games - you know: win some lose some. However the bad matchmaking (sometimes I wonder if there even IS a matchmaking - 'cause even as a beginner you will get thrown in against veteran players with badges all over your screen quite often) could make on believe this game is pay2win. But even if your cards and strategies where of the same strength - good players will own you any day in this. The game is quite skilldependent and the time you need to learn the basics even and when to play your cards, learning which faction your opponent is playing and therefore how it can react will be accompanied by loss after loss.However the animated cards are quite a funny feature and the art is good - nothing i really dig like the MTG-Artworks but good all around.I dont like about the game that there's no way to get rid of soulbound cards you have to many of. (Most Cards are limited to three per deck - however the game won't stop to hand you out the 20th copy of the same wealthy noble ever)The game is quite lively and the community is rather nice.By that I mean roughly half of your opponents won't react to chat whatsoever - a quarter will 'gg' but I had quite nice short chats with rest of the lot. No Flame, no trolling - quite harmonic.Anyone who likes digital TCG and wants to give this a try I'd recommend playing it for ten hours or so - that's when you'll mostly likely have enough experience with the game, grinded enough to have a nice collection of cards + the occasional gamemaker-cards so the diversity will unfold before you.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								Exciting and Frustrating.Exciting:  There are lots of different cards with different powers, and turns are played simultaneously, so there is lots of tension and excitement and surprises.  This plays very differently than other cards games in which matches have more of a sense of grinding them out and focussing on small advantages.  Another plus during the Beta is that you receive lots of free cards (including one per day for simply logging in), so if this game catches your interest you might as well download it and start collecting free cards in case you like it.Frustrating:  There are certain uber cards and uber combos, most of which are rare.  And at least during the Beta, a majority of the players I encounter are long-time players with good collections.  Therefore, it is not uncommon during a match for a newer player to be totally outmatched by cards and tactics that you have no chance of countering.  My hope is that once the game is published there will be a large base of players so that newer players will mostly play against other newer players. Another frustration is that, at least as of this writing, there is no replay function, which means that sometimes effects will happen and you will have no idea how or what happened.  The company says that a replay feature will be added.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												Infinity Wars is a TCG that reminds me of the Star Wars Galaxies Trading Card Game.  Infinity Wars has several factions that each have their own play style.  The tech faction is about upgrading your units to hell and beyond with cards such as (GIVE THAT MAN A JETPACK!) and the ability to combine units, so you can take an unit w ith tons of defense and one with tons of attack, and make one super unit that will nuke the ♥♥♥♥ out of everything.  The tech zombie faction takes dead units and revives them to return them to the game.  The Star Trek faction (not even ♥♥♥♥ing kidding) takes your enemy's units and makes them join your side.  The flaming dawn uses incredibly excessive attack to destroy the enemy base before they can get set up.It seems that every card in the game can be gotten for free if you take enough time, so that's nice.  The game systems are taught through a tutorial, so I'll only speak about my favorite of which.  You have three cards as a sort of sidedeck.  The three cards you choose in this sidedeck will be in a special zone at the start of the game.  These are called your commanders.  They determine the faction of your deck.  If you use one flaming dawn, one tech, and one zombie, for instance, you can use the weakest cards of all of them.  If you use two flaming dawn and one tech, you can use the tier 2 cards of flaming dawn and the tier ones of tech.  If you have all flaming dawn, you can use the tier 3s of flaming dawn.  This system allows you to choose between specializing or mixing.  It also makes it easier to get started, as you don't need a LOT of cards from one faction, just 20-30 from three of your choice to have a deck.  (You start out with a fairly crappy deck of your choice, btw, which you should only use in merged play or pauper mode, and use the free weekly decks for normal gameplay.)There are three game types that I have unlocked so far.  Infinite, which is just use the decks as normal.  Merged, which mixes the two players decks together, so you can use the same cards as your opponent and be on an equal field.  And finally, pauper, which forces both players to use common and uncommon cards.Give it a try, you'll only regret it a little.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								Still has bugs and less than satisfying UI, it's a beta, but at its core it's the best digital ccg you can play right now in terms of mechanics. And unlike most digital ccgs, it actually has trading. The art is mostly dark/adult oriented and has character, and all the cards being animated is a nice touch. The simultaneous turn resolution makes it so you don't wait as long for your opponent to play, and adds an extra layer of psychological warfare and strategy to what is already a pretty complex game. This has the potential (keyword potential) to topple M:TG if the developers manage to stay afloat for long enough to polish everything, and I hope they do.In conclusion, I'd say that if you like CCGs and don't give this game a shot, you are crazy.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								IW is fun and accessible to the flexible gamer, but be prepared for a rocky user experience and an odd juxtaposition of content.Paying for advantage is an inseparable part of this genre.  However, IW does a very good job of giving new players and f2p'ers free decks and cards to play with.   If you get good, you can win cards and the in-game currency to buy card packs.  I didn't find the simultaneous turns clunky.  It's a relatively novel mechanic that is likely counter-intuitive to experienced card players.  As a dabbling TCG/CCG gamer, it wasn't any more challenging a mechanic than any other in the game.  This game is complex and a casual gamer should be prepared for tough play.My concerns about the game are bugs in the client and the dev teams ability to ever iron out bugs and implement features.   The client has always been very, very buggy and prone to all sorts of weird behavior, including desyncs between player clients!  I would caution potential spenders given the slow rate of development and the severity of some bugs.I am extremely skeptical about the integrity of a team that would create crossovers with well-established franchises before their own game is even officially released.  I'm sure Star Trek decks appeal to some players, but, frankly, it smacks of pandering and, to my eyes, belies confidence in their original content and IP.  More to the point, Star Trek hardly shares common thematic elements, beyond very broad themes common to almost any sci-fi/science fantasy setting.  The very inclusion is jarring to me.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 14, 2015
												As someone who hasn't played a whole lot of card games before IW, I have to say it is an enjoyable game rewarding in equal ammount strategy, predicting your opponent and creativity in deck building. Even if just one of the three appeals to you, the game is worth a try, as even casual play is rewarding and the game is comparably (to the F2P standard) generous with its free rewards. You can get boosters for ingame currency and levelling up also grants you a free soulbound booster. Not to mention logging in and playing 3 games per day awards a free card each,At this point you might be wondering: will the game be worth a play if you want to stay free and not spend anything on it? The answer is yes, many of the most powerful and useful cards are of low rarity, with the exception of a few decks it is rare to see a deck filled with high rarity cards. This along with the ease of earning new ones and the ability to trade makes it fairly easy to get a decent deck running once you've gotten familiar with the game.As for negatives: the game has bugs, owing to the limitations of the developers. They vary in severity with an occasional desync bug even capable of ruining a game, others merely being a nuissance (naccurate card text, a button name giving an error message) or causing unexpected card interaction, although these cases seem the exception rather than a rule by my experience.All in all the game feels like an unpolished gem. It has a great core, fun gameplay, variety of choice in deck creation, but is held back by bugs and what seems to be a limitation of dev resources.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												This is a mixed review. I am no stranger to CCGs both digital and tangible (MTG, Yugioh, Hearthstone, now Infinity Wars) and have invested many hours and dollars into them over many years. It could be said with confidence that I enjoy them and understand advanced concepts within them. I was seeking an alternative to Hearthstone when I came across IW and gave it a shot as a free to play digital game with fully animated cards of generally good quality art. The core concepts were interesting, although the game does not do a totally adequate job explaining the functionality of all the various "zones" (nor is it uniform in their terminology as some cards refer to the "assault" zone as the "attack" zone) and it was only after several hours of play and deck building that i discovered the "purity" mechanic required to understand competant deck building. I also discovered some cards do not function entirely as written in the card text, but surely these complaints can be fixed via future patches. Overall I have had fun with IW. The campaign mode, while comprised of a very nonsensical plot, has some interesting stage puzzles to be solved, though some campaigns can be steamrolled via custom deck building that trivializes certain AI factions. The AI in general is rather poor, in some cases it plays cards to the support zone and then seems to forget they exist. In other cases it stays the course when death is inevitable rather than adapting its strategy. But CCGs are meant to be played against humans, so let's discuss that aspect.This is where my review turns sour. Match making is garbage. INB4 people say i'm complaining about losses. I'm not. It is garbage because I will click to play and just sit there for upwards of MINUTES (if it at all) before being matched and then it is against players with a wealth more experience than I (the new player). I am uncertain if this is the fault of poor MM programming or if it an indicator of just how few people play the game. High quality cards can be negated as an advantage with the mode that mixes both player's decks together (new players should ALWAYS pick their opponents commanders, they likely have a meta strat instead of just picking their 3 coolest looking characters). This makes it come down to purely player skill and luck of the draw, such as who gets all the CC and who gets nothing but infinity character cards. The players themselves seem friendly enough, but it is obvious that most of what you will find are veterans of the alpha build of the game, having either spent 100s of real money on cards, or simply having invested 1000s of hours during the game's hight of player usage (which, if that time is now, then what a sad state of affairs). So ultimately I would recommend this game if only to grow the player base and improve match making for new players. The various factions are unique from one another (but otherwise cliche) and mixing and matching your deck is fun. I think I'd prefer this game more if it was a physical card game i could pick up and play at a local card shop with people of equal skill and humble disposable incomes.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								Its a good game.On the topic of Digital TCG and it being pay2win I gotta say no.Well, the difference between good cards and common cards can often be pretty drastic.However - the game uses a system in which one has to declare 3 of your own cards to be commanders - and the difference between a good Deck and a bad One is often decided by how well these three synergize.Which is a strong point of the game, because grinding just 3 cards together who do synergize is absolutely possible by just playing the different Solo-Campaigns - ofcourse this relies quite a bit on luck.However i've experienced the Reward and Achievementystem of Infinity Wars to be really fair - the game awards you quite often with a series of cards or single ones. In just some days I had quite a lot of the rare cards of the game - however the turning point for me was just getting that one commander who could win me games by being good as a standalone and synergizing with pretty much every faction.Unlike games like Pox Nora - i appreciate it that the starterdecks you unlock via the different campaigns are freely adjustable and every card goes in to your collection - so one can build quite diverse decks from the getgo.The thing is - when I start games like this i want to build my own decks right from the start and play even games - you know: win some lose some. However the bad matchmaking (sometimes I wonder if there even IS a matchmaking - 'cause even as a beginner you will get thrown in against veteran players with badges all over your screen quite often) could make on believe this game is pay2win. But even if your cards and strategies where of the same strength - good players will own you any day in this. The game is quite skilldependent and the time you need to learn the basics even and when to play your cards, learning which faction your opponent is playing and therefore how it can react will be accompanied by loss after loss.However the animated cards are quite a funny feature and the art is good - nothing i really dig like the MTG-Artworks but good all around.I dont like about the game that there's no way to get rid of soulbound cards you have to many of. (Most Cards are limited to three per deck - however the game won't stop to hand you out the 20th copy of the same wealthy noble ever)The game is quite lively and the community is rather nice.By that I mean roughly half of your opponents won't react to chat whatsoever - a quarter will 'gg' but I had quite nice short chats with rest of the lot. No Flame, no trolling - quite harmonic.Anyone who likes digital TCG and wants to give this a try I'd recommend playing it for ten hours or so - that's when you'll mostly likely have enough experience with the game, grinded enough to have a nice collection of cards + the occasional gamemaker-cards so the diversity will unfold before you.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2015

												Currently I am at an odd stance with this game. I see its potential, but it seems held back by the way it treats new players. Is it pay 2 win? No. But while it isn't pay 2 win, it is very tough on new players. The matchmaking system shows no mercy upon new players, and you will be thrown against those who have much better deck comps than you. Is it possible to win with the beginner decks? Yes. But your chances of winning are much lower than those who have been playing the game for a long time. I've had fun with the game, and enjoyed the various different cards. But the multiple different classes and playstyles, makes it take forever to get an interesting comp together unless you want tospend money, or grind through the monotony of a beginner deck.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2015
												Big Magic the Gathering player here.One major turn off of Infinity Wars isn't that there are counters, but that there are HARD counters.I was running a Aggro deck of mostly 1 drop 4/2s, and would easily win most matchups. Then I would run into the Chinese based Defense Matters army and usually lose. No big deal, It's a bad matchup and you have to have those. Mind you I would still win 20% of the time, so there was always a chance.Then you run into the Chaotic ♥♥♥♥ers. Forget what the mechanic was called, but as long as you didn't kill the Monster/Creature/whatever it heals the damage you dealt to it and gets buffed whenever it kills something. Considering it's a 5/5 and my 12 guys running into it are 4/2s, it eats ALL of them. Coupled with the surprise factor, I could easily have my opponent down to 15 health only for them to flip one of those and suddenly be staring down a 45/45 Hexproof Indestructable with my entire board gone. Oh yeah. This damn thing that just ate my entire board? "Cannot be killed by Non Damage Means" and "Cannot be targetted by spells your opponents control". So my Kill spells can't get it out of the way, I can't bounce the damn thing out of the way,  my creatures stand no chance, and it's either don't attack or lose my force.All in all I was highly enjoying my time with this game, but when you go up against a deck that literally folds to you UNLESS they get one of their copies of a creature you literally can't touch, that's ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.It's a damn shame because the mechanics are tight, the (usual) way to play is highly skill based, and a right or wrong move can make or break a match. But then you just run headlong into hard counter and there's not a DAMN thing you can do.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												Game play is incredible fun and very addicting!  For that reason alone I highly recommend this game.This game has tremendous potential, and after having played it for some time (over 45 hours of game play at the time of this review), I suspect that a high amount of bugs and an often very unintutitive UI is what is holding this game back. In my case I found trying to view all my cards/deck building frustrating. And the first time my husband and I traded cards, the trade occurred without either one of us realizing that I didn't get my cards from the trade until I went to use them and couldn't find them. Imagine a UI where a person could make a trade like that with the wrong person. I would be unimpressed if this happened with anyone other than my husband who of course kindly re-traded the cards. In addition, I had to reboot the game constantly due to duel invites not being received from others on my friends list.But -- this game is free. What do you have to lose by trying it out? While the game is free, you have the option to purchase cards, but it certainly is not necessary to do so to enjoy the game. You are able to earn points to purchase cards with in-game currency if you desire to go that route. I would recommend anyone to give it a try, the game itself is amazing fun, but be prepared to deal with bugs and a UI that will sometimes leave you scratching your head.In the end, if the bugs are fixed and the UI made more intuitive, this game could sincerely blow other TCG's out of the water in my opinion, without question.  The game play itself is simply that much fun.

												I wasn't expecting much from this game. I downloaded it mostly out of boredom. This game plesently surpised me! I'm really having fun with it. content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												Updated review after many months away.Same story as in the early access. Lots and lots of potential here. It just oozes it everywhere. However there are 3 big things that made me uninstall this for the last time.1. Most importantly is bugs. Bugs everywhere. I have lost so many matches that I actually won because the game froze and I was forced to quit out. Not to mention endless animation loops that force you to quit. also there are constant disconnects mid match. This is crippling in rift running where you only get 3 shots and your done. When you have a killer deck and end up losing it because bugs force restarts then it really kills your joy.2. Booster packs take foreeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeever to earn once your boosted xp from low levels goes away. you get 170-350 currency for losing/winning. a booster costs 5250. as you can see you need a lot of wins or even more combinations of losses and wins to get 15 cards. There is trading but no auction house which this game desperately needs. 15+ wins for one booster might be tolerable assuming you win all matches except for problem 3.3. The community is very very very veeeeeeeeery small. I have sat in queues for unranked or ranked for 30-90 minutes with no matches. If you play at the peak hours its tolerable, but god forbid you want to play on non peak times. There just isn't a large enough player base for a pvp focused game. Even hex, duels of champions, and sol forge have larger player bases. Another consequence of the small player base is you are much more likely to get constantly steam rolled by the people that can dump hundreds and even for some thousands into this game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												Infinity Wars is a TCG that reminds me of the Star Wars Galaxies Trading Card Game.  Infinity Wars has several factions that each have their own play style.  The tech faction is about upgrading your units to hell and beyond with cards such as (GIVE THAT MAN A JETPACK!) and the ability to combine units, so you can take an unit w ith tons of defense and one with tons of attack, and make one super unit that will nuke the ♥♥♥♥ out of everything.  The tech zombie faction takes dead units and revives them to return them to the game.  The Star Trek faction (not even ♥♥♥♥ing kidding) takes your enemy's units and makes them join your side.  The flaming dawn uses incredibly excessive attack to destroy the enemy base before they can get set up.It seems that every card in the game can be gotten for free if you take enough time, so that's nice.  The game systems are taught through a tutorial, so I'll only speak about my favorite of which.  You have three cards as a sort of sidedeck.  The three cards you choose in this sidedeck will be in a special zone at the start of the game.  These are called your commanders.  They determine the faction of your deck.  If you use one flaming dawn, one tech, and one zombie, for instance, you can use the weakest cards of all of them.  If you use two flaming dawn and one tech, you can use the tier 2 cards of flaming dawn and the tier ones of tech.  If you have all flaming dawn, you can use the tier 3s of flaming dawn.  This system allows you to choose between specializing or mixing.  It also makes it easier to get started, as you don't need a LOT of cards from one faction, just 20-30 from three of your choice to have a deck.  (You start out with a fairly crappy deck of your choice, btw, which you should only use in merged play or pauper mode, and use the free weekly decks for normal gameplay.)There are three game types that I have unlocked so far.  Infinite, which is just use the decks as normal.  Merged, which mixes the two players decks together, so you can use the same cards as your opponent and be on an equal field.  And finally, pauper, which forces both players to use common and uncommon cards.Give it a try, you'll only regret it a little.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												Really solid TCG.Pretty innovative mechanics in the Command, Attack, Defense and Support Zones and simultaneous turns. Sort of struck me as strange at first, since you don't answer your opponent's plays in typical TCG fashion, but instead have to outwit your opponent and predict what they're going to do on the current turn. Definitely adds a unique spin on things, and gets a bit easier to do (obviously) as you learn the cards and factions.Speaking of factions, there are eight, each with a free, basic unlockable starter deck. All factions are very different from each other, and up to three factions can be combined into a single deck, offering a ton of variety in builds.The free-to-play model is executed very well here, in my opinion, as you get a free card for logging in every day, and another (or sometimes a 15-card booster pack, though personally this has only happened once) for playing three full games that day. Any rarity card is obtainable this way, including Legendary, the highest rarity. There are also weekly quests, which award one card each, and a campaign for each faction, which unlocks the starter deck I mentioned earlier as well as some extra cards for that faction. Finally, every time you level up, you get a free booster pack. Buying packs with the in-game currency, Infinity Points, however, is definitely grindy, and it's pretty much one of the only cons I have with this game. Despite my never having bought a pack though, I have quite a few good cards, including a few Epics and a Legendary, and for the most part, can hold my own in a PVP match.Overall, I'm really liking this game, and it can only get better as more content is added.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
												Changed to a Recommended because in the end I still enjoy playing the game.  The largest issues the game stem from its low player base and the nightmare that Lightmare Studios is.  Below is my negative review because, while the game is free, you should know what you're getting into and what its history looks like.~~~Changed to a "not recommended" because of the recent shop changes.  Long story short, you basically have to purchase lightmare points with real money to buy cards like you used to.  ~~~They've made changes from the original card packs to these new "penta-packs."  You can purchase faction packs, which made me really excited, until I realized you have to use lightmare points, 300 of them for 5 cards.  300lp =~ $3 dollars if you start with 0lp.  $3 dollars for a 5-virtual-card pack guaranteeing no more than ONE rare.If you want to buy cards using in-game currency, you only have two options, where you used to have 8ish, one pack from each new set of cards released.  Now, you can pick from the original card set, or the entire bunch of cards available.  The IW2013 Penta-pack and the Collection Penta-pack.  These each cost 3000 infinity points, where you used to be able to buy a pack of 3(?) for a little over 1000.  We can no longer buy packs of 15 for a little over 5000, they removed that feature entirely.  When they made these changes, it became practically impossible for me to card hunt like I used to.  I would buy card-set packs containing the cards I was looking for, 15 cards for 5000 like I said before.  These are the changes they made to the shop, and were the last straw for an otherwise avid player of the game.  I cannot and will not recommend the game because this has crossed the line and become pay-to-win.  Infinity Wars has a history of making the game harder and harder to enjoy for those who are not willing to purchase from the shop with real money, which should never be the case for any sort of game, free or not.
